for leave to introduce Bill C-380, an act to amend the Criminal Code (firearms).

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Pursuant to Standing Order 68(2), the motion is deemed adopted.

Madam Speaker, the purpose of this bill is to send a powerful message of deterrence to anyone thinking of taking a gun along on the commission of a crime.
This bill would significantly toughen section 85 of the Criminal Code, the section which makes it an offence to use a firearm while committing a crime. The minimum mandatory sentence would be increased from one year to five years for first offence and three years to eight years for any subsequent offence.
Under this bill there would be no eligibility for parole during that five or eight year period. The bill would also specifically prevent a mandatory sentence from having any impact on the sentence imposed for the other offence committed.
The bill specifically requires the written consent of the provincial attorney general before any section 85 charge could be withdrawn or plea bargained away.
The idea is not new. It was proposed by the former Prime Minister of Canada, the Right Hon. John G. Diefenbaker. It is also supported by police chiefs right across Canada and by the Canadian Police Association.

Madam Speaker, it is an honour to present a number of petitions today from
Northwest Territories, Yukon, Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia.
The petitioners say that they are residents of Canada and they wish to designate a day for the recognition of Canada's original inhabitants, to honour our native cultures, and that June 21 is the most appropriate day to recognize these First Nations.
Therefore they are calling upon Parliament to enact Bill C-268, an act respecting a national solidarity day for the First Nations of Canada.

Madam Speaker, on another topic, again the petitioners are by and large from British Columbia.
They point out their opposition to any notion of selling water to the United States and Mexico as a result of the North American free trade agreement.
They are asking the Government of Canada to state categorically through legislation that our rivers are not for sale.

Madam Speaker, I would like to table a petition from residents of Val-d'Or, Amos, Vassan, Sullivan, Val-Senneville and Saint-Ed-mond-d'Abitibi, stating that films depicting violence on television are dangerous and unacceptable because they encourage further violence.
They also point out that all toys that are an incentive to violent games are unacceptable and that production of such toys should be banned. Freedom of the press should be restricted when reporting acts of violence. The repeated reporting of acts of violence on all television channels and on radio may encourage similar acts of violence.
Wherefore your petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to pass legislation dealing with the above, to wipe out violence in our society, protect our children and guarantee everyone in this country a better quality of life.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, first of all, I am not surprised to see Liberal members trying to prevent us from explaining to Canadians.
This is just one more instance of their lack of courtesy toward the person who has the floor. It is typical of the Liberals, and I suppose they just want to show how little they care about the problems facing Canadians today.

It is typical of the Liberal Party. Put your head in the sand and continue. Canadians value very much that kind of attitude.
Madam Speaker, could we have order in the House? [Translation]
Could we have some order in the House? I realize the Liberal Party is anxious to hide the facts from Canadians.

Over many years this Chamber has been no stranger to hot and heavy debates on economic issues, especially on the numerous occasions over the last 30 years or more
Government Orders
when the world was in a recession or, as it is today, emerging from the global downturn.
Those in this House who have lived through the many cycles of our economy since the downturn of the early 1960s and on, or those who have studied our economic history know better than most that there are two certainties.
First, recessions will come, but recessions will most assuredly pass. Each downturn in the economy will often be greeted as if it were the first in history, a sudden apparition demanding to be cleanly and surgically removed, never to return again.
Second, as we emerge from a downturn we each must resist the siren song which would delude us into believing that quick fixes will remove the pain, creating illusions of growth. The only responsible and enduring policy response which is effective is to manage our national economy as if it were our very own personal economy.
Those who have been around here for a while know full well that regardless of the heat of the debate or the degree of the righteous indignation expressed at any moment, and certainly the walls of this Chamber have heard it all before, there have been precious few governments before that focus on the fundamental principles so consistently to serve the long-term interests of all Canadians.
In the aftermath of yesterday's statement by my colleague, the Minister of Finance, the opposition parties would like to underline their perceptions and what they want Canadians to perceive for cheap political reasons.
I see that in the NDP member there. Those who have a corner on virtue, the socialist magpies there, will they stand up and ask the president of the New Democratic Party to withdraw and retract her untrue statements to Canadians yesterday that the changes mean that sexually harassed women in Canada no longer get protection under the UI act?
That was the statement of the president of their party. It is an untrue statement and it is one which I expect the righteous, truthful, honest, socialists to demand that their president withdraw and retract because it is a falsehood to Canadian women. I hope that they do it.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
The announcement made yesterday showed clearly that this government has made human resource development the top priority of the economic policy of this government.
In answer to the tens of thousands of Canadians from all regions of Canada who have participated in the community talks under the prosperity initiatives, yes, those members over on the other side, their absence was noted at those community talks with the the real people, the workers, the bosses, the employers, the educators. The message from coast to coast to coast was the same: Invest in human resources because this is the key to our development.
No one has heard any of those great members over on the other side underlining the fact that the cuts announced yesterday by the Minister of Finance were necessary. We know it is not nice to cut programs, but we had no choice. We as a country and we as a people must pay our way.

Why should newborn babies in this country not have the right to start with a clean slate like anybody else? Unfortunately, from day one they are stuck with a debt they will carry with them for the rest of their lives. Today, in a consistent and coherent manner, thanks to the Labour Force Development Board-

-we have made investment in people a top priority.
What about those displaced workers? Those members on the other side who pretend to care, why do they not look at the strong measures taken in the statement by the government yesterday to invest in people?
A special $300 million program will be targeted to long-term employed people who are permanently displaced because of restructuring. They will have special counselling and special enhancement training programs tailor-made to their needs. There are over 100,000 Canadians with long-time attachment to work who will benefit from this measure.

For instance, what about the decision to freeze employer premiums for small businesses? It is a fact that the contribution of small business to the Canadian economy is very substantial, and this positive measure will inject almost $500 million more into our economy to create jobs. Of course, they would rather not mention that measure because it is a positive one.
What really makes me sick, if you will pardon the expression, is the way they seem to use other people's misery to score political points.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Oh, oh.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
For the sake of scoring minor political points with other people's misery, they object to the responsible measures the government is introducing in order to invest in human resources and get employers and unions to work together to meet the challenges facing every industrialized country on this planet.
These people seem to think that Canada is a self-contained unit, a small island isolated from the rest of the world, where we can ignore the realities of a global economy. So what happens to 70 per cent of our production? We are an exporting country, and the key to Canada's economic success is a highly trained work force.

Those measures in there are taken in a revolutionary way. This measure, this central partnership initiative, and history will record it, I predict to you, will change forever the way we do business in Canada. Oh yes, I see the strange faces on the other side.
This government has fostered partnership. It has brought special equity groups, the labour movement and the business sector together at one table called the Labour Force Development Board, to put forward measures to help Canadians face the challenge of human resource development.
No one will talk about the great program my colleague, the Minister of Finance, announced yesterday and which I call the program to prevent unemployment.
For the first time in a major way-I know I am being cut by time and of course Liberals do not want Canadians to get the good news. Canadians will still get the good news because, fortunately for Canada, it is not only this
December 3, 1992

place that we can use to bring the message to Canadians. We shall bring it because it is a message that Canadians must understand and must get in order to get Canada growing again, which I know will be a political disadvantage for these cheap politically-minded people.

The question was raised. It took unanimous consent to change the rule that at this point in the debate, after five hours of debate, there are only 10-minute periods that are not followed by 10 or 5 minutes for questions and comments, only 10-minute speeches.
Unanimous consent was sought to let the minister speak for 20 minutes instead of 10, and some wanted it to be followed with a question period. But the House did not give unanimous consent. Therefore we return automatically to the Standing Order which says that only 10-minute speeches are acceptable, unless at some point the House agrees unanimously to change it.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, in the past few months Canadians have made it absolutely clear that they are looking to this government and to all members of Parliament for some real leadership on the issue of jobs and the economy. I made a survey in my riding of all of the households in Victoria. We got a tremendous response from the people of Victoria to that householder. It became very clear again that the people of Victoria, and I know this is typical of all communities in Canada, want top priority given to achieving full employment in Canada within a reasonable period of time. By a 73 per cent majority, the respondents said the federal government has to work toward a goal of full employment.
They want working people and their unions to have a more active role in administering and designing training needs. They feel very strongly that the North American free trade agreement will do little to increase employment in Canada. In fact, 70 per cent believe it will increase unemployment in this country.
What is true in Victoria is true across this country. The reaction of the people of Canada as they begin to absorb the statement made yesterday by the Minister of Finance will be deep disappointment and, indeed, anger everywhere, except in the boardrooms of the financial institutions of this country. There is anger at the arrogance, complacency, meanness and incompetence of this government in the area of the economy.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
In Victoria the public service cutbacks and wage freeze will slow down the recovery that had begun to take place and will impose new burdens on people who can ill afford it. The tragedy is that the approach the Minister of Finance took yesterday and this government has taken over the last number of years is economically unnecessary. In fact, the Conservative policy is really not an economic policy, it is a choice which is driven by ideology and upper middle class complacency about the state of affairs in this country.
The member for Ontario across the way laughs at that. There are 1.6 million Canadians who are out of work. This is not simply the result of the policies of this government, and we on all sides should understand and concede that. It is in part because of the global recession. However, it is also in part because of the policies of this government and the underlying weaknesses in the Canadian economy.
The real people in Canada are the ones who will be hurt by the statement made yesterday by the Minister of Finance. This government had choices. By cutting the unemployment insurance benefits to try to save some money with this budget, the government is imposing a new hardship on those who will be going through the trauma of unemployment, often for the first time. People will have to look at trying to survive at the poverty line, which is what most people have to do on UI.
The government will be imposing this economic problem at a time when it has already previously imposed further delays in UI and unconscionable problems in the delivery of the UI system, problems which all members of Parliament become familiar with through the case work and constituency work they do.
Further, and this I think is the most venal provision in the statement made yesterday, the withdrawal of UI from those who quit or are terminated, apparently for cause, is completely fraught with difficulty and will produce these results. First, there will be terrible pressures imposed on those on the front line in Canada Employment Centres who have to make the initial decision as to whether the party is entitled to UI or not. It will produce a huge increase in appeals. It will encourage lying and cheating by either employers or employees who are seeking unemployment insurance
and have no ready alternatives. It will produce new pressures on social assistance and on welfare, yet another pass-through of this government's financial problems on to the provinces and municipalities across Canada. It will add stress to the lives of those who are already under stress as a result of the termination of their employment.
The minister of unemployment, as he was called at one point by my hon. friend from Annapolis Valley-Hants, took after my leader for suggesting that those who are sexually harassed would now lose employment. It should be absolutely understood, and I would have thought members opposite would understand, how the reality is going to take place.
When an employee suffers sexual harassment, as has been documented in case after case after case, it takes an enormous amount of courage to step forward and call the employer or the third party who is engaged in the sexual harassment. There will be case after case where people quit because they cannot stand the sexual harassment but are still afraid to raise the issue, or having raised it, cannot prove it within the time available before some official in UI.
While the minister is technically correct, that termination because of sexual harassment would entitle the individual to unemployment insurance, the minister fails to understand in I think a complacent and arrogant way, and so do the members opposite who will be supporting this legislation, that the reality will not permit that to be said and done and properly and fairly judged.
In fact, there is no reasonable system in place even to judge whether the sexual harassment has occurred or not. The reality is going to be that there will be hundreds of thousands of women who will lose their jobs because of sexual harassment and who will now not for practical purposes be entitled to unemployment insurance, again imposing this government's rigid ideology on the weaker members of our society.
The changes in the UI provisions in respect of quitting or termination also break a contractual commitment that this Parliament has essentially made to those who have contributed to UI over the years, an understanding of the basis of their commitment.
This originally started as an unemployment insurance program and thus had the elements of a commitment between this Parliament and the people who were
December 3, 1992

making payments. For the government to retroactively change that, albeit it will not apply to claims presently in progress, but those who have been contributing over the years and have a new claim, will now find it governed by changes of rules imposed retroactively by the government.
I said the tragedy is that this is not economically necessary. The Globe and Mail in an editorial yesterday gave the government three options: holding the line, modest cuts or deep cuts. This editorial points out very clearly that within a reasonable period of time, by simply holding the line on spending, but not deep cuts in public spending, the government could achieve the objective of reducing the deficit.
I would like to add that if the government would also take its responsibilities in the area of defence and policing defence expenditures seriously, including ending this ridiculous expenditure of $4.4 billion on helicopters, but in addition imposes a rigorous policing of expenditures, it could save the Canadian taxpayers billions of dollars and accelerate the reduction of the deficit which we all want.
This was a mean-spirited and difficult statement made by the Minister of Finance. I call upon the people of Canada to rise up and require and force the government to change the direction it has gone in the time that it has left in office, a brief time.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure and an honour for me this morning to speak on a document and a speech made by the Minister of Finance yesterday. To begin, let me emphasize the presence of the Minister of Finance who in his speech yesterday said to the opposition, "I am making my speech. I await your comments and your suggestions. I have a budget coming in March and I am waiting for you to give me your comments and suggestions in a non-partisan way for the good of Canada". That is what the Minister of Finance said yesterday in this House.
The Minister of Finance made his speech at 3.15 p.m. He was here in this House from 3.15 to midnight when the House adjourned. He was here to listen to the
Government Orders
opposition's suggestions and I commend him for that. We know the work and the importance of the department he leads. As well as being Deputy Prime Minister, he took the time and he is still taking the time today to be here to listen to suggestions.
At midnight I was talking with him and unfortunately we came to the conclusion that no one on the other side of the House up to midnight had made a suggestion for the good of Canada, not 25 suggestions, but one valid suggestion for the good of Canada.
I was interviewed by the media in Trois-Rivieres a few minutes ago and they told me that everyone was criticizing this morning and the opposition was critical of us. I said to them, "Yes, but what suggestions or ideas has the opposition put forward?" It is easy to criticize; just about anybody can do it. You do not even have to be an opposition member. But the Minister of Finance is the one who has proposed interesting, intelligent and practical solutions to ensure the well-being of our country.
Allow me to go over the speech made yesterday by the minister. You will hear people criticize from the point of view of small business, and you have heard various comments on that by different people. The Minister of Finance also heard these comments and yesterday he took action to help small-business people.
The Minister of Finance listened to Canadians because he knows that 80 per cent of all jobs in Canada are created by the small business sector. I hope that the opposition will also listen to Canadians. Madam Speaker, the support for small businesses is significant. This help is important to Canada's economic activity.
The minister did not mention any increase in unemployment insurance premiums for small businesses next year. He actually went further than that. Indeed, any small business which will be created in 1993, or that did not exist in 1992, and which will increase the number of its employees in 1993, will incur no additional UI premium costs, which translates into a subsidy of about $1,600 per employee for the year. Madam Speaker, I did not hear a lot of complaints about this measure. It is a good measure so people do not criticize it. But I did not hear many people from the other side congratulate the minister either, Madam Speaker. I did not hear them congratulate him even once.

Government Orders
Madam Speaker, he introduced a 10 per cent investment tax credit. Once again, the buyer of any new machinery or equipment will be entitled to that credit.
That is important. It often provides whatever little help the small business needed to upgrade its equipment, its machinery, but was somewhat reluctant to buy. Now they have this additional 10 percent tax credit.
The Small Businesses Loans Act had been mentioned, and the minister made an effort in that area in his 1992 budget and again yesterday, raising the ceiling to $250,000. That is great news for the people in the riding of Trois-Rivieres. They are many who have taken advantage of this particular act and I am convinced there will be even more following this further increase.
In addition, from now on, employees will be allowed to use their RRSPs to buy shares. That too is important and is in keeping with the private enterprise concept this government has put forward and has been trying to pursue for eight years now, the principle that jobs are created by the private sector in this country. Let us stop entertaining the belief that spending astronomical amounts can help. The Liberals did just that during three or four months in 1981-1982 without any specific direction regarding employment nor any kind of rhyme or reason for such spending. They called that job creation programs where people would do construction, repairs or paint jobs, just about anything for four months, just to find themselves back on unemployment at the end of these four months. Billions were spent on that, billions that are now painfully lacking and form the monstrous debt we inherited back in 1984 and that we also have to pay interest on. In spite of this heritage from the Liberals, the Minister of Finance managed to announce positive measures to support the Canadian economy and that of Quebec.
He has extended the home buyers' plan. Why? Again, because he has been listening to the Canadian people. He introduced this project and it has produced very positive results. As Minister of Finance he had choices to make. Again he has chosen to listen to the Canadian people. He must be given credit for that.
The issue of the two-year wage freeze will certainly be raised. It is never very exciting to announce a wage freeze or a 3 per cent cut in government spending and throughout departments. And it is not very exciting either to tell all government agencies except a few that they will get a 10 per cent cut over two years. But a minister or a government who want to act responsibly have to look after our future. And they also have to live with the legacy left to them.
Opposition parties will spend the whole day repeating that the finance minister did not get his budget projections right. I should like to remind you, Madam Speaker, that the IMF and the OECD were also wrong in their projections for 1992. The banks did not fare any better. All economists failed in their projections, because the economic situation changed not only in Canada but also in the whole world so that all the figures were altered. That is why everybody failed to gauge the real state of the economy. If you compare with all those fine experts, Madam Speaker, you will realize that our finance minister is not any worse. He was not that far off the mark but, just like everybody else, he has to take the international situation into account.
I still have a lot to say, Madam Speaker, but unfortunately, I see you are indicating that my time is almost up. lb conclude, all I am asking of the opposition in this second day of debate is that they at least put forward suggestions and ideas for the well-being of Canada.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I cannot say that I am pleased to be participating in this budget debate today. The debate is bom out of a profound sense of disappointment for many members of Parliament, a profound sense of frustration and of anger that today rather than debating an economic plan that would begin the process of restoring confidence in Canada's economy in putting the unemployed back to work; instead, we are forced to examine a document that is bereft of any imagination, bereft of any confidence, bereft of any compassion, bereft of any ideas about how to put this country, Canada, with all of its potential, back on the road to prosperity.
December 3, 1992

Perhaps it is not ironic that the Minister of Finance comes from the great province of Alberta. Albertans have expertise in a great many areas and one of the areas in which they have expertise is in the whole question of fossils; indeed, Alberta can be said to be the fossil centre of this country. This economic statement, this budget- because that is what it is-really is the work of a dinosaur, of a political party about to disappear from the face of Canada. Like a dinosaur that knows it is dying, this dinosaur with this document is attempting to leave its fossilized footprints behind long after it is gone.
We had a Conservative Party that had two choices, a party that confronted two paths, a party that has been in power for the last eight years. One path represented change, an acknowledgement that the course that has been followed for the last eight years has not produced prosperity in this country, an acknowledgement that Canada needed a change in its current fiscal and monetary course. That was one path.
The other path was the path of stubbornness, the path of pig-headedness, the path that said: "We shall never surrender before our blind ideological beliefs; we shall never admit we were wrong; and we would rather go down and disappear politically off the face of Canada rather than admit that we have led Canada to a course of ruin and destruction economically".
The minister chose the latter course. He is like the doctor who tired of fighting the disease that laid his patients low in the hospital ward, turned away from fighting the disease and began to kill off the patients. He is the Minister of Finance who refused to declare war on unemployment but instead declared war on the unemployed. He is the Minister of Finance who refused to declare war on poverty but instead attacks those who are poorest among us. Because, Madam Speaker, when you wipe away and swish away all the smoke, get rid of all the mirrors in this budget document, and it is a budget, right from its initial inception it is deceptive. It is not a mini-statement. It is not an economic statement. It is a full budget.
What do we have? We have over three fiscal years projected by this Minister of Finance $8 billion-count them-in the words of Joey Smallwood, not $1, not $2, not $5, not $7, but $8 billion dollars in cuts, and over the same corresponding period of time we have less than $2.2 billion in stimulation.
Government Orders
You do not have to be a genius to know that if you cut $8 billion and you only spend $2 billion in the grip of a recession, you are taking away, you are hauling out, you are draining away, you are pumping from the body politic, the body economic structure of this country, $6 billion at a time when the nation is in the grip of a recession.
That is bad enough, but who are those billions being taken from? Which Canadians are going to pay? Are the large, multinational Canadian corporations, who the Auditor General just said last week are sheltering their profits in the Bahamas in offshore companies, going to pay? The Auditor General told this Minister of Finance that large, Canadian corporations are hiding their profits in the Bahamas. They are using loopholes to avoid taxes on billions. Does the Minister of Finance collect the few billions he raises or the cuts from those people? No, there is not a measure in this budget to take $1 in tax out of the pockets of those who are experts in avoiding paying their taxes.
Does this budget document take one dollar or one dime out of the richest 1 per cent or 2 per cent that avoid paying tax? Not a single dime.
Who does it take money from? We look to the minister's own budget statement, page 15, Economic and Fiscal Statement. The minister announced in a grand fashion that the wages of members of Parliament will be frozen, he says with a stiff upper lip. We have all had our wages frozen. Ministers of the Crown have had their wages frozen. Oh, what good soldiers are we in the face of a recession. We have frozen our wages. Are we not brave?
However, what have we done to the unemployed? We have taken $2.5 billion out of the pockets of the unemployed. We have not frozen the wages of the unemployed. We have not told them they would not get a raise. We have not treated the unemployed the way we have treated members of Parliament, frozen their wages. We have cut their wages. We have said that they will go from 60 per cent to 57 per cent of their former salaries.
What more cowardly measure ever in the history of this place has been introduced by a Minister of Finance? A minister would say it is simply good enough to freeze the salaries of members of Parliament but appropriate to cut the salaries of those who have least among us.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
This budget lacks not only imagination, lacks not only an acknowledgement of reality, but it lacks compassion. It is the work of a tired government, an old government, a government that knows not where to go and not where to turn.
The unemployed the minister has chosen to attack, those who live in poverty that the minister has chosen to attack, who are they? They are the urban poor whose life is a job ghetto, bounced around from one low-paying job to another. They are the rural poor whose lives have been the cycle of seasonal employment, whose livelihood depends upon the forestry if it is healthy, the mining sector if it is functioning, the fishery if there are fish, and the agricultural sector if our farmers can sell around the world. Those are the people who are targeted.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Families with children.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Families with children. Those are the people who are targeted to be bounced off the unemployment insurance program.
Do not buy for one second this line by the minister that only bad people who get themselves fired are going to be hurt and only those lazy people who quit these good paying jobs that are out there are going to be hurt and if anybody who is decent, fair or honest finds they have been treated badly we will have an appeal process and we will look after them. Nobody is going to be hurt.
How can the minister say that when next year alone he has already budgeted nearly $1 billion in cuts. That money has to be found. The year after another $1.5 billion in cuts. Where are these people going to go? Are they going to disappear or vaporize off the face of the earth? Are they going to be beamed up off the planet by the starship Enterprise, never to be seen or heard from again? No, they are going to go down to the local welfare office.
The Government of Canada by sleight of hand has transferred $2.5 billion worth of the cost out of the federal coffers and on to the backs of hard-pressed provincial governments.
Which governments will bear the largest burden? Those governments whose economy is in the greatest crisis, the Government of Newfoundland, the Government of Saskatchewan, the Government of Manitoba, and, yes, the Government of Ontario. Those are the governments that will have the burden of bearing this transfer of poverty out of federal coffers to provincial coffers.
I want to say to my friend, the Minister of Finance, that I understand this government is tired. I understand he is tired. I understand that perhaps this is the best that can be squeezed out of the collective brain power of that tired troop across the way.
However, I know there remains just a shred of integrity and dignity and a modicum of courage on the benches opposite. I know my friend, the Minister of Finance, and this is the best he can do with the crowd he sits with. I know he will do the honourable thing and put this package to the people of Canada in a national referendum called an election. Let the people of Canada say yes or no to this economic prescription for a country that is in crisis.

speakeroldname: Mr. Charles A. Langlois (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Industry, Science and Technology):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I could hardly wait to take part this morning in the debate on the economic statement made by the hon. Minister of Finance in this House yesterday.
I would say without hesitation that the statement by the hon. Minister of Finance is really a big step toward economic recovery in Canada.
Yesterday, the Minister of Finance suggested two options to the Canadian people. The first one favours an economic recovery based on the participation of the private sector and strongly supported by various interventions aimed at stimulating investment and job creation. The second one clearly indicates this government's commitment to the continued reduction of government spending.
That is a clear message which shows Canadians the objectives that our government has been pursuing from the start. I think it is important to refer to the comments made by the Minister of Finance in the introduction to the economic statement tabled in the House yesterday. I will quote directly from the statement made by the Minister yesterday.
December 3, 1992

Our economic policy is to build confidence, enhance growth, create jobs, and help Canadians adjust to this period of transition and take advantage of new opportunities.
All of our efforts have been directed at investing in growth through sound monetary and fiscal policies, the opening up of markets, streamlining government, building the skills of Canadians, and encouraging private sector enterprise and initiative as the basis for economic progress.
That is why the series of measures announced in the economic and fiscal statement, particularly with regards to small businesses, represent one aspect, one of the major elements that will contribute to our reaching our objectives. That is why I will talk during the next few minutes, about these important measures proposed in the economic and fiscal statement for Canadian small businesses.
I would like to remind you that small businesses play a major role in the Canadian economy at two fundamental levels, employment and investment.
Businesses with 50 employees or fewer represent 95 per cent of all Canadian businesses and account for about 45 per cent of private sector employment. During the last few years, they have been responsible for most of the job creation, that is more than 2 million new jobs. Furthermore, small businesses account for nearly half of the private sector investments during the same period.
I would also like to stress the fact that the current fiscal regime for small businesses recognizes the importance of that sector's contribution to the Canadian economy.
Madam Speaker, here are a few examples illustrating this point. First of all Canadian small businesses enjoy a special deduction bringing down their federal income tax rate from 28.8 to 12.8 per cent. In the United States small businesses pay much higher taxes, with federal rales ranging from 15 to 39 per cent for the same income bracket.
Second, the lifetime capital gains exemption provides an incentive for individuals to invest in small businesses. Capital gains resulting from the disposition of qualified small business shares are eligible for a $500,000 exemption. In addition, only 75 per cent of capital gains over and above the exemption are subject to income tax. Also, small businesses qualify for the most generous incentives
Government Orders
for research and development in all of the G-7 countries.
On the other hand, small businesses are presently subject to strong financial and competitive pressures, and these are largely due to the need for federal and provincial governments to better co-ordinate their efforts whether when dealing with the GST or other taxes, with public spending or with establishing regulations. In other words, despite the benefits of the present taxation system, several small businesses consider that, overall, the tax and regulatory context south of the border is more inviting.
To help change and improve that situation yesterday's economic statement has put in place, or rather suggests to put in place, the components of a program to help the small business sector develop and create yet more jobs. I would like to list a few of these components, Madam Speaker.
The statement provides that most small businesses increasing employment next year will be able to do so with no increase in unemployment insurance premiums. Any new business whose employer share of UI premiums was less than $60,000 in 1992 will be eligible for a benefit under this program.
This means that for most small businesses, UI premium costs will be capped at their 1992 level. Similarly, most new businesses starting up in 1993 will pay no UI premiums in that year. This assistance will reduce the cost of additional employees by up to $1,600 each.
We also want to encourage investment. As an incentive for small businesses to accelerate investment spending, a 10 per cent investment tax credit for small business will apply, for one year, to investments in machinery and equipment for small businesses engaged in manufacturing, construction, farming, fishing, mining, oil and gas and long-haul transportation. These are very active sectors of our economy, Madam Speaker, with a very substantial potential for expansion and job creation. The credit will apply to investments made before 1994.
The proposed measures will also help small businesses obtain the financing they need. The rules for investments in small business by RRSPs and Labour-Sponsored Venture Capital funds will be simplified and expanded.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
For instance, individuals will be permitted to hold unrestricted amounts of qualifying small business investments in their RRSPs, while preferred shares will be added to the list of eligible investments for LSVCCs. That is very important.
Furthermore, the loan limit allowed under the Small Businesses Loans Act will be raised from $50,000 to $250,000.
The Small Business Financing Program will be extended to the end of 1994. This will permit small businesses to refinance loans at interest rates below normal commercial market rates.
This series of measures should encourage Canada's small businesses to make the investments they have been planning for some time and thus create new jobs.
Finally, I would like to mention that part of the minister's economic statement which deals with major investments in the transportation sector.
I am very pleased to see the economic statement mentions the possibility of entering into agreements with the provinces, including my own province of Quebec, so that we can start a number of major highway projects in Quebec and bring them to completion especially in my own riding where road inprovements are badly needed. We know some sections of Flighway 138 east of Havre-Saint-Pierre are not yet finished, and I am pleased to see the economic statement addresses this problem. The Government of Quebec will now be able to sign an agreement with our government to finance the completion of these projects.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I think we seldom take the time, here in the House, to consider what was said in the past.
In March this year when I spoke in the debate on the budget I mentioned the lack of concrete measures to improve the economy and help Canadians who were suffering as a result of Tory policies.
From what we have heard about the new budget, I was right. Once again their financial policies are doing nothing to improve the economy of this country. The government keeps harping on global economic restructuring and the international recession. I agree that these
issues are important, but I certainly do not agree with their approach to all the problems facing our economy.
The government prefers to wait and see what will happen. The Minister of Finance himself said that he was waiting to see what the Americans would do after the U.S. election before doing anything at all.
They had another alternative. They could at least have tried to reduce the serious unemployment problem in this country. They could have tried to find jobs for those who have none. They could have done something for Canadians living below the poverty line.
But let us be fair. The government is making some progress. But why is it only because of the Liberal policies they adopted? During the budget debate last March we noticed that the government decided to adopt a Liberal proposal for using RRSPs for the first-time purchase of a home. Once again the government borrows concepts from the Liberals to boost the economy.

The government's attitude has had a devastating impact in my riding of Restigouche-Chaleur. The government's economic policies have wreaked havoc in the forestry sector in my riding, leading to 300 lay-offs at the Atholville Pulp Mill, 500 lay-offs at the Dalhousie mill and a number of other related lay-offs throughout the riding. Nevertheless the government stubbornly maintains many of its disastrous policies.
We cannot forget the companies that have laid off people. We cannot forget these individuals who are laid off and presently without work.
We have heard a lot yesterday and today about unemployment. In my riding the level is at 16 per cent. This figure is unacceptable.
It does not include those individuals who have given up looking for work.
Small businesses in the riding are suffering. The federal government expects them to carry the economic recovery yet it continues to tax them to death. All the while the large multinational corporations continue to operate paying little or no taxes.
This government's unwillingness to stand up to multinationals is clearly outlined in last week's Auditor General's report and Bill C-91 which is presently being studied by a committee. Small business, in my mind, is the engine of today's economy and it is going to need a
December 3, 1992

boost. I must in all fairness say to the minister some of the announcements yesterday were a step in the right direction, a very small step.
The government keeps telling us of the importance of education and the need to have a well-educated workforce to compete in the world's economy. Meanwhile the government is mercilessly slashing education and training budgets. Since 1986 it has continually reduced its contributions to post-secondary education. The maximum level for the Canada Student Loans Program has not risen since 1984.
The government has put a tax, the GST, on books and other learning resources. It has finally implemented cuts to the summer employment experience program, therefore diminishing students' abilities to support themselves through their educational careers.
Spending on education, research and development are investments in the future of our country. We must get back on the right track.
With regard to student loans, collection agencies are presently hounding students who are unemployed. They are hounding their families who are unemployed. This has to stop. I heard earlier one of the members from the opposite side was looking for a suggestion. I suggest the minister review the Canada Student Loans Program completely with a view to searching out those who are unemployed who cannot make their payments. Maybe they could work for the state, or a municipality to repay their debts. When we look at this idea, we see that criminals are sometimes better treated than our students. It is about time government start looking at that aspect.

People in my riding met to organize conferences on the economy. The Nepisiguit economic conference submitted its report nearly a year ago. A second conference, the Restigouche economic conference, is now under way in another part, of my riding. These two conferences bring together community people who care about the situation in their region. The purpose of this regional strategic analysis is to take charge of the region's economy in order to make it better. These groups realize
Government Orders
the region's problems but are also ready to find solutions.
Another committee was formed to consider the possibility of reopening the Atholville Pulp Mill and to look at the problems of the forestry industry in general. Other groups, like the Restigouche and Chaleur industrial commission, the business men and women of St. Quentin, the CDCs of Kedgwick, Dalhousie and Campbellton, the chamber of commerce in Beresford, are also working to solve some of the region's problems. They are trying to find innovative solutions to improve the economy and promote development.
The lack of leadership from the federal government makes more work for these committees, but their power is limited. The government must show leadership and initiative to help them. For this, the government should immediately start investing in the present infrastructure of Restigouche-Chaleur.
The ports of Belledune and Dalhousie are still looking for a strategic plan. Since the federal government still does not promote them a plan is necessary.

The ports of Belledune and Dalhousie in my riding have to be developed. There is a lot of potential.

Dredging is needed for the docks in the communities of Pointe-Verte and Petit-Rocher.

The wharf at New Mills has to be expanded for our fishermen. Emphasis has to be put on tourism, not only in my riding but right across Canada. The tourism potential of Restigouche-Chaleur must be assisted and expanded. We have a good base to start with but it takes a little bit of help from the federal government.
We have a network of outdoor centres in Restigouche-West. We have museums, we have the Park Sugarloaf. We have the Chaleur Phantom, Recreaplex, Chaleur Park, and the Eel River Bar development that is in the works. There are parks in the Jacquet River area and we have a major new park that has just been developed-

December 3, 1992
Government Orders

-Atlas Park. It is very important to have more money to improve tourism facilities in our riding.

There are other projects under way such as la plage de Beresford, un terrain de golf. It is very important the message gets out that tourism and small business are probably the best answers to some of our problems. We have to start making sure they are part of the solution.
I must also say we have to look at the transportation system. I am happy to say the minister looked at the transportation system somewhat in his proposals yesterday. I also believe there has to be more emphasis put on roads, airports and ports. I hope some of the announcements that were made yesterday with regard to roads, airports and ports are going to apply to all ridings in Canada and not just a select few.
The time has come for governments at all levels to enter into a new partnership. The municipalities, the provinces and the federal government must begin to priorize their plans and make decisions on this basis.
In wrapping up, I would like to say Canadians need a government with initiative. They need a government willing to provide leadership and get Canada working again. In short, I believe we need a new government.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to focus on just a couple of issues in the economic statement of yesterday.
I listened to the various comments yesterday both in the House and in the media about the measures announced with regard to unemployment insurance benefit rates. A lot of simplistic phrases were thrown out that are totally incorrect. One was that we are fighting the deficit on the backs of the unemployed.
I would like to be specific on that and I hope the hon. member will listen rather than speaking from the seat of his pants over there.
Let me just go through the details. The unemployment insurance benefit rate is being reduced from 60 per cent of previous earnings up to the maximum insurable earnings to 57 per cent for new claims starting April 1, 1993. Current beneficiaries are all grandfathered. The
net result of the benefit rate reduction from 60 per cent to 57 per cent, which so many are playing upon, is a freeze in unemployment insurance benefits in keeping with the government's restraint across all policy sectors. It will counteract the growth in earnings that would otherwise cause average benefits to increase. How in the world can one say if you move from 60 per cent to 57 per cent that it is not a cut? Well, we have to remember that the 57 per cent is based on a higher number. When you base it on a higher industrial base rate number, the net effect of the change is no change and it continues at a flat or freeze position.
I wish hon. members opposite would do justice to what is exactly happening here. The net effect of this change is to freeze the benefits as opposed to reducing the benefits. That is the first point I would like to make. We heard a lot of comments from the media last night and even some from the opposition here in the House that it is totally unfair to disentitle voluntary quitters.
Let us look at the facts. The effective date of the proclamation of the necessary amendments to the Unemployment Insurance Act for persons who voluntarily leave their jobs without just cause or lose their jobs through their own misconduct will no longer be eligible for unemployment insurance benefits. The measure is to be permanent.
Let us put this in context. Those persons are already subject to administrative penalties which delay the start of benefits from seven to twelve weeks and are paid benefits at a lower rate of 50 per cent. That is already happening. What the economic statement adds is that those who leave their jobs without just cause will lose their benefits.
Let us look at just cause. What does just cause include? It includes sexual or other harassment. That is the first one. The second is obligation to accompany a spouse or dependent child to another residence; third-
Madam Speaker, these people continue to speak over there. They refuse to listen. Let us get the facts on the table. The first just cause was sexual or other harassment. No one will be penalized if that is the reason they must leave; second, obligation to accompany a spouse or dependent child to another residence; third, discrimination on a prohibited ground of discrimination as contained in the Canadian Human Rights Act; fourth,
December 3, 1992

working conditions that constitute a danger to health; and fifth, an obligation to care for a child.
It is totally false to say that anyone is going to be cut off benefits because of those reasons. We must remember there is an adjudication process and an appeal process to deal with that should someone be unfairly let go or fired.
Madam Speaker, let us look at the facts first. Once we have the facts then let us start looking at whether the process will work and will the process work fairly. That is the intent of this.
Let us go on to another part of the statement. To encourage small business to expand and to hire new employees, the government will pay any increase in the unemployment insurance premiums in 1993 over 1992 up to a maximum of $30,000 per firm. In effect, for most small businesses, UI premium costs will be capped at their 1992 levels. In fact most start-up businesses will have a UI premium holiday for 1993.
Any incorporated or unincorporated business whose employer share of UI premiums in 1992 was less than $60,000 will be eligible for a benefit under the program. For those businesses which had between zero and $30,000 of UI employer premiums, the maximum will be $30,000. For those which pay between $30,000 and $60,000, the maximum benefit will be phased down on a dollar for dollar basis.
This is very good news for our small business sector which we know creates the vast majority of jobs in Canada. This will help them greatly because the net effect upon a small business will be to reduce their hiring costs for an additional worker up to about $1,600 per additional new worker.
Other actions for small business will include a 10 per cent small business investment tax credit for machinery and equipment purchases. Rules on investments in small businesses by RRSPs and other funds will be simplified and investment options expanded. Programs that provide financial assistance are being expanded or extended, all to help small businesses hire more people as we begin to move to a higher growth rate than what we have seen in the last five quarters. All of this is very encouraging and it is important that we get the facts on the table.
Government Orders
There are some very tough measures that were announced in the economic statement. One of them is a freeze on public servants and their salaries. I want to pay tribute to the civil servants who work in my riding. We have several offices in my riding, immigration, employment, retraining, pension, Revenue Canada and customs offices. I can say without any equivocation for myself and for my staff that we have received excellent service from the vast majority of those public servants.
Their task is not simple; they carry out programs where they have no say about the content on most occasions. Sometimes they know the programs could even be improved, but they have to administer them as they are given to them. They do that for people who are often very angry, very frustrated, do not know what is going on and are very impatient.
I want to commend the vast majority of public servants right across Canada, and particularly in my riding, for their professionalism and the way in which they carry out their tasks.
I am also disappointed that in this budget-or this economic statement, I am sorry-that the deficit is not going to be lower than it is. Here we are, after eight budgets, two economic statements at least and every single one has cut spending. When we began in 1984-85 we started to cut spending. Every single budget from 1985 on has cut spending.
When we started in 1984 the annual deficit was in the $38.3 billion to $38.5 billion range; now we are coming down to $34.4. We have only reduced it by about $4 billion. To me, that is one of the tremendous disappointments that this statement brings to us as Canadians and members in this House. After eight years of cutting we still have only made $4 billion worth of progress.
Let us remember why we are not making much progress. We were making a lot of progress prior to the recession and it looked very encouraging, but we did not go up in that deficit because of renewed spending. We continued to cut spending. The reason it went up is because of reduced revenues. That is totally contrary and totally different than what happened in the early eighties when the annual deficit continued to rise, due both to reduced revenue but also in large measure to increased spending. We have to keep that in mind.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
I am also disappointed that we did not cut off all advocacy groups. We have reduced them in this statement 10 per cent now and 10 per cent next year. I think most of those should have been cut to zero. I know that in some cases people will say we discriminate. Well, we discriminate now. The National Action Committee is only being cut 10 per cent and 10 per cent, yet REAL Women get zero. So we are discriminating right now. I think all advocacy groups should get zero and that is our target except for organizations such as the CNIB or Red Cross which we should continue to fund.
In conclusion I am pleased that at least we are going to take some action on eliminating interprovincial trade barriers. Those have to go because it will create jobs that will eliminate much of the lack of competitiveness we now have in comparison to the rest of the world and that will help Canada both to create jobs and to be more competitive.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, yesterday was one of the saddest days that I have witnessed in this House of Commons. It was a sad day because I think there were still some Canadians who looked to this government and the mini budget to help ease the terrible toll that Tory government policies have brought to our country.
I believe there were some people out there who clung to the thought that the government, even a Tory government, would see the devastation and see the error of their ways, realize that things just are not right, realize the human suffering that their policies have caused, and act with compassion. Some look to the government for, at the very least, hope, plain and simple hope. Sadly, yesterday that hope was finally extinguished.
Yesterday this government admitted it could do nothing to correct the ills of its own policies and the policies of the Liberals before it. Yesterday in this Chamber the finance minister and the minister of trade all but admitted that they were impotent, impotent to do anything in the face of world market forces, unable to create any Canadian solutions to our problems, unable to help ordinary Canadians.
What does it mean to be a Canadian? For the government it seems to mean that it rolls over and plays dead in the heat of the market forces' cauldron.
Can you imagine, Madam Speaker, the Japanese, the Germans or the Americans, who also rely on trade, standing before the people and saying: "We cannot do anything to help; we have to wait for other countries to get better, then we will too." Can we imagine that happening? That is exactly what we heard in this Chamber last night. Unfortunately that is not where yesterday's story ends. The story gets even worse.
Yesterday we also received another lesson in the priorities of the government. It is bad enough that the government usually sticks to increasing the burden carried by average working people, the ordinary Canadians who work the hardest and pay the most. Yesterday the government went a step further. It managed to increase the burden of the unemployed. The government has revictimized those unable to work or who cannot find work. It managed to kick someone who was already down.
At this difficult time when the country has seen record unemployment thanks to the government's policies-a slavish pursuit of deficit reduction, a slavish pursuit of opening up Canada, selling it to the lowest bidder and shipping our jobs away-instead of choosing to help the unemployed the government has cut UI benefits and limited the numbers eligible.
Now when a man quits work because of appalling conditions, unreasonable demands, concerns about health and safety, he could potentially no longer receive UI benefits. When a woman quits work because she is sexually harassed she could potentially no longer receive UI benefits. At the very least there could be a brand new bureaucracy at UIC, a star chamber deciding who should receive UI and who should not.
I listened carefully to the previous speaker. What he does not understand is that before yesterday's announcement a woman who was sexually harassed on the job would at least know if she quit her job she would serve the penalization period for so-called voluntarily quitting and then be eligible for UI benefits. Now she will no longer be able to do this. This will result in women staying in situations where they are being sexually harassed. For some women this will mean if they leave they will not get benefits, not be able to feed their children and will have to turn to the welfare roll.
December 3, 1992

The government seems to forget that all working people pay into the UIC. It is not a charity. Is it not ironic that at the very time the government is again attacking the Public Service it now seems to be creating a new bureaucracy at UIC to judge who it deems to be deserving and undeserving recipients?
The government insists it is making tough decisions to help all Canadians. Let us look at how successful its policies have been. On deficit reduction in only nine months it appears the projections of the finance minister were off by a mere $11.9 billion. On free trade deals
500,000	jobs have been lost, mostly in the manufacturing sector, but the trade minister boasts they have been replaced with service jobs at fast food restaurants.
The only other area where there has been a real job growth is for volunteers in the increasing food banks across the country. As for retraining for the new demand for the global economy, the government is taking $300 million from existing UI funds for training. No new funds, no new strategy.
This is not a government making the tough decisions for the betterment of Canada. This is not a government adapting to changes in a restructured global economy. This is a government which keeps tripping over its own ideology and unfortunately it keeps landing with a thud on average Canadians.
This is a government not even following its own advice. It is not reducing the deficit. It is not retraining and adapting. Only now is the government talking about the needs of a service economy, the needs of R and D. That advice was given to the government years ago by the Economic Council which it has also axed.
The government's obsession is with its fight against inflation, its tight monetary policy. The publication Canadian Business Economics concludes that easing the anti-inflation fight would have saved jobs and led to a dramatic improvement in the deficit and trade. The saddest part of the Conservative policies is that they do not even make economic sense.
Canadians realize that politics is often an adversarial process, but Canadians also realize there is a time to put aside dogmatism, a time to put aside political ideology. Canadians realize there is a time when the government
Government Orders
must do what is right to help its people regardless of its political ideology.
Unfortunately government members who sit across from me are the only Canadians who do not seem to realize that very simple message. Instead the government insists on pursuing the same policies which over eight years have been successful only in increasing the deficit and increasing the number of unemployed Canadians.
It is not good enough to stand here and criticize. That is what the Liberals do. They criticize. They do not offer solutions. They hold their breath hoping to be the next government. It is the responsibility of opposition parties to present alternatives. The New Democrats have done so.
Last night my colleague from Essex-Windsor spoke eloquently and passionately on this very matter. He spoke of alternatives that would take into consideration the plight of 1.5 million unemployed Canadians. He spoke of the choices the government had.
To quote from the document which the finance minister released yesterday: "The essence of governing is choosing. There are choices to be made and we are prepared to make them in the best interest of Canadians".
New Democrats would not have chosen to spend, as did the government, $4.5 billion on military helicopters before they launched a serious campaign to rebuild Canada's infrastructure and provide necessary jobs. The best social policy is a full employment policy.
New Democrats would not have chosen, as did the government, to allow tax avoidance for wealthy individuals and profitable corporations before they helped retrain Canadians to adapt to the changes in this world.
New Democrats would not have allowed, as the government has, wealthy individuals to hide their fortunes in private trust loopholes while ordinary Canadians pay more than their full share of taxes and then some.
Unlike this government, New Democrats would have ended the capital gains tax exemption rather than forcing sexually harassed women to stay at a job for fear of not receiving UI benefits.
Unlike this government, we would have eliminated the business entertainment and meal subsidies and instead helped get hungry children away from dependency on

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
food banks and given them some real hope for the future.
New Democrats would not be trying to extend multinational drug company patents, extensions which even the government itself admits are going to cost provincial health care and average Canadians hundreds of millions of dollars. Unlike this government, New Democrats would not be extending these patents instead of fulfilling promises to provide child care so we can maximize the potential of our human resources.
When all the world's armies are downsizing, New Democrats would not allow, as the government has, our basis in the defence budget to bloat instead of continuing and increasing green initiatives that would provide jobs and are so important to our future.
New Democrats would not have panicked and signed an ill conceived and sweeping document like the trade deal with the U.S. or NAFTA which will again make us drawers of water and hewers of wood.
There were choices. There were new ideas. Sadly only the Conservatives stick dogmatically to trickle down economic theories that have failed everywhere else in the world.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I too rise with muted thoughts on the speech of the Minister of Finance yesterday.
I am going to say a couple of things in the brief time here that have caused me concern. Then in the last few minutes of this 10-minute contribution I do have two very specific proposals on policy that I think obviously cannot be implemented in this economic document but certainly may be considered hopefully before the minister brings in presumably another budget in the spring.
In a very general way, with all the facts and figures and all the tables and charts ,1 think the minister would agree with me that unless there is confidence in the community outside this hall from coast to coast, unless there are very specific tax policies with stimulation, we are not going to get the recovery that we all desire and want so much for the Canadians we serve. The minister wants that as much as any speaker in this House.
In the few minutes I have I want to express in a general way my disappointment. I appreciate the parameters were very limited for manoeuvring by the minister. It was either fish or cut bait or try to pump it up or else chop more. As other speakers have said, I do not really see where he could chop much more, although I will have a few proposals there. Certainly tax increases were absolutely verboten as far as the public was concerned.
However, without getting into analysis of the speech yesterday, the smoke and mirrors, the Alice in Wonderland aspect of this whole document is right in the speech which appears in Hansard. At page 12 of the statement, after talking about some of the measures that he announced to get some money to try to get the deficit down, which includes the salary freeze, he stated:
The actions I have announced today will bring the estimated deficit
down to $34.4 billion this year and $32.6 billion next year.
When I heard that last night I thought of Alice in Wonderland and doublespeak. We knew before last night that the deficit was supposed to be 27 point something billion. He said that with a smile last night.
I do not know if the opposition will ask the question today in Question Period, but I certainly hope the question is answered. If the minister had not included these measures that are enumerated on page 12 of his printed speech, what was to be the estimate for the deficit? If, in the minister's words, he was just bringing it down to $34.4 billion and next year it is going to be $32.6 billion, what was the amount of the deficit? That as I say, illustrates the smoke and mirrors and the doublespeak in so much of this document that I do not have the time to analyse fully.
The other part which is a little more sensitive is the question of confidence. I know the minister well. As I say, it is a little unfortunate in terms of the confidence of Canadians out there who have either lost their jobs or are concerned about their jobs. I will not get into the speech by the member for Humber-St. Barbe-Baie Verte. He mentioned in effect that we have frozen our salaries, but we have not frozen the payout to the unemployed who are actually going to have a 3 per cent cut from 60 per cent to 57 per cent. One could really make a whole speech on that point.
December 3, 1992

There is just something wrong. One of the top public servants of the land led the bureaucracy in the federal Public Service and brought in PS 2000. He was very involved in constitutional discussions and is now the president of the CNR. I am referring to Mr. Paul Tellier. In his very first meeting with management he informs them that they have problems on the railway and 10,000 employees are going to have to go.
This is a man who has given good public service to Canada. Undoubtedly he has certain pension qualifications, yet he is hand-picked without any railway experience to go into an area that we all know has serious problems. We worry about the rationalization of the air, but I think anyone involved in transportation knows that the rationalization of the rail is going to confront us very seriously within the next five years. A man with a very solid pay has been put into position. He has made contributions and has done his work for Canada. He has been put into that area, hand-picked by the Prime Minister to run the CN with no experience. He told them that 10,000 of them were going to lose their jobs.
That is something that everyone in the barber shops and the garages can understand. Just what is going on when a top public servant comes around and in his first meeting says: "Hey, I have been looked after. I have a new job and one of my jobs is to tell you that you are going to be out of a job?"
My friend across the way is the second most powerful political person on the federal scene and he disappointed me. He could have stopped the transfer of the immigration data processing office to Vegreville.
He knows that that type of move was complained about when he was in opposition when it was done for such rank political purposes. Again it is the type of thing that in terms of John and Jane Q. Public out there it just causes real concern about what can be believed about these people.
Those members complained about certain things when they were in opposition. Then they get in power and, with those two things, not to mention Bill C-91, they do it just as badly as the Liberal government did it.
We will have a chance to talk about Bill C-91 next week after another allocation of time order so that we can get on with the report stage and the third reading. It
Government Orders
does not help Canadians. It may help the multinationals, but I thought this government had learned after the referendum that it is not good enough to have business on your side. The people have to be on your side. The real concern out there has been that this government has lost touch with the people.
In terms of the negatives of this budget there is the business of the immigration centre in Vegreville and Paul Tellier running the railway as sort of a hobby after he has been a professional public servant. He was hand-picked by the Prime Minister to run CN when we know all railways run into serious trouble. This is something that shakes the very confidence of Canadians.
Frankly, another budget in the spring is not even going to do enough to help restore the basic confidence of Canadians who see these things. They do not have to be economic wizards to know that there is something wrong when they are unemployed.
Talk to the fishermen, both the unemployed and those who are going to be unemployed. Talk to the airline workers who wonder about their jobs. Talk to people in areas in my part of the country where there is going be more base closures and more job losses. They are concerned for their families.
However, they pick up the papers and see someone who has been well looked after getting another premium job in the railways. Then they see the minister putting the immigration office in Vegreville. If the survey shows that this is an economic way to have immigration processing far distant from where the real immigration cases are, why then put it there instead of in some other area where there is loss of employment and futures. People understand that.
That is why the confidence of the people is shaken. I really thought that the vote we had on October 26 would have told some of the leaders of the land how upset people were, but I do not think it did.
That is the negative side that I have mentioned. There is so much more on the negative side I could say but I really do not want to go too far in order to conform to the time limit which is very short.
The minister has asked for positive and concrete proposals to improve the economy. As an Independent Conservative member of the House, I do not have the resources and staff to produce detailed studies. Howev-

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
er, after several years in politics and with eyes and ears open to the community and input from voters I have a couple of suggestions which in the future will go a long way in helping the economy.
The first is to encourage small and new business. I know the minister intends to do that through tax credits. The trouble with tax credits is that they are no good unless the business is making money. New businesses are not making money and most small businesses are not making money today.
I agree small businesses are the major creators of jobs. In the critical growth stages most of them benefit very little, if at all, from tax credits on tax deductible expense allowances. They need stable, long-term funding at low interest rates rather than the roller-coaster pattern in rates and availability offered by the government, the Bank of Canada and paranoid bankers.
I propose that small businesses be permitted to borrow funds for terms of 10 years or more at fixed rates on the basis that interest is not a tax deductible expense for the borrower and not a taxable income for the lender.
Some of the proposals could be massaged but in effect this means small businesses when they first open will most likely not have any taxable income for a few years and more than likely will show losses. There should not be that much impact.
Such loans should be included as eligible with limits from the Small Businesses Loans Act. Perhaps the maximum of such non tax deductible loans to any business should be limited to perhaps $5 million. It may also be necessary to permit the pooling of such loans where they can be sold through security dealers. This will create an ample supply of funds at significantly lower rates than presently available with positive long-term tax consequences.
In conclusion my second proposal is somewhat the same thing but even shorter. It is similar but is directed to the home market and housing industry. It is designed to make quality housing more affordable. It will increase the value of existing homes and thus people's net worth. It helps to get equity back into the system. This is what we need. It will increase the value of existing homes-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
