subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, thank you for giving me a few moments to speak as have my other colleagues. Of course, I recognize the good faith and good will of all hon. members who in turn share their varying perceptions of a reality on which everyone agrees. But I see that these very diverse solutions lack common vision and realism. Of course that is the reason for political options, partisanship and divisions among parliamentarians and managers.
Madam Speaker, I would therefore tell you that in my mind this economic statement that the hon. Minister of Finance submitted in the Elouse is not a budget in itself. It is very important not to consider it or perceive it as a budget. It follows on a budget that was presented more than six months ago in February. Given the mishaps along the way, the continuing recession, the high interest rates, inflation which was high then too, all these factors affected the budget which needs to be reviewed.
With this in mind the hon. minister and our government decided by common agreement to make a course correction. So you must not think that this is a new budget that would cut or eliminate departments. We will deal with that in a future budget. The idea was to seize the opportunity of the present circumstances, some terrible and some exceptional, in order not only to correct some of the occasional errors but also to modify our course according to some new positive elements that were emerging such as the inflation rate which has been brought under control and is now the lowest in all of the G-7 countries, and interest rates which were increasing constantly during the last two or three years and are now at one of the lowest levels ever.
Therefore it was timely and appropriate for the minister and for our government to take these measures in order to rectify the situation in a context of confidence because Canada enjoys an enviable reputation worldwide. We had to take advantage of the exceptional confidence we enjoy, of the low interest rate we now

have, of the lowered rate of inflation. We had to seize this opportunity seven months after presentation of the 1992 budget, to redress the situation.
What did we do? The statement by the Minister of Finance, has several objectives besides raising confidence and increasing participation. The first was to have the government set an example. We had to make cutbacks, as we did over the last eight years, hoping to control and eventually eliminate the deficit. I agree it did not happen so far but it is the recession and the benefits we must provide to our citizens, the protection we must give them, which have prevented us from pursuing the lowering of the deficit and eventually the debt.
Besides further spending cuts the economic statement provides for the continuation of the privatization policy, a policy which will end government spending on those operations which could obviously be run by the private sector. We have frozen salaries, from the prime minister, cabinet ministers and members of Parliament on down through the public service, Parliament and Crown corporations.
Then there is a second objective which I regard as most important. We will relieve the financial burden of the Canadian people. How? By restoring confidence. In that new and encouraging climate I referred to earlier families and consumers will have money to spend again. They will start consuming again, and if they spend more the industry will produce more and jobs will be created.
How will consumers and families benefit from that extra cash? May I remind you that the 1992 budget introduced and promised a tax rate cut. This measure will be pursued in 1993. In addition families, the head of the family, mother or father, will receive increased allowances in the form of benefits which means they will have more cash available to spend. In turn production and job creation will increase.
That is the second factor that ought to be taken into consideration and this change in course is a positive one. There is also the growth assistance initiative to promote the establishment of new businesses, thereby creating
Government Orders
new jobs. So research and development will be increased and support will be provided to small business.
This brings me to this last objective, which deals with jobs and investments in small and medium-sized businesses. Nearly 80 percent of businesses in Canada fall in that category. They are the bigger employer in our country. And these are the ones that have been-how can I say?-made vulnerable, weakened, shaken by the economic and financial situation to say nothing of the monetary situation. Interest rates made them vulnerable and, of course, inflation prevented consumers from spending because prices were on the rise. These businesses therefore produced less and less.
So small and medium-sized businesses' participation will be enhanced and these will be given a better start in the seventh month on this new course. Of course, assistance will be provided to them in various way. Allow me to look at this area in particular.
As I was saying, small businesses play a vital and major role in the Canadian economy. Did you know that between 1979 and 1990 they created more than two million new full time jobs? Those are fantastic investments in the private sector.
Canada's federal tax system for small businesses is one of the most favourable in the world. This is all the more reason to take advantage of the favourable situation that prevails right now with low interest rates, an inflation rate that is under control and the new confidence shown by the rest of the world toward Canada. It is important to take advantage of these circumstances so that small businesses which are the major employers in the country can again produce and hire people.
Let me give you an example of the tax incentives which we and they benefit from. Did you know that our tax rates are lower than those in the U.S.? Few people know that. For instance, Canadian small businesses which are incorporated can take advantage of a special deduction which lowers the federal income tax rate to 12.8 per cent, including the 3 per cent surtax; that is 12.8 per cent on the first $200,000 in revenue from an active business. What is that rate in the U.S.? Is it 10 per cent, 12 per cent, 14 per cent? No, Madam Speaker. In the United States the federal tax rates for small businesses range from 15 per cent to 39 per cent. You can see that there is

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
a favourable climate in Canada for renewed growth in the small business sector and the creation of new jobs.
Let me give you another example. Canadian small businesses which are incorporated are also entitled to the most generous R and D incentives not only compared to the U.S. but to all other G-7 countries. I should mention the refundable federal tax credit of 35 per cent which enables small businesses to receive funds directly without delay. Here is another example to illustrate those favourable conditions. There is a cumulative exemption, strictly for capital gains, which enables small businesses to invest again and again. This exemption can reach $500,000. This is another interesting incentive which should not be overlooked. This is precisely what awaits us tomorrow. Those privileges, those favourable conditions that we introduced for small businesses will continue to exist.
Do you want another example? Small businesses increasing employment will have no increase in unemployment insurance payments; some will even be exempted from paying the employer's premiums. These are important measures for small businesses that will enjoy a new boom.
I just wanted to tell you that small businesses will greatly develop as a result of the various measures taken to boost confidence, improve our monetary and interest rate policies and stimulate investments.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the banner headline in the minister's own backyard really put it aptly when it read: "Mulroney's Tories run out of gas". If you look at the opening paragraph in The Globe and Mail Jeffery Simpson once again put it very aptly when he said: "Finance Minister, Don Mazankowski's economic statement yesterday displayed all the hallmarks of a government running on an intellectual fuel tank marked empty".
Yesterday's economic statement or mini budget or whatever you want to call it by any measure was a depressing and pathetic response to the economic woes that challenge our country and Canadians. I say it is pathetic and depressing because I used two principal measures to look at how good this economic statement will be for Canada's economy.
There were two overriding options. The first was to change course and seek a new direction on a road that was clearly not working versus staying the course, business as usual, head in the sand and let us hope the economy will improve naturally. That was the first challenge.
The second challenge was whether to apply an approach that cut, restricted and withdrew from the economy or an approach prepared to stimulate a serious, comprehensive job creation program. For me and many of the constituents I have the honour of representing those were the two major challenges in terms of delineating an approach and providing a clear indicator of whether this government was serious about attacking those economic woes. Having opted to stay the course and restrict rather than expand the economy this Conservative government, in my opinion, has selected the wrong remedy. It has failed to inject confidence as a necessary variable to achieve any kind of recovery. It has shown it has been mismanaging because its projections have been wildly off the mark.
For instance this minister had projected a deficit figure $7 billion lower than it is. He then had to find another $8 billion in cuts which means he was $15 billion off. Not only has it done all those things but by selecting a "stay the course, don't worry, trust us" approach, it has demonstrated how disconnected this government has become from the reality that stares every average Canadian in the face every single day of the week. The government is clearly out of touch, out of tune and needs to be put out of its misery.
If we take the experiment to the south of us, through their election, it is startling how similar the two governments are. The Americans' incumbent president selected the same approach we witnessed yesterday in the economic statement. He said: "We are going to be getting out of this recession sooner or later. I do not want to interfere. I do not want to interject. I do not want to intervene". But the incumbent president was also a captive and a prisoner of a White House and he had no idea of what was going on in small town or big town America.
The Americans clearly selected a new course of economic management a few weeks ago despite the pros and cons on either side. The economy is clearly issue number one for Americans as it is for Canadians. One would have thought if the government did not learn the lesson in the referendum campaign about the disen-
December 3, 1992

chantment and disenfranchised perhaps it would have learned the lesson about some of the economic management decisions that have been made to the south of us, but that is not the case.
We can look at my own region of Toronto in the province of Ontario. Unemployment in Toronto is at 12.3 per cent which is higher than the national average. Last month alone 1,000 new families were added to the welfare rolls pushing the case-load up to over 108,000 families in Toronto who have to survive on welfare. That is a 14 per cent increase over last year. If we add the record numbers of people at food banks or under the poverty line the message is quite clear. In Ontario .5 million people are unemployed in what is and was one of the key economic engines or pistons of the national economy.
The government withdrew $300 million through UI cuts which removed $300 million of disposable income or $300 million from that economy. Eighty per cent of all lost manufacturing jobs are in Ontario. The construction and trades industries are as dead as door nails.
What did this government do for Toronto? What did it do for Ontario? What did it do to address the manufacturing drought, the economic malaise that has inflicted one of the major centres of economic activity? In some other regions of the country the Minister of Finance at least sugar-coated the bitter pill. In Toronto and Ontario there is precious little.
I know the minister from Brampton will probably say: "Look what we are doing with Pearson airport". They do not tell you when the construction jobs will come on stream. It will certainly not be this winter. Probably by the time they come on stream this government will be long gone. A lot of Canadians also say selling the most profitable airport in the country to private interests is not good business to start with.
I ask myself as a member of Parliament from the region of metropolitan Toronto, where the metro chairman identified close to $9 billion worth of projects that are on the shelf, if all three levels of government participated in a good many of the projects would that not stimulate and serve to inflict confidence in the economy? It would put some oxygen into the economy
Government Orders
instead of putting a lid on it as this government has opted to do.
Councillor Norm Gardner from metro asked and I quote: "Many ministers in Toronto have paid lip-service to metro's economic woes. I would really like to know where they think their bacon lies".
I would like to know as well. There was a time when metro was represented by a half dozen ministers who were active and progressive in defending the interests of Toronto. Right now Toronto is not even on the map of the government's agenda. Perhaps it has written it off.
What should constituents in my riding or in the ridings of my neighbouring members of Parliament and colleagues be told in terms of how yesterday's statement relates to the everyday challenges facing them? We have very little to tell them.
I simply wish to say the Minister of Finance said yesterday governing means choosing. Well it is the same for democracy. Democracy means choosing as well. Yesterday's statement made it a lot easier and certainly a lot more certain why this government cannot, will not, and should not ever earn the trust of Canadians again and certainly not in the next election.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, first of all I want to congratulate the Minister of Finance on his presentation yesterday to the House of Commons and to the country. I believe it was a well thought out, well presented, and a very good statement for the times we are in.
The hon. member who just sat down said in politics we have to make tough decisions and that is very true. You have to take a look at a country's position and financial situation. You have to look at the world economy, at the pressures on your dollar and on interest rates and so on when you put together a very important economic statement like my hon. friend did.
I have been sitting here listening to some of the speeches. I have read some of the speeches and I have watched some of them on television. To date, just like the last speaker, all we heard was moaning and groaning and complaining, and not one new idea that fits the economic times we are in. There has not been one new idea that would not add to the deficit or add to higher taxes. Not one.

Government Orders
Yet the opposition members are telling the Canadian public "put us in there and we will take care of everything". I do not think the Canadian public can be hoodwinked like that. I think the Canadian public wants to hear what they to have to offer. The airy-fairy suggestions that were presented and the hyperbole of the finance critic of the Liberal Party yesterday made it very obvious there was not a good idea given in the whole place. That includes my friend from Windsor who stood up and pontificated and said how terrible things are. We know how tough things are in Canada and that is exactly why the Minister of Finance brought in an economic statement that is going to do this country good.
I believe the biggest single expenditure now in the Government of Canada is the unemployment insurance. It is huge. Time after time people have said to us we have to get a handle on the unemployment insurance system. We have to make sure people who are collecting unemployment insurance are the right people collecting it the people who deserve it. We have been told that time after time. In these tough times when you are making huge expenditures like that you have to make sure the unemployment system is doing the proper thing.
I listened to the NDP members standing in this House saying there are going to be cuts in unemployment insurance when that is not factual. The Unemployment Insurance Program would be frozen at its current level.
One of the things they must understand is that next year the base rises. In order to freeze the level when the base rises we must decrease the benefits from 60 to 57 per cent to make it even. Therefore it is not a cut it is a freeze. It is a freeze and that should be understood by everyone. It is not a cut.
I listened to the New Democratic Party today. It talks about job creation. It says: "We need jobs in this country". Yet in the same breath it says to cancel the helicopter order.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Order, please. I would be delighted to recognize all hon. members one after the other but it is rather difficult when everyone speaks at the same time.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do not mind, they can heckle all they want. I am going to keep going anyway. Do not worry about them. I am not. I am not worried about them at all.
As I was saying, the New Democratic Party talks about jobs and job creation. Then it turns around and says to cancel the helicopter project. I was at a plant in Nova Scotia, I.M.P. to be exact. I toured the plant recently and visited with the workers and management. Do you know what? It is doing the outfitting for all these helicopters. This plant will do all the intricate wiring and put in all the instrumentation and so on. These are important jobs for Nova Scotia, very important jobs for Nova Scotia. As a matter of fact in my riding of Brampton I received two letters from companies that said to make sure the contract goes through because they provide this instrument or that instrument for the helicopter. The same is true in Mississauga. There are plants there that will provide supplies for those helicopters. Those are jobs in Canada. Those are important jobs.
If we cancel those kinds of contracts, like the NDP want us to do, those jobs will be lost. Let it then explain to its friends why that was cancelled and why their jobs were lost because of an action like that.
This is a very important contract as all our contracts are very important for the creation and preservation of jobs in our country.
I heard my hon. friend talk about the United States, about the President of the United States and the economy in the United States. It is too bad that the good numbers came out just a couple of weeks after the election but the economy is improving in the United States. That is a hopeful sign for us in Canada because we trade with it.
I want to remind this House that its deficit this year will probably be $400 billion per capita far higher than Canada's and it is growing. If the president-elect does what he says he is going to do we MU see a deficit that will be beyond belief in the United States. It has major problems with that.
Our Minister of Finance, our government, has come to grips with this. We are fighting the deficit. We have to fight the deficit. We cannot let it get out of control like the NDP and its friends in the Canadian Labour Congress suggest-the Canadian Labour Congress came out
December 3, 1992

the other day with two ideas, actually it was seven ideas but I just costed two of them. One was to extend unemployment insurance for an extra 26 weeks and the other was to cut the GST to 5 per cent. Those two things alone in one year would cost $10 billion. Did Bob White come up with an idea of where we could find $10 billion? No. It would either be added to the deficit or there would be increased taxes.
We cannot have it that way. We are not in a position to do those types of things. We cannot afford those types of things. The Canadian people understand that and I believe most sincerely that the Canadian people will support the Minister of Finance and this statement. They understand the tough row he has to hoe. They understand the situation that not only Canada is in but that countries around the world are in. They are all experiencing phenomenal problems.
I have not heard anybody from the NDP in the last little while stand up, like they used to, and talk about Sweden. What a wonderful model Sweden is with 500 per cent interest rates this year because it had to get things under control. Things were totally out of control in that country. Unemployment in Sweden is rising at a rate unseen anywhere right now.
The socialist ways do not work. God bless the people in Sweden. They saw the light and finally elected a conservative government which has to come in, as all conservative governments do, and clean up the mess that was left behind. That is exactly what is happening in Sweden today, and that is not the model. We understand the tough decisions that have to be made.
The Minister of Finance is a tough guy. He does not like making the decisions he has to make. There is nothing easier for a politician to do than throw money at a problem, to say: "Here, here is some money. Go away".
This minister is not doing that. This minister is putting scarce resources where they are needed. This minister is cutting back on expenditures because, quite simply, we cannot afford to go on spending the way we have. We cannot afford it. The buck stops somewhere. Once that credit card gets to its limit we have to start paying it back before we get any more credit. That is what we have to do and that is what this Minister of Finance has done. He
Government Orders
is to be congratulated. I know he will have the support of the Canadian people.
