subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, government members seem obsessed by the national debt. It reminds me of the movie Fatal Attraction. That is the only thing they talk about. Unfortunately, this time, Canadians were expecting much more than what they got.
Look at how things are going in Canada right now: the recession is the worst our country has seen since the 1930s; 1.5 million Canadians are unemployed; 2.3 million are on welfare and 3.8 million are living below the poverty level. Moreover, there are more than one million children living below the poverty line and more than two million Canadians lining up at food banks.
I ask the Minister of Finance and the government what they have done for those people in their last budget? What have they done? That last budget did not do much for anyone, neither for the debt and the deficit, nor for the Canadian people and the Canadian businesses. Finally the government did not deliver an economic statement as it called it, but a purely political statement. It simply took away $8 billion from the Canadian economy and put $2 billion back into it. That implies a net deficit of $6 billion for the Canadian economy.
The hon. minister was speaking of deficit control but what have we seen so far? Year after year the deficit keeps rising steadily. In the end the fact is that this government is selling the furniture to be able to pay the rent, to be able to go on. That is what they are doing; they sell the furniture to pay the rent and that is not fair.
This budget is an assault against the Canadian infrastructure, be it from the point of view of the Canadian people or in the literal sense. Here are a few examples from the budget. It speaks of supporting the growth of small businesses. Even the government recognizes that here in Canada it is the small businesses that have created the majority of jobs in the 1980s and 1990s.
Finally, more than 80 per cent of Canadian jobs have been created by small businesses. We can read in the minister's budget that the ceiling for loans to small businesses under the Small Businesses Loans Act will be increased to $250,000. But that hardly helps new businesses since all new firms do not become profitable

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
overnight and, hence, do not go knocking on the bank's door. Even if they did we must recognize that the banks do not come to their rescue.
The minister also proposes to help small businesses by exempting them temporarily from the payment of UI premiums. But again, if there are no profits small businesses will not hire people.
Instead of attacking the problem of unemployment this budget attacks the unemployed. We have seen in the statement made yesterday by the minister that unemployed Canadians are the ones who will be paying the price. This government will continue its attack on them and on the Canadian people.
We can also see in this budget an attack on the public sector. Government employees who provide services to Canadians will be affected. They have done their fair share these past few years. Their salaries have decreased following a wage control; their salaries have been frozen. Of course, taking into account the rate of inflation it is obvious there has been a decline.
With regard to investing in public infrastructure the proposal is'far from adequate. Let me tell you why. The government expects to create some 5,000 jobs over the next few years. In the last analysis this means very little when you consider that approximately 10,000 jobs have disappeared at Canadian National at one swoop. The government's $5 million commitment in this bill will not help much. It is a start but it will not solve Canada's economic problems.
Another important point is that this government asks us for suggestions. Our leader already submitted to the federal government a pretty concrete and efficient proposal concerning investments in infrastructures. The federal government could enter into a partnership with provinces and municipalities. These three levels of government could contribute one-third each. Then we could really create jobs in order to help Canadians.
I do not understand why the federal government would make such a statement and say it is an economic statement since it does not contain much to help the Canadian economy.
In closing the federal government in this statement really did nothing to help the Canadian economy. It is much more of an attack against the unemployed, against Canadians.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, yesterday's economic statement by the finance minister was made during the most serious job crisis in this country's history. One in four Canadians is either unemployed or under-employed, plants are closing throughout the country, and farms continue to go bankrupt. We have unfair taxes, worsening inequality and a sky-rocketing federal deficit.
In the face of all this, the finance minister yesterday delivered to this House a mini budget, a document, that will create an over-all net job loss in this country when unemployment is well over 11 per cent. This government saw Canadians drowning and instead of throwing them a line, it threw them an anchor. That is the bad news.
The good news is this government will not be around long enough to implement most of the harmful measures it has brought in.
Canadians everywhere were looking for two things from this statement.

They wanted a change. They wanted the government to acknowledge the failure of the old and outdated policies. They wanted new ideas to turn things around. Last, they wanted a message that would give them hope. They wanted to know that the government in Ottawa is willing to take whatever emergency measures are necessary to create jobs and put Canadians back to work.
On both counts, the economic statement can only be described as a monumental failure. There is not the faintest glimmer of hope in that statement. The unemployment rate is going to stay at 11 per cent all through next year. The deficit will be almost twice as much as anticipated.
Not one single Canadian family can now hope for 1993 to be a better year. There is nothing in that statement to justify such hope.
December 3, 1992



Rather than take bold action to help Canadians who have lost their jobs this government has chosen a 3-D approach: deny the problem, delegate the cost and dump on those who are hurting the most.
The cuts announced to unemployment insurance rank among the most mean-spirited economic actions ever taken by a Canadian government. These do nothing to solve unemployment. They will not generate a single job. They simply transfer costs to provincial, municipal and territorial governments as more and more Canadians are forced to turn to social assistance. The costs of unemployment insurance have gone up because of unemployment, not because of the unemployed. All the minister can do in response to this is punish the victims. This is not acceptable.
Leaving a job is not something that is taken lightly at any time in one's life. There are many reasons why people voluntarily leave their jobs such as harassment, discrimination and unsafe conditions. With a single move the federal government has put enormous power into the hands of employers. Unless employees can prove they were harassed, discriminated against or placed in danger they will not see a cent from an insurance program they have paid into. This is unacceptable.
Madam Speaker, put yourself in the position of a construction worker who is working in a situation under unsafe conditions and feels he or she must quit for health and safety reasons. I would put myself in the shoes of a woman who is being sexually harassed or discriminated against in the work place. Where does she turn now with UI denied if she leaves her job? How does she pay the bills if she cannot prove the harassment and discrimination happened? We do not move into the 21st century by returning to the employment policies of the 19th century.
There is one thing the Minister of Finance said yesterday with which I whole-heartedly agree and I quote: "Governing is about making choices". Absolutely. The government could have chosen to eliminate the business entertainment tax deduction. That is a $1 million saving to the taxpayer right there. It could have chosen to cancel the $4.4 billion helicopter program designed to fight a country that no longer exists. It could have taken that $4.4 billion and invested in a country that
Government Orders
does exist, Canada. The government had a choice. The government could have chosen to cancel the $1 billion tax break to the wealthy owners of private trusts. But, no, this government would rather close hospitals than close tax loopholes.

The government has decided to single out those who are least to blame for the present recession and to make scapegoats of them; I mean the unemployed, native Indians, the poor in the third world and the generations to come that will pay for the cuts affecting the environment.
We in our party would have made a different choice. We would have chosen a full employment economy, an economy where the government's first priority would be to create decent, lasting, well-paid jobs for everyone.

We must be prepared to commit to a full employment economy. We must be prepared for an all-out attack on unemployment and not an attack on the unemployed. We do not do that with bad trade deals like NAFTA and the FTA that destroy jobs. We do not do that by unfair taxes like the GST that hit hardest at those who can afford them the least. We do not do that with high interest rates that inflate the dollar and choke the economy.
A full employment economy means investing in Canadians. It means generating jobs and doing the work we so badly need such as rebuilding our social, municipal and environmental infrastructures. It means directed research, enriched education and a skilled and talented work force ready to take on the world.
For the past year we on this side have said to the government: "Take a fresh approach or move over for someone who will". Today we know that fresh approach is simply not possible from this government. What we heard yesterday was not a mini budget, an economic statement or a fiscal plan. It was a signed declaration of bankruptcy, morally, intellectually and politically.
We heard much in the minister's statement about the deficit. There is a federal government deficit all right. It is a deficit of ideas, a deficit of imagination and a deficit

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
of compassion for the people who have been so badly harmed by the policies of this government.
We in the New Democratic Party have an alternative. We have a vision. It is time for a change. Since this government has no vision and offers no hope, I say get out of the way for someone who does.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak on the economic statement made yesterday by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance.
It is not pleasant for us as members of Parliament to look at our country's economic situation and see the different measures that the government must take; we must analyze these measures and see whether they are what Canadians want and whether they are the right choice in the present economic situation.
This morning, I talked with the staff in my riding office in Jonquiere, Lise Dumont, M. France Paradis and Marie-Therese Ferland, and asked them whether the office had received any calls. "What are the people saying?"
The first thing people in our ridings bring up is unemployment insurance. They ask us why the government cut their future benefits from 60 to 57 per cent. Why is the government going after the unemployed in particular? Also, public servants call and ask us why the government froze their salaries. They point out that they had no increase last year and 3 per cent this year, if I recall correctly, and now for the next two years they will have to live with no pay increase.
Those issues affect people and also us as members. It is no fun to see that our salaries will not go up, even though we are better paid than many people in our society. But besides that, there are some positive elements and others which are less good. We talked about some of the tougher measures, such as those I just mentioned. What are the positive ones in yesterday's economic statement? First, there is no tax increase next year. Since income tax is supposed to go down by 1 per cent in 1993 that means some $2 billion more in the Canadian economy. That is an important point. Generally speaking when people have more money we can expect some economic recovery.
Second, we have the amounts that will be allocated to manpower training. We are talking about a total of $2.2 billion, an increase of $300 million over last year. This is another step in the right direction.
In the small business sector, and I will talk about this in more detail later on, we now have 700,000 small businesses with fewer than five employees. We have
900.000	with fewer than 50 employees. This means they are eligible for small business loans of up to $250,000. Incidentally, when the banks grant these loans 85 per cent of the loan is guaranteed so that if a business is in financial difficulty the bank has some protection. By the same token, small businesses that need money for investment purposes have some assurance that the money will be available through the bank.
There are other ways in which we can help small businesses. For instance we can now tell them: if you hire new employees, next year you won't have to pay their unemployment insurance premiums which may save you as much as $1,600 per employee.
When we look at these measures and consider what we will have to do as a government to reactivate the economy I wish we were able to do more. This morning I would like to say that since there will be a new budget in March, perhaps the government should give the following some serious thought. We have $20 billion in the unemployment insurance fund. It is "pro-passive": $20 billion which is being used to pay people who stay home because they are out of work when they would much rather have a job. They do not want to stay home doing nothing. They want jobs.
As a government, we managed to take part of this money which is still in the unemployment insurance fund and invest it in manpower training. People say training is important. The challenge is that we have to create hundreds of thousands of jobs. We want to create
300.000	this year. It is a first step but we need a lot more. We have 1.6 million people who are unemployed. So we need hundreds of thousands of jobs. Why not take the UI fund and give it to small businesses?
Let me give you an example, let us say a weekly salary of $400. Small businesses would hire someone and we would pay three-quarters of that person's salary for so many weeks. Small businesses and employers would wake up and decide to expand or activate production and start hiring people. The UI fund just sits there. It is passive. Why not make it pro-active? The only difference is that I would take the money and offer it to small
December 3, 1992

businesses so that they could hire people. I have to assume, of course, that after a number of weeks these companies will decide to keep the people they hired and that the wheels will keep on turning. The money is there.
It is a suggestion. If we have to change the legislation, well let us do it! That is our job. We are already using the money for manpower training so I suggest the next budget should consider using the fund to activate the economy even more since people want to work. The Minister of Finance has taken a few steps in the right direction but he will have to take more later on.
Madam Speaker, I realize my time has almost run out and perhaps I may tell listeners that we, their elected representatives, understand them and are aware of their problems. However, there are certain budgetary measures we have to take because the government has less revenue. It is not spending more but less money is coming in. We are trying to do our best and we will keep trying to examine the various alternatives for accelerating economic activity and creating jobs.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
It being one o'clock I do now leave the chair until two o'clock this afternoon.
At 1 p.m. the House took recess.

AFTER RECESS

The House resumed at 2 p.m.

Mr. Speaker, in Canada a sexual assault is committed every 17 minutes and 90 per cent of the victims are women. Ever since 14 women died at the hands of Marc Lepine on December 6, 1989, we can no longer ignore the violent epidemic which is poisoning us all.
It is a fact that the majority of women in Canada are now afraid to walk their own neighbourhoods at night. In fact one woman from my riding says she will no longer use her own bank machine after she was recently harassed in broad daylight. My constituent was able to elude her attacker but for many women there is no escape from violence, especially in the home.
We were all shocked by the tragic murder last summer of 18-year old Carrie Lynn Pinard. Carrie never saw the face of the man who took her life. It was also not so long ago that three year-old Kayla Klaudusz disappeared and was later found dead in Lake Ontario.
We must stop this epidemic. It is time for all men to speak out against violence against women.

Mr. Speaker, the media and the opposition seem determined to mislead the Canadian people regarding the effects of the past and the pending legislation affecting drug patent laws.
We keep hearing that drug prices have gone up because of legislation providing increased patent protection. However what we do not hear is that patented drugs account for approximately 3 per cent of the entire pharmaceutical industry and of the over-all increase in drug prices, patented drugs have risen only 2.9 per cent since 1984, while the remaining amount of the over-all increase has been in the non-patented line of drugs.
I think it is important to note that there are approximately 19,000 drugs that can be legally sold of which approximately 652 are patented drugs. That leaves over
18,000	non-patented drugs that are not even affected by patent legislation.
The opposition and the media are also dramatically silent about the increase in research and development in Canada sponsored by the pharmaceutical companies since 1984, Ontario being a key beneficiary.
I would love to list just some of the advantages Canadians realize from our patent protection legislation but unfortunately time does not permit me to do so.

December 3, 1992

Mr. Speaker, twice this week Canadians saw the Tory government put the interests of large, powerful corporations over those of Canadians and their health.
First the government's pathetic response to the foetal alcohol syndrome report showed the government buckling to the dictates of the liquor industry. The government refused to take leadership in initiating health warning labels on alcoholic beverages setting out the dangers of drinking during pregnancy.
Next we saw the government at the direction of the multinational drug companies move forward with its drug policy which will result in higher drug costs for families, seniors and provincial drug plans.
Canadians now know that this government is serving the interests of powerful corporations, not the interests of Canadians and their health.
[DOT]fc H* s)4

Mr. Speaker, I do not envy the challenge that the world recession has created for our Minister of Finance. Life would be ever so much easier if only we had the financial resources to spend.
Yesterday's economic statement caused great concern among many, not the least of whom are our public servants. I understand that yesterday's statement does not affect their earned salary increments. It is my understanding that the government assured the Public Service of two consecutive annual increases of 3 per cent. The Public Service received the first 3 per cent increase last July. They will not receive the next.
I know that everyone has some awareness of our tough fiscal situation and is understanding. However I wonder what happened to that commitment.

Mr. Speaker, December 2, 1992, will long stand as one of the darkest days in Canadian history. For one fleeting moment yesterday
Canadians held their collective breath in hopes that the contents of the finance minister's economic statement would help answer their prayers. Instead, the minister's proposals created new nightmares for all Canadians.
The finance minister has completely forgotten about northern Ontario. He has done nothing to stimulate the stagnant economy and create jobs in northern Ontario. Indeed, he has decided to cut spending by 10 per cent on programs such as FEDNOR which are designed specifically to attract new business and industry to northern Ontario.
The government has also shown cowardice in cutting UI benefits. Rather than making the tough decisions it should have, it chose to stay the course and make those who could least afford it bear the brunt of the government's fiscal mismanagement. Over the past year there has been an increase of almost 30 per cent in the number of business and consumer bankruptcies in my riding of Nipissing. All of this may be attributed to the devastating economic policies of the present government which has laid claim to being the fiscal saviour of Canada. It has shown all the signs of a tired and feeble government. The only statement which should be forthcoming from this government now is the call for an election.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to point out the initiative taken by Aeterna Laboratories, a company in my riding, which has made a name for itself in the health field. Aeterna has been dynamic and shown initiative. For example, this young company has developed the Natcel food supplement, which took four years of research.
Besides encouraging research in Canada, this product is available from 1,000 therapists in Quebec and will soon be sold throughout North America.
Canadian private companies must be increasingly innovative and competitive. As markets become global we must continue to give our constituents the tools they need to bring about the economic growth from which everyone benefits.
December 3, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the Tory government's budget statement once again highlights a government out of touch with the people of this country and totally inept at managing our economy. If an accountant of a business in Northumberland misjudged the company's budgeting as badly as this government did its deficit, the business would be bankrupt or the accountant would be fired.
This tired government is out of touch and disconnected from economic realities faced by business and consumers, Canadians. Unemployment is chronically high. Welfare rolls are soaring. In Northumberland alone it is estimated that 2,000 more citizens will be on welfare in the next month, many of them youth. Food banks and soup kitchens across the country are the growth phenomenon.
People need jobs. Northumberland needs harbours, water, sewage treatment, infrastructure which would create jobs, assist welfare-swamped municipalities and taxpayers. Instead, the government cuts jobs.
Where is the justice? Where is the vision? Where is the competence? Not in this tired old Tory government. Let us elect the Tories out of business now.

Mr. Speaker, further to the economic and fiscal statement presented yesterday, December 2, 1992,1 want to say that I do not agree with freezing public servants' salaries. Our public servants in Abitibi do an excellent job in representing the Canadian government properly and serving the people and I think that we must respect our previous commitments to them.

Mr. Speaker, the Westray mine explosion took 26 lives almost seven months ago. Yet the people in the area and in the rest of Nova Scotia have been denied the right to answers that would help the families who lost loved ones in the disaster to understand what went wrong.
There have been four formal requests of the Prime Minister and this government to hold hearings as to what happened. The federal government put a lot of money into this mine. It seems only proper that it would like to know the answers as to why this tragedy took place at the Westray mine.
As a Nova Scotian and as a representative in this House I am ashamed of the lack of leadership that this government has shown in this tragedy. I call upon this government and the Prime Minister, who came to this House because of the people of Pictou County, to hold a hearing into the reasons why 26 lives were lost last May in the Westray mine.

Mr. Speaker, today we celebrate the United Nations International Day of the Disabled. This is a unique opportunity to step up our efforts so that equality for the disabled throughout the world is not an abstract concept but a reality.
Canada defends human rights at home and abroad and is proud that the world has such a day for the disabled. Nevertheless, we must extend our activity beyond our own borders. Following the international conference of ministers responsible for the disabled, a working group will consider how to establish a permanent mechanism for exchanging information and technology among all countries.
The goal is the full integration of the disabled in all communities of the world. Canadians and citizens of all other countries can work together for equality, a basic right that we must never cease to defend.

December 3, 1992
Mr. Speaker, the Tory government has a responsibility to develop a national highway program and it has failed utterly to meet that obligation.

Mr. Speaker, this is a compilation of press comments on the mini budget. It is uninspiring, unimaginative, as bad as the Liberal statements in the early 1980s. Canadians have been scrooged by a mini budget which is too little, too late, too Tory, a terrible exercise. The Tories did not know what the right thing was for the last eight years and still do not. This is a mini budget, heartless and brainless, a brazen attack on the nation's most vulnerable citizens. As Tories run out of gas, this has been a government running on an intellectual fuel tank marked empty. I quote from La Presse: Le remede de Mazankowski est me boite de Q-Tips.
But there is also hope from the same source. It is la fin du regne.
The program that the minister announced yesterday is not a national one. It does nothing to meet the transportation needs of much of Canada, in particular northern Ontario.
The Ontario Auditor General has found that it will take $20 billion to bring that province's highway system to a satisfactory level. Provinces and municipalities throughout Canada have been hard hit by the Tory recession so the federal government must participate in a shared program of infrastructure reconstruction.
The federal government should identify all federal transportation responsibilities that require upgrading, including VIA Rail, CN, CP, marine facilities and funding for provincial transportation services.
*
*

Federal investment in Canada's infrastructure is long overdue and would assist Canada's economic recovery while creating desperately needed jobs. The projects that would result would also make many of our highways safer.

Mr. Speaker, last July legislation was passed to tighten the control of firearms. However, one important measure to reduce the illegal use of firearms was not addressed. I am referring to the need to amend the Criminal Code to introduce a law that would have a minimum mandatory prison sentence whenever an individual, including a young offender, commits a crime using a firearm.
The finance minister's economic statement yesterday was bad news for transportation in Canada and bad news for the economy. It is a shameful product of a Tory government that has lost the right to govern.

Many law enforcement officers are supportive of this idea. Chief Bryan Cousineau of the York Regional Police agrees. He is adamant that even first-time offenders committing a crime while carrying a firearm should be given a mandatory jail sentence.
It is time for us to get tougher with those who threaten the lives of our citizens. We should not tolerate people who use guns to commit crimes. There should be no plea bargaining, only mandatory jail sentences for such actions.

Mr. Speaker, the United Nations has declared today, December 3, as the International Day of Disabled Persons.
Canada must invest in all her citizens, including persons with disabilities, if we are to ensure that the Canada of tomorrow will be strong and competitive. Such a commitment has been clearly demonstrated in recent years by our annual National Access Awareness Week and the current five-year National Strategy for the Integration of Persons Disabilities.


Canada is recognized as a world leader in integrating disabled persons into the community.
Earlier this year we hosted Independence '92 in Vancouver. In October the Secretary of State, the minister responsible for the status of disabled persons hosted the first ever International Conference of Ministers Responsible for Persons with Disabilities in Montreal. A few days later he addressed the UN General Assembly in special session to mark the end of the Decade of Disabled Persons.
Today, as we recognize the International Day of Disabled Persons, I congratulate the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State for their vision, energy and leadership in working for equality of opportunity for persons with disabilities, both in Canada and around the world.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, farm producers in supply managed sectors are concerned about the GATT trade talks. For five years Canada and about 100 other countries have been negotiating a new trade agreement. Today the talks are deadlocked and some countries are threatening to impose tariffs.
Canadian farmers have been well served by GATT article XI. They want it to be maintained. The government must help them now and give them the assurance that article XI will be kept.

Mr. Speaker, I must say I welcome the economic recovery measures announced by the Minister of Finance. First of all, the government is maintaining a sound and responsible economic policy. Second, the government is introducing measures to help small businesses.
We all know that small business is the primary engine of our economy and the prime creator of jobs. The government's measures include an exemption from unemployment insurance premiums for new businesses starting up in 1993.
Oral Questions
Furthermore, a 10 per cent investment tax credit will be offered to small businesses. Finally, the ceiling for loans to individual businesses under the Small Businesses Loans Act will be raised from $200,000 to $250,000.
Mr. Speaker, I am confident that these support measures for small business will stimulate economic recovery and help Canadians who are seeking jobs.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, now that Canadians have had a chance to look at the statement of the Minister of Finance it is evident that the Prime Minister, the Minister of Finance and the cabinet just do not get it.
There is absolutely nothing in it for the unemployed. They are not attacking unemployment; they are attacking the people who are not working. There is nothing in this budget that will create jobs and create growth. That is very evident and we have made some suggestions to the government.
Why has the Minister of Finance not taken the suggestion of the opposition to plug the loopholes referred to by the Auditor General last week when he said that hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars are placed abroad by big corporations which are avoiding taxes in Canada?
That money could be used to create a program for infrastructure as demanded by the municipalities. The government could create jobs immediately. For every dollar invested by the federal government it could have had $3 of success.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first and foremost, there was a very sensible and affordable infrastructure program advanced in the economic plan I introduced yesterday.
With respect to the closing of loopholes, for example, financial institutions were paying $150 million a year in tax in 1984. We introduced the large corporations tax and the capital tax on large financial institutions. Last year financial institutions paid $1 billion in income tax.

December 3, 1992
Oral Questions
In 1985, we introduced a minimum tax regime for high-income individuals. We eliminated income splitting among family members through the use of interest-free loans. We removed tax shelters based on investments in yachts, recreational vehicles and other similar properties. We terminated the scientific research tax and credit measure. We stopped the so-called carve-out transactions in oil and gas. We prevented the use of trusts and market securities issued in such a way that the capital returns to investors were distributed tax free.
I could go on to 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989 and 1990 to cite more.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
What a great speech. While the government did that, it produced a deficit of $30 billion every year.
Now the Auditor General tells the government there are some loopholes and it is not moving on them.

Yesterday the Government of Quebec, using the limited resources at its disposal, tabled a program that may create jobs. We suggested a program to the federal government. This summer I travelled across Canada. I spoke to the mayors of Montreal, Laval and a number of other municipalities, and they are all ready to create jobs immediately.
Why does the government not do something? Is it because when they give money to municipalities they cannot play the patronage game themselves?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the economic plan I outlined yesterday takes steps to encourage investment in growth, investment in people, investment in infrastructure, investment in trade, encouraging partnerships and takes action with respect to costs.
The infrastructure program announced yesterday is something that can go forward very quickly. Discussions with a number of provinces are at an advanced stage. We want to transform the commitment for these infrastructure undertakings into action as soon as we possibly can
so there can be jobs created and a spin-off benefit can occur. That will not only stimulate economic activity. It will also improve the competitiveness and productive capacity of our country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is something in the minister's budget that is worrying a lot of Canadians. That is the new rule forcing those who quit their jobs voluntarily out of the unemployment benefit scheme.
We have received many telephone calls today from women's organizations telling us there are a lot of people who are obliged to quit their jobs because of sexual harassment. In order to keep their privacy they are willing to take a penalty of 12 weeks but still benefit from the plan to which they have made contributions for many weeks or months.
Is it fair to oblige them now to make a case for their situation if they want to draw what they have invested in an insurance program?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think this is a very serious question. The hon. member mentions receiving calls from women's organizations. Looking at the irresponsible and false statements made yesterday by Judy Rebick and Nancy Riche, the president of the NDP, no wonder those people are concerned out there.
Some people have interpreted this measure as meaning that sexually harassed people in Canada can no longer receive UI benefits. This is a falsehood. This is a false statement.
Sexually harassed persons are still protected. They were yesterday. They are today. They will be tomorrow. For those who are yelling on that side of the House, look at section 28 of the Unemployment Insurance Act.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of employment. The problem is that this government has given the women of Canada a terrific choice. They can work with sexual harassers or they can quit voluntarily and go through a long and costly battle to prove their case.
Why has the minister created this mess? When will he give a clear definition of sexual harassment as just cause for voluntary quitters for a change?
December 3. 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canadians have to understand the stratagem of those petty leaders out there. This is a complete falsehood.
Sexual harassment is a just cause for any Canadian to quit his or her job. Yes, we have people who say that we should keep it under a lid, that we should not expose the harasser and we should let the woman suffer sexual harassment. This government is saying no to that. In Canada, a sexually harassed woman or man can quit his or her job and receive UI benefits. This has not changed.

Mr. Speaker, I spent four years as the chair of the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board. I know what it takes to prove just cause.
This government is forcing Canadian women to sacrifice privacy if, in their poverty, they can afford it. Why is the minister targeting women and worsening the nightmare of sexual harassment? It is a nightmare.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member is sincere about her preoccupation, stop spreading the lie that women will not be protected under the act. They will have protection. They have protection and that provision of the Unemployment Insurance Act has not changed.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I listened very carefully to what the hon. minister said. He said that she should stop spreading that lie. I want the hon. minister to make it quite clear that he was not suggesting that the hon. member was lying.
Mr. Speaker, you are exactly correct. I did not say that she was lying but that she was spreading what Rebick and Riche said yesterday.

Mr. Speaker, an analysis of the Minister of Finance's economic statement yesterday indicates that there will be a net loss of 62,000 jobs because of the measures the government has introduced. The minister's statement is a failure by every measurement.
The first reaction today is that a manufacturing plant in Quebec has filed for bankruptcy putting 400 workers out of work. The General Motors plant in St. Catharines is looking at selling off or closing down and another 800 workers will be affected.
Oral Questions
This country cannot afford more job losses. The Minister of Finance's economic statement creates a net job loss. Will the minister do the right thing and withdraw this economic statement before further harm is done to this country?
Hon. Don Ma/.ankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance): Mr. Speaker, no. It is a responsible and affordable approach. If the hon. member wants to get the economy of Ontario going perhaps she could speak to her friend, Premier Rae.
A headline in the November 14 Toronto Star read: "NDP is blamed for job losses. Ontario's economy, particularly the manufacturing sector, continues to be racked by massive job losses and Queen's Park is being blamed". Another quote: "The Ontario NDP government with a vicious high tax punch to the solar plexus: It knocked Ontario businessmen to their knees, then it smashed its labour legislation over business' head. Now as business lies dazed and bleeding on the floor Premier Bob Rae's government is prepared to deliver-"

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Yukon.

Mr. Speaker, the sign of a truly bankrupt government is when it cannot defend its own policies and has to put the blame on someone else.
The Minister of Finance in his statement yesterday said that he had some choices. I would suggest the minister had many choices but this government chose that it would prefer to close hospitals rather than tax loopholes.
The minister had another choice. For instance, a 3 per cent drop in Canada's interest rates would have saved almost the same amount of money that was slashed from programs through the minister's economic statement. A 3 per cent drop in interest rates would also have created
120,000	jobs.
The minister knows very well that the government's policies influence interest rates in this country. Why did he choose to penalize the victims of this recession rather than take positive steps toward lowering interest rates?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again we see the bankruptcy of ideas coming from over there. I presented

Oral Questions
a plan on behalf of the federal Government of Canada. Where is the NDP's plan?
We know what the Ontario government has done to exacerbate the unemployment problem in Ontario.
The hon. member talks about a 3 per cent drop in the interest rate. What kind of fiscal and monetary policy would she propose to bring a reduction of 3 percentage points in the interest rate? You cannot just dial a phone and get a reduction of 3 per cent in interest rates.

Mr. Speaker, the government has chosen a policy along with the Bank of Canada to focus solely on the reduction of inflation and not the creation of employment. It has resulted in gross unemployment and an increased deficit.
[Translation\
I have another question for the Minister of Employment and Immigration. The most inhumane thing that was announced in yesterday's budget is perhaps the change in the unemployment insurance program. It is an assault on workers who will be forced to hang on to any kind of job, no matter how unbearable. It will put an end to labour mobility and cost taxpayers, provinces and territories alike, hundreds of billions of dollars. The minister claims that such a change is justified.
I would like to ask the minister the following question. The government must do away with this new policy. Is it going to do it now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, will the leader of the NDP ask the president of the NDP, Nancy Riche, to retract the false statement she made yesterday, misleading Canadians?

Mr. Speaker, I also have a question for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
First, I want to say to him that the vicious plan of his to make culprits of all those who quit or who are fired is a throwback to the sweat shops of pre-industrial England. It stacks the odds so ruthlessly in favour of the employer
and puts women in particular at risk in terms of sexual harassment.
The minister says they will have their day in court. Yes, and who pays the bills and who buys the groceries in the meantime? I ask the minister why is he, by this measure, aiding and abetting sexual harassment in the workplace?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canadians have to wonder. Yesterday in the statement of the finance minister there was not one iota of reference to the nature of what is a just cause for quitting a job in Canada, not one word.
I want Canadians to know that the only issue is that voluntary quitters, people who quit a job for no good reason, can no longer expect hardworking Canadian workers and employers to pay them benefits for having quit a job for no just cause.

Mr. Speaker, can the minister not get it through his head that establishing just cause takes time and you have to buy the groceries while that time goes on.
The minister will be aware that Newfoundland has the highest unemployment rate in Canada. He will be aware that two-thirds of the country's lowest income earners are women. The minister's decision to target those who quit or who are fired is a sinister, cowardly assault on the poor regions and on women. I say to him that it is those regions and those women who will be compromised.
Can the minister give us one good reason why he persists in this madness? Or does he get his jollies out of kicking people while they are down?

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: Just a moment. I think on both sides for the rest of this Question Period I want some concentration on making sure that there are no personal affronts thrown across the floor of the House.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member wants to reflect on his question he is talking about a process under the Unemployment Insurance Act that was not raised at all in the statement of the finance minister yesterday.
Canadians have a right to know this. This department has dealt with the issue of just cause for 42 years. There is a process in place. The instructions to the officers are to give the benefit of the doubt to the applicant. That is
December 3, 1992

why this unemployment insurance fund costs workers and employers in Canada $21 billion this year.
Surely Canadians will support the screening out of a person who quits his or her job for the purpose of sitting at home and drawing UI while there are people who work hard to pay those premiums. This is about justice and fairness to the workers of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Hundred of thousands of unemployed and poor Quebecers were expecting the government to finally break its silence and choose the real priorities in its budget. Fixing two bridges, Mr. Speaker, is hardly enough.
My question is this: how long does the government think it can keep on fooling Quebecers and the Canadian people with its amateurish policies and its total lack of vision to stimulate growth?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am quite surprised at the hon. member's question. Quite frankly, we laid out an economic plan yesterday that deals, in a very comprehensive way, with investment and growth, improvements in the small business sector, R and D and transforming into a new economy, investment in people through enhanced and improved training programs, and an infrastructure program that can be started and expedited very quickly, with emphasis on the Atlantic region, the province of Quebec, and Ontario and in all regions of the country to deal with some of the bottle-necks in transportation that are under the jurisdiction of the federal government. That applies to bridges, roads and parks.
We also outlined our steps to invest and enhance our trading opportunities and to promote partnerships not only with other governments but with the private sector, and then, of course, very comprehensive action with respect to the containment of costs. It is a blueprint that deals with the problems that we face today and the problems of the future.

It is a blueprint for poverty and for unemployment.
Oral Questions
Mr. Speaker, the government's training programs do not meet one-third of the current demand. The government talks about pharmaceutical research but it has cut research grants to universities and it has decimated Canada's ability to develop environmental technologies.
Montreal has the highest unemployment rate and the highest poverty rate of any major city in Canada. Does the government really think that cutting unemployment benefits or repairing two bridges is going to turn that around?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, not to a casual observer, but to any serious observer of the economic statement of yesterday, anyone who cares to look at it must conclude that the top priority which comes out of this statement is investing in human resources.
We have increased the money for training unemployed Canadians by 450 per cent, from $400 million three years ago to $2,221 billion yesterday. Furthermore, we have increased the spending under the Consolidated Revenue Fund to further train Canadians.
As I have heard the member say, if the key to Canada's competitiveness is investment in human resources, he should applaud the Minister of Finance for what he did yesterday.

Mr. Speaker, it is clear from his comments that the Minister of Employment and Immigration does not understand the reality of the workplace for women or for visible minorities.
Racial and sexual discrimination cases take two years even through the Human Rights Commission. How does he think that his department and his tribunals will be either better or faster? Employees cannot go without income for months and years and women will be forced to stay in abusive situations.
Will the minister please, please come to his senses and reverse this decision that penalizes the victims of discrimination?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a lot of respect for the hon. member but I would hope that she would talk

December 3, 1992
Oral Questions
with the president of her party. Yesterday, Nancy Riche, made that statement-
Oh, oh.

This is serious for the women of Canada. If there is one woman in this country who is sexually harassed and because of the statement made yesterday by the president of the NDP, stays in place and continues to be sexually harassed, you have not rendered a service to that Canadian woman. The fact is that person should quit her job, expose the harasser and she will be protected.
Oh, oh.

The fact is, Mr. Speaker, that this minister does not understand what is happening right across this country to people who are being pressed by economic circumstance and are facing discrimination and harassment. He should understand it.
I want to ask the Minister of Finance this. This morning we discovered that the four U.S. states of Michigan, New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania have this same policy, of cutting off unemployment benefits from those who are fired or who quit.
Will the Minister of Finance admit that this mean new policy that he has brought in is to harmonize this Canadian social policy with supporting policies of United States' states and to forget about the values that Canadians hold dear?
Oh, oh.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the proposed UI changes have nothing to do with the social programs of our trading partners.
We are making these changes because they are the right thing to do at this time of our fiscal situation. Canadians know that our social programs will continue to provide, by world standards, very generous benefits to unemployed Canadians.
Maybe the hon. member will not admit it but the treatment of an unemployed person in Canada is still
better than in France, in Japan and even in the United States of America.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
Yesterday's shocking and heartless statement by the Minister of Finance was a vicious assault on the unemployed. The minister boasts about a $300 million training program. However, the minister fails to tell Canadians about the $2.4 billion he robbed from the unemployed.
Why are the unemployed paying for this government's economic incompetence?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am sure the hon. member understands that when we are under extreme fiscal pressure a number of measures have to be taken-
Because of your incompetence.

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
He says because of my incompetence, Mr. Speaker. The current Leader of the Opposition, when he was finance minister back in 1978, brought in a budget that reduced the weekly benefits from 66-2/3 per cent to 60 per cent of weekly insurable earnings. Furthermore, at that point in time the costs of the unemployment insurance program were $4 billion. What did the then Minister of Finance take out of the unemployment insurance program; $935 million to take effect in 1980 and 1981.
There comes a time when finance ministers and governments have to make tough decisions. We have made some very difficult decisions but we have not been as heartless as the current Leader of the Opposition, the former Minister of Finance.

Mr. Speaker, this country does not want researchers. What we want is leadership by this government.
It is clear that this government is out of touch with reality. There are 1.5 million Canadians who are unemployed; 2.2 million live on welfare; 400,000 young people are unemployed and this government has decided to stay the course, the course that has brought on this economic recession. It is time for change.
Will the minister introduce a serious economic plan that will put Canadians back to work?
December 3. 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the Leader of the Opposition was the finance minister he cut one million Canadians and inflation was running at 9 percent at that particular time.
What we have in this economic plan is clearly a plan for the future: investing in people, investing in plant and equipment, investing in infrastructure, investing in partnerships, enhancing trade, adjusting to the new realities, adjusting to the realities of a newly emerging economy. That is leadership.
You cannot adopt policies for a world as you think you would like it to be; you have to adopt policies for the world as it is.

Mr. Speaker, my question is also for the Minister of Finance.
Last month in Toronto alone 1,000 additional families were added to the welfare rolls, bringing the total number of recipients to a record 108,000 families and costing over $1.5 billion. These figures are surely to rise after the minister's mini budget yesterday.
Rather than attacking the unemployed and their benefits as he squarely did yesterday, which will only push more families on to the welfare rolls, why did the government refuse to stimulate the Toronto centred economy seriously in order to create and emphasize job fare rather than more welfare?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the purpose of the statement yesterday was to create jobs and take people off unemployment and take people off welfare. That is the over-all objective, building upon the initiatives taken in the February budget which really zeroed in on the economy of Ontario.
In the manufacturing and processing sectors we took a number of positive steps to improve the capital cost allowance. We took steps to reduce the burden of taxes. Yesterday we announced no new taxes. As a matter of fact we froze UI premiums. We provided incentives for people to go out and hire new people. We provided further incentives to the small business sector because that generates 80 per cent of the jobs.
Oral Questions
Insofar as what the hon. member is suggesting about overlooking Ontario, some $230 million are allocated for Ontario in terms of infrastructure, to improve the rail initiatives and the runways.
We will be sitting down very soon with each of the provincial governments to work out the kinds of sharing arrangements that are reasonable so that we can get these projects going very quickly and that the provinces will have some input and some say into the priorities they wish us to proceed with.

The minister says that in due course they will be sitting down. Mr. Speaker, this province has been waiting for eight years for some concrete proposals to put Canadians back to work and it is still waiting.
Since the minister talked about Ontario, given that the province of Ontario has suffered 80 per cent of all lost manufacturing jobs in the country, that its housing industry remains terribly weak at best, and that its construction and trade sectors are absolutely flat, how can the government be so disconnected and out of touch with reality to be able to ignore the urgent need to stimulate seriously-not the pap we have had-the Ontario economy which happens to be one of the major engines of economic growth in this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I agree with the hon. member. The economy of Ontario is a very major engine of economic activity accounting for about 40 per cent of the economic activity in Canada.
With respect to the infrastructure proposals I can assure the hon. member that starting today-and this would be a continuation of some earlier discussions we have had with the provinces-we will go to work to get these infrastructure projects on the road.
The hon. member talks about housing. There has been a very impressive pick-up in housing due to the policies that we announced. Yesterday I announced the extension of the RRSP program.
The hon. member has further comments about what we should be doing to assist the economy of Ontario. I read this headline: "NDP blamed for job losses in Ontario". I am sure the hon. member would agree with that. You cannot have a government that is anti-business and expect them to create jobs. That is something that we-

December 3, 1992
Oral Questions

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I think we will have to move on.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs. It concerns the announced massive cuts in Canada's development assistance which will not only affect aid-related jobs in Canada but which will have a devastating impact on our commitment to the global fight against poverty, AIDS and environmental destruction.
At a time when 40,000 children are dying each day of preventable disease and hunger, how can this government defend these inhumane cuts while spending over $4 billion on attack helicopters? Will the minister at the very least assure the House that these savage cuts will exempt not only famine relief but also support for NGOs and aid for meeting basic human needs, particularly those of women and children?

speakeroldname: Hon. Monique Landry (Minister for External Relations and Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)):
speakerposition: Minister for External Relations; Minister responsible for La Francophonie; Minister of State (Indian Affairs and Northern Development)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, since 1984 this government has certainly made it clear that it was committed to pursue programs in aid of third world countries.
Of course, our international concerns and domestic concerns are interrelated. If Canada is ever to provide more assistance it has to start by putting its fiscal house in order. Only then will it be in a position to increase its foreign aid budget. That is what we are doing by continuing to discharge our commitments towards the poorest of the poor, the women and children in the third world.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance who seems to be running the environment department these days.
Yesterday's Tory blueprint clearly made it a black day for the green plan. This government's failed commitment to the environment took another step back with the third cut to the green plan. This will mean cuts to the Fraser River Management Plan, Tree Plan Canada, and the clean-up of the St. Lawrence River and the Great Lakes. No opportunity was taken to develop new and innovative jobs in the environment.
When will the government finally defend the environment instead of trashing it all the time?

Mr. Speaker, it is incumbent upon us personally and collectively to curtail further deficit increases. Under the green plan there will be a reduction of $60 million this year, with a reduction in the following two years of 10 per cent. Given that, there will be an increase of some 30 per cent in spending on the green plan even after those cuts are done.
In terms of priorizing the aspects of the plan the hon. member has mentioned, those decisions have not been taken yet and they will be taken collectively by the cabinet of this government.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance. Yesterday's economic statement includes a measure concerning flow-through shares to promote investment in junior oil and gas companies. It provides for yearly write-offs totalling nearly $10 million to finance exploration.
I would like to know why the mining industry is excluded from this measure affecting small companies starting up in Quebec?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what we did yesterday for small explorers and oil companies was to bring the policy in line with the mining sector because they currently have those provisions.
What I did indicate was that the Income Tax Act would be amended to provide more flexibility to the mining sector to utilize its non-capital losses in the same way as it utilizes its capital losses.
December 3, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Solicitor General.
Last week Wray Budreo, a sexual deviant with a 30-year history of molesting children, was scheduled to be released from prison after serving only four of a six-year sentence.
It seems to have taken public outrage to force a last minute delay in his release, preventing this paedophile from going back on the streets where undoubtedly he would have continued his record of attacking children.
What is the Canadian government going to do to prevent the release of dangerous offenders such as Wray Budreo? Surely such a person should be put away for life.

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the House will know that Bill C-36 came into effect recently. That considerably tightened up the regulations and the law with respect to sexual offenders.
There is a concern remaining with respect to high risk repeat sexual offenders. We are presently reviewing three possibilities: first, broadening the use of dangerous offender applications; second, reviewing the definition of the words serious harm to make sure that it is appropriate; and, third, working within present mental health laws rather than criminal laws to detain high risk repeat sexual offenders beyond the conviction for which they are serving time.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
In the highlights from yesterday's economic statement we will find many charts but none that mention unemployment. Perhaps the minister is ashamed that Canada has the highest unemployment rate in the G-7.
I ask the minister to rise to the challenge of the highest unemployment in the G-7 and put an end to this episode of "Maz" misery.
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I acknowledge that the unemployment levels are too high. There has been some improvement in employment generation over the last five or six months. I think I was quite honest with the House and with the Canadian people that one of our biggest problems is the fact that the growth that is generated is insufficient to generate the kind of job potential we need.
Hopefully, with the pick-up in the U.S. economy and with the initiatives we took yesterday, the specific initiatives with respect to infrastructure and the other incentives, we will have a pick-up. We are expecting 300,000 new jobs to be created in 1993. I wish it were better but this is one of the problems we are facing as we go through this period of transition.

Mr. Speaker, the minister keeps telling us that Santa Claus is coming but all his elves are out of work.
My supplementary question is for the same minister. The minister has pledged to give new businesses a break by forgiving their UI premiums for 1993. The minister's plan may be nothing more than a disguised first step in dumping the entire UI burden on to the backs of workers.
I ask the minister if his plan to dismantle the UI system is also the beginning of a new tax on the working class.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member's observation is absolute nonsense. When she talks about the difficulties Canada has I would remind her that in terms of the G-7 community the unemployment figures have risen from 18 million in 1990 to 23 million in 1992. It is not only Canada that is having this employment problem. Other countries are having similar problems.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
Yesterday the minister continued to ignore tax shelters for the very rich identified by the Auditor General. He continues to attack low and middle-income Canadians.

December 3, 1992
Privilege
Will he tell us precisely how his 10 per cent cuts will apply to regional development, transportation, western diversification, ACOA, agriculture and native programs?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member's question allows me an opportunity to complete an answer I started in the earlier part of Question Period. I outlined all the tightening of loopholes we undertook in
1985.
In 1986 we introduced the at risk rules to restrict the tax credit and business loss claims of investors in limited partnerships. We removed the tax advantage of salary deferral arrangements. We restricted the ability of corporations to engage in after tax financing through preferred shares. We prevented the use of commercial trusts to avoid tax in a manner unintended by the law.
In 1987 we the government introduced a phased reduction in the extent of the acceleration in capital cost allowances. We reduced the reserves claimed by financial institutions.
Right.

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: We imposed a creditable capital tax on large deposit taking institutions and we introduced the general anti-avoidance rule. In 1989 we constrained the ability of corporations to transfer the benefits of accelerated capital cost allowance through leasing.

Mr. Speaker, he does not tell us about the 34 or 37 tax increases for middle and low-income Canadians. Will the minister tell us why he is reducing the Crow benefit by $73 million next year and $104 million the year after? Does he not know that some of our prairie producers have big problems? Does he know what this is going to do to increase the cost of moving grain across the prairies?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is an expert on the Crow. I have seen some articles he has written. He would also be interested in knowing that under the GWTA in excess of $800 million is being paid out by the federal government.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I am wondering if the government House leader could indicate to the House the business for tomorrow, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, at this point it would be my intention to call Bill C-93, the government organizations bill, at second reading for tomorrow.
I would like to formally designate Monday as an allotted day, the final allotted day of this period. On Thesday we anticipate starting report stage of Bill C-91, the Patent Act. Question of privilege.
Point of order.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Halifax. A minister and a member have risen on a point of order. I have indicated that I should hear the question of privilege first.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of privilege arising from the response of the minister of employment to my question earlier. The minister accused me of spreading lies. He then said he did not call me a liar. He did however say I was spreading lies. As far as I am concerned, that allegation not only impugns my integrity but it also impugns by intelligence.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The hon. member has raised a matter which came up during Question Period. Hon. members will remember I did rise and I did ask the hon. minister to make it very clear that he was not calling the hon. member a liar or imputing lies to her.
The minister responded and at the time I thought that was adequate. I have listened to the hon. member but I think the matter is closed. However, the hon. member's further intervention on this matter, making it necessary for me to rise again, indicates to all hon. members how careful we must be when we are describing motives of
December 3, 1992

less than honour to any member on either side of the Chair. I thank the hon. member for the intervention.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker. I do not want to belabour the point in terms of your ruling. I would merely point out that we have been accused today in Question Period of attacking the poor, being heartless, being out of touch and all of those things and frequently we get shouted down when we address the House. If those things were a point of privilege, I am afraid we would spend all day discussing points of privilege.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, pursuant to Standing Order 83(1) I wish to table a notice of Ways and Means motion to amend the Customs Tariff, the Excise Act, the Excise Tax Act, the Customs Act, the Criminal Code and a related act, and I ask that an Order of the Day be designated for consideration of the motion.

Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order of which I have given notice to the Minister of Employment and Immigration and yourself. It is related to the matter on which the member for Halifax rose.
During Question Period today the Minister of Employment and Immigration very clearly accused two individuals, who are not members of this House, of being liars. The traditions of Parliament provide for free speech in this House and that members who say things in here are immune from any prosecution or any action because of their comments.
Points of Order
However, in Beauchesne's sixth edition on page 22 under the section "Freedom of Speech", it states:
77. Freedom of speech does not mean that Members have an unlimited or unrestrained right to speak on every issue. The rules of the House impose limits on the participation of Members and it is the duty of the Speaker, to restrain those who abuse the rules.
I would argue that had the Minister of Employment and Immigration said the same words outside of this House the two individuals, Judy Rebick and Nancy Riche, who were named by the minister repeatedly, would have the right to seek legal remedies.
I would suggest that the minister has crossed the fine line in this House, has used his position to abuse two individuals who spoke what they believe to be true and we believe to be true. I think, Mr. Speaker, you should ask the Minister of Employment and Immigration to withdraw those accusations against Ms. Rebick and Ms. Nancy Riche and apologize to them as well.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: We will spare the hon. member the protection of the House. I made that statement last night outside as soon as I heard it. It is on the record. If they want to sue me, be my guest.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Thunder Bay- Atikokan has raised a matter with reference to the text on the rules. I would ask him to let me examine carefully Hansard and I will come back to the House.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Very briefly, Mr. Speaker, I am wondering if the Chair could provide guidance to the House with respect to your ruling with regard to the point of privilege which has been raised by my colleague, the member for Halifax. Perhaps while the Chair is reflecting, he could indicate to the House as to what really is the difference between calling someone a liar and saying someone is spreading lies.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I will try to be as helpful as I can. The Chair is in the position of having to make rulings sometimes very quickly. I made a ruling. I have asked the House to accept it. I do not now intend to discuss it further.
I have thanked the hon. member for raising the matter. I have asked the House to keep in mind that

December 3, 1992
Points of Order
when statements are made that get either close to the line or over the line, it causes further statements along the same way.
I cannot be put in the position of re-examining a ruling that I made in the heat of debate and then discussing it further. That is asking more of the Chair than I think is appropriate.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Yes, Mr. Speaker. I was not questioning or reflecting upon your ruling. In point of fact, we accept the ruling of the Chair.
I seek the guidance of the Chair to try to provide some direction to members of this House in terms of the particular dispute that was in question. I would hope that the Chair would reflect upon my request because I believe it to be a very serious thing that has happened here today.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The Chair will reflect upon it but I am just asking hon. members please do not put the Chair in the position where many minutes later, after a decision has to be made as I said in the heat of conflict, to get into a philosophic discussion about the very matter upon which the Speaker has ruled.
If the hon. member or any other hon. member wishes to come to my office and discuss this matter, I of course will hear them. I am trying as much as is possible, and I am sure that all hon. members are very supportive of this, to try to maintain proper decorum in the Chamber. That is why of course I rose some time ago and said that I hoped that everyone would constrain themselves for the rest of Question Period and not make statements which are personal affronts on other members whether it comes from either side of the House. I recognize the point of my colleague, the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond, and I will reflect on the matter.

Mr. Speaker, I tried to get the attention of the Speaker going back to the questions raised by the House leader of the opposition to the House leader of the government about the work of the House over the next several days.
As you will know, he mentioned that Bill C-91 was coming forward. I was going to ask him whether he
would make an undertaking that in view of the use of time allocation on the second reading of the bill and in view of the fact that the committee hearings have been very much shortened that this House at report stage would have an opportunity for a full and thorough debate of the bill without an attempt to close off the bill by either time allocation or closure motion.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: First of all in response let me say that I apologize to the hon. member for Surrey North. There were a number of members rising and I did not realize that the hon. member was on the usual Thursday afternoon question raised by the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond. Therefore, I ask the hon. member to accept my apologies.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I was seeking the floor on another matter and I accept your response on the question of the C-91 intervention.
If I may, while I am on my feet, I would like to respond to a question of privilege raised last Monday by the hon. member for Essex-Kent.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: Let us not get ahead of ourselves. The hon. member for Surrey North has raised a matter. The government may want to respond or it may want to discuss it with the hon. member. If there is no response then I am going to go ahead.

Mr. Speaker, I certainly recognize that the oversight by the Speaker was not intentional and I do not take any affront from that. However, I do think that it is very important that that question be answered by the government, if not by the House leader then the House leader's parliamentary secretary.
We have a major piece of legislation that we have to plan for and to have some understanding on. The significance to the Canadian public and to provincial governments is great. We need some commitment from this government that it is not going to use time allocation again or closure to ram that bill through this House.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I just want to draw to the hon. member's attention that there was an all-party agreement in committee on this particular bill-
No, there was not.
