speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George -Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to enter into a very brief debate tonight.
On November 27 I asked the Minister of the Environment a very important question on the controversial Alcan Kemano project in northern British Columbia in my riding. It related directly to a number of documents that have seen the light of day related to this project. They indicated that at the time this whole project was being reviewed by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans, there was considerable controversy within the department. The department's own scientists then were questioning the senior staff within the department and indeed the political direction of the department to allow the project to proceed without a full environmental review.
Included in those documents, among other things, was one particular memorandum from a public employee that suggested he had been asked by his superiors to change his expert witness testimony at a time when this particular case was proceeding to court.
It has been very clear over the number of years that this issue has been discussed in public that there is a clear mood in northern British Columbia and, indeed, throughout the province to have a full public environmental review of this project, not to speak of all the excellent work of community groups in my riding in
December 3, 1992

communities like Fort Fraser, Fraser Lake, Vanderhoof, Prince George and other areas. I think there is an obligation on the part of the government to have a full review. The point in my question to the minister that day is that we have learned from the department's own freedom of information officer that there are some
83,000	pages of information on this project which the department refuses to release.
We have been advised by officials in the department in Ottawa that where the proponent, the Alcan Aluminum Company, has provided information to the government that the company has instructed the government not to release any of the documentation.
I say to the Government of Canada, why not release these documents. If the project is so good, why can it not stand on its own feet and have the public information available to people.
I also pursued the question with the minister at the same time, knowing that in British Columbia the new government there thankfully has taken a different approach on this issue. The Minister of the Environment of B.C. will be releasing all of the documents that the B.C. government has produced on this over time and we will get a chance to see the involvement of the Social Credit government of the day. The settlement agreement, as it is called, that governs the flow in this river was signed in secret in 1987. I called on the Minister of the Environment to approach the minister in British Columbia to have a full joint review of this project. Tonight I hope that the person responding from the government side will encourage the minister to do just that. Let us have a full public review of the Kemano project.

speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the government has acted responsibly in this review of the Kemano Completion Project. The 1987 settlement agreement reached between the Department of Fisheries and Oceans, British Columbia and Alcan provided fisheries protection through mitigation requirements for the Nechako River system, and furthermore removed the pristine Nanika River from further development by Alcan.
The Department of Fisheries and Oceans conducted considerable analysis of the potential impacts of the proposed Kemano Completion Project to determine
Adjournment Debate
protection requirements for fish and fish habitat and also undertook public consultation in 1984.
An out of court settlement agreement was reached with British Columbia and Alcan in 1987 after an independent review panel chaired by Dr. David Strangway, the then president of the University of British Columbia, advised that fisheries experts agreed that the potentially negative impacts on fisheries from the Kemano Completion Project could be mitigated.
The Department of Fisheries and Oceans applied the principles of its policy for the management of fish habitat, providing for no net loss of fish habitat and responsible resource management. The agreement formalized the release of flows to protect fisheries, and required Alcan to provide measures to mitigate the potential impacts on fish and fish habitat, thus securing longer term protection for the fish stocks.
In summary, the settlement agreement was entered into with extensive consideration for potential impacts on fisheries and the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans took the appropriate steps to ensure the necessary protection for fish and fish habitat.

Mr. Speaker, tonight I want to introduce you to four small business people from Toronto. There is Jim Frangos, who is a fur coat manufacturer, Nick Piras who is a restaurateur, Will Molson and Susan Bellan, who are retailers.
What do they all have in common? They are all being forced out of business because they cannot get a bank loan. Jim Frangos, the fur coat manufacturer, has been in business for many years. He built up a good business. He has borrowed money from the banks over the years numerous times, and always paid his bills. Right now the banks will not lend him any money. He is in peril of losing his home and in peril of losing his business.
Fur coats, however, are actually selling again. It is interesting to note that right now Canadian furs are being shipped to Greece. They are manufacturing fur coats in Greece and shipping them back to Canada to sell here and elsewhere around the world. There are all sorts of fur coats being sold, but the banks will not lend a fur coat manufacturer in Canada any money to stay in business.

December 3, 1992
Adjournment Debate
Nick Piras, a restaurateur, has a fine high-class restaurant in Toronto. He has been in business for many years. He has built up a good business. He has borrowed money from the banks. Again, he has never missed a payment, but the banks will not lend him any money. I have a letter from his banker right here which states: "Dear Nick: This is to confirm that the bank is not prepared to provide additional financing for your business".
Will Molson and Susan Bellan, who are retailers, have been in business for 12 years now. They borrowed money in the past. They have never missed a payment and they cannot get a bank loan.
A few years ago it was an entirely different story. One could go into a bank and ask for a loan and they would say: "How much?" In fact, if one asked for a certain amount of money they would say: "Won't you take some more?" Not any more.
Mr. Speaker, as you know and I know, the story is entirely different. A small business person cannot get a bank loan. In fact, I have been told that the banks, all of them, want to clear off their books about 25 per cent of bank loans that are outstanding.
We know that the Minister of State for Small Businesses and the Minister of Finance are most sympathetic with this situation. They have been trying to help. In fact, in the February budget there were some things for small business in it. In the economic and fiscal statement yesterday there were some things for small business. The legislation to implement those things that were in the budget last February still has not been passed. In fact, we had a debate on second reading of a bill a few days ago. Still we do not have this legislation through.
The banks themselves are not being outstanding either. We know the Minister of State for Small Businesses has met with them numerous times and pleaded with them to do something. Yesterday the Minister of Finance in his statement stated: "I am serving notice to Canada's banks that I expect them to make a special effort to play a constructive role in ensuring the success ot this program". Those are great words, but there still is not any action.
Jim Frangos just cannot wait. Nick Piras cannot wait. Will Molson and Susan Bellan cannot wait and thousands of other small business people cannot wait.
I want to ask the minister tonight just what am I going to tell them.

speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I hope you will give me the chance to respond because there is much good news in the highlights of the Minister of Finance's economic statement given yesterday in the House.
A significant part of the statement by the Minister of Finance was devoted to small business and to new and improved ways of helping this very important sector of our Canadian economy. I would like to highlight a few of them.
The Small Businesses Foans Act program which assists small business in obtaining access to financing will be made even more effective by the increase in maximum loan size to $250,000. This higher limit will permit larger program loans for all eligible businesses, including firms investing in technology, to improve their competitiveness. A number of other improvements are being made to the program and these will be made public tomorrow when the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism tables a bill to amend the act.
As indicated in the economic statement, the government is also working to broaden the implication of the program to include some forms of working capital loans. The Small Business Financing Program, aimed at helping financially troubled businesses lower their cost of debt, is being extended to December 31, 1994.
The revitalization of our manufacturing industry is of a high priority and this process will be helped by the introduction of an investment tax credit on the purchase of machinery and equipment. This two-year program will lower cost and promote investment in modernization and technology. Farge amounts of capital from Canadians in all walks of life are presently held in RRSPs and RRIFs. In order to direct some of these funds to investment in small businesses the rules for self-directed RRSPs and RRIFs are being simplified together with the reporting requirements of trustees of these types of plans. The simplified regulations should result in an increased flow of capital to small businesses which is what the hon. member is looking for.
December 3, 1992

The statement gives recognition to the importance of technology today by improving and simplifying R and D rules for small businesses. These will eliminate confusion and uncertainty among business persons and allow them to proceed with projects knowing that their expenditures do indeed qualify for tax credits and other benefits.
We will be mentioning in passing other initiatives in the economic statement designed to help small business continue in its vital role, improvements to the industrial research program, a reduction of the regulatory burden and a holiday from unemployment insurance premiums for new employees of small businesses.

Mr. Speaker, I am here concerning my question of May 22 of this year regarding the Westray mine.
I asked the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism about the safety of this mine and all we got were vague generalities. I want to know, and the people of Nova Scotia and Canada want to know, about the role of the government, particularly his and that of the Prime Minister regarding the safety of this mine.
In his response to my supplementary: "What the Prime Minister was talking about is that this is over all an economic or business decision for the Government of Canada and not a safety decision; in fact, the Devco report of 1987 emphasized almost entirely nothing but business questions. That is what he was talking about".
The Devco report did relate to safety decisions. The government supposedly, with the statements of the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism, had independent inquiries coming from experts on the safety of the Westray mine. The fact is that the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources was concerned with safety.
The problem is that nothing was acted upon regarding safety. In fact the minister of energy would not even answer a question in this House that was put to him on the question of safety.
Adjournment Debate
The fact of the matter is that we in Atlantic Canada are in a desperate economic situation but not desperate enough to forego the safety factors on job opportunities. The people of Pictou county are no exception. The people want to work. It is not a question, as my colleague from Cape Breton-East Richmond and I have stated, of Cape Bretoners feeling that Pictou county coal was going to be a competition. The question is the safety of people.
In fact in Cape Breton right now we have had a very serious problem with regard to flooding of the Lingan mine, to the extent that the Lingan mine has now been closed four months ahead of schedule. It has also put at risk the Lingan-Phalen mine which employs another 700 people and is the sole source right now of metallurgical coal that is blended with the higher sulphur coal that gives the Cape Breton Development Corporation coal its readily accessible markets.
The problem, of course, is if we lose the Lingan-Phalen mine, then Devco and industrial Cape Breton is in even more of a difficult situation.
The fact of the matter is management at Devco closed Lingan-Phalen until they could be absolutely sure there was not going to be any flooding. That will be closed for months and it will mean severe economic hardship. The fact is the safety of the people came first.
We want to know what safety factors were not considered by this government. We want to know what fell down, who fell down, in this regard. It is not a big question. We want some answers and the fact is we are not getting them. The most incredible thing relating to the inquiry set up by the province of Nova Scotia into this terrible disaster was that the wording of the inquiry was found to contravene the rights of the officers of the Curragh Resources to be able to get a fair hearing in a criminal action.
It is almost impossible to believe that the province of Nova Scotia, the Attorney General, the whole Department of the Attorney General, would not know how to word an inquiry so it would not run foul of that concern, particularly when it had the precedent from Ontario just a few years before. There is a lot of skulduggery here. We were not allowed to have this heard in the standing committee on industry. The families are agonizing over

December 3, 1992
Adjournment Debate
unanswered questions and I feel it is only fair that the government do more to provide those answers.

speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity today to clear up the hon. member's confusion surrounding the reports of the independent mining consultants regarding the development of the Westray mine.
As the responsible minister said in this House on many occasions, reputable independent mining consultants were engaged by the lender to ensure that the mine was in compliance with provincial regulations. As guarantor of the loan to Westray, we reviewed these reports in order to ensure that the interests of the Canadian taxpayer were safeguarded.
According to the report submitted by Associated Mining Consultants Incorporated, at no time was the Westray mine not in full compliance with the regulations governing mining operations in the province of Nova Scotia.
The government has released thousands of pages of documentation relating to this file and has answered fully literally dozens of questions in the House in this regard. Given this fact, it is understandable that the hon. member might have misunderstood various responses to certain questions, but I can assure him that at no time did the government offer conflicting information as indicated by the hon. member in his question of May 22,
1992.

Mr. Speaker, on June 8 I asked the Minister of Justice to extend the mandate of the Canadian Human Rights Commission in order to enforce employment equity under the Canada Public Service Act as well as within federal agencies. I expressed concerns that victims of racism and discrimination often have to wait two to three years-in the case of Chander Grover I think it has been six years-to have their cases dealt with because of inadequate resources.
The minister in response to my question refused to even recognize that there was a problem.
The Canadian Human Rights Commission needs adequate funding to deal with both systemic discrimination as well as individual complaints. Because of inadequate resources, as I said, complainants often have to wait far
too long to have their cases processed. Yet instead of increasing funding, this year $347,000 was cut from the commission's budget.
In addition, termination of the Court Challenges Program by the federal government in the last budget was another serious blow to equality rights for women and minorities. This means that disadvantaged persons no longer have legal funds for test cases and equality cases under the charter, cases that are so important in interpreting and sometimes in changing our laws.
We also found in that budget that the government refused absolutely to fund a race relations foundation which had been promised as part of redress for Japanese Canadians. This was another betrayal.
This week we learn that advocacy groups have had 10 per cent per year cuts in their grants under the mini budget. These groups are essential to fight for disadvantaged and powerless Canadians. This 10 per cent per year cut has to be added to very dramatic cuts they have had that have accumulated over the last three years. In some cases it must bring it up to 60 per cent or 70 per cent cuts which essentially will destroy many very important organizations.
I am ashamed that our government as an employer itself practises systemic discrimination. It has not increased the hiring of visible minorities over the past four years. The 3.6 per cent participation rate in the Public Service compares very poorly with 7 per cent racial minorities in the general work force.
In June the minister told us the review of the Employment Equity Act would provide a better context for understanding what needs to be done, but nothing has been done. The parliamentary committee asked for direct enforcement by the Human Rights Commission and the commissioner himself has for years advocated several reforms in this direction.
By the year 2001, 80 per cent of new entrants into the labour force in Canada will be women, visible minorities, aboriginals and persons with disabilities. Canada must protect their rights to equality and must open opportunities for their advancement. The government must act now to renew and review the Canadian Human Rights Commission and amend the Canadian Human Rights Act so that we can achieve real equality in Canada.
December 3, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not agree with the comments of the hon. member.
First of all, the Employment Equity Act was reviewed over the past several months by a special committee of Parliament chaired by the hon. member for Don Valley East. That report has been tabled in Parliament and the government is having a look at it. We have 150 days in which to respond to the committee's report.
The Minister of State for Employment and Immigration is also examining the report in consultation with the Minister of Justice and other interested ministers, and the role of the Canadian Human Rights Commission is obviously an issue that is being considered fully.
I should point out to the House that the Government of Canada itself has had employment programs and in fact considerable progress has been made.
You have heard, Mr. Speaker, that somehow the Canadian Human Rights Commission has not been getting any money but in fact I point out that since the fiscal year 1987-88 the budget of the Canadian Human Rights Commission has increased by 66 per cent as well as a 27 per cent increase in person-year allotment. There are a lot of government departments that would like to have had that in the last five years. The hon. member should point that out.
The Canadian Human Rights Commission is independent of the government. The commission is responsible for the enforcement and administration of the Canadian Human Rights Act. The way in which it administers the act and allocates its resources is a matter which the commission must decide. However, I understand the commission has taken a number of steps to speed up the processing and resolution of complaints.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on November 25 I put a question to the minister responsible for small business concerning the Westray coal disaster. At that time I called on the government to conduct a federal inquiry into matters surrounding that particular place of operation. Unfortu-
Adjournment Debate
nately the government has not seen fit to instruct its officials to hold a parliamentary inquiry.
I want to remind the parliamentary secretary to the minister responsible that this is one of the most serious and tragic events that has happened in the history of Nova Scotia and for this federal government to turn its face away from the people and particularly the widows and family members of those deceased miners is despicable.
The Auditor General pointed out in his report that only $9.9 million in fees were paid to the management. Not a bad day's pay. The government gave a guarantee of 103 per cent of pre-production costs. That is what the Westray promoters got. Not a bad day at all for them.
I want to remind the parliamentary secretary again that the people of Canada, the people of Pictou county and the people of Nova Scotia deserve as a minimum a parliamentary inquiry to discover all of the facts surrounding this tragic event.
It is not sufficient for the government to say that it will let the province do it because we know what the province of Nova Scotia under the leadership of Donald Cameron has done with that particular issue. We know about the safety concerns at this particular mine which is regulated by the province of Nova Scotia. It is an absolute and utter disgrace, as the charges which have been evidenced to date will indicate.'
I want to remind the parliamentary secretary that in my own district as of today the Lingan colliery has shut down and the Phalen colliery is shut down. For many safety reasons I would advise workers not to go back to the Phalen mine. In point of fact on Saturday of this week I will be meeting with mining representatives to discuss that very issue.
On the Westray issue this government was drunk with stupidity, falling over itself to provide money, $9.9 million in management fees to the promoters, 103 per cent loan guarantee on pre-production costs.
It would be appropriate and morally responsible for the Government of Canada to conduct a parliamentary inquiry in order to give the officials that the government has been protecting for the last number of months an opportunity to come forward, put their case before the Canadian people and account for their omissions or,

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
indeed, have them account for the nice little goose egg they made with the Tory administration in Ottawa.
The parliamentary secretary, whom I know to be a respectable man in this Chamber, should urge his ministers and his colleagues to have the appropriate committee examine in detail all of the information which is there for everyone to see, except the people of Canada who do not have an opportunity to question those in authority.
I urge the parliamentary secretary to do that on behalf of the people in Pictou county who are calling upon the Prime Minister and the government to order a parliamentary inquiry.

speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have been asked to respond to the suggestion made in the Auditor General's report and also by the hon. member that the government provided assistance to Westray that amounted to 103 per cent of the net pre-production costs.
The company was required to provide $15 million in cash during the pre-production period, plus share in the loan insurance risk, with possible tax benefit credits, principally in future years. The total financing by Cur-ragh totalled $30 million, consisting of $9 million in cash, $6 million in deferred management fees, and $15 million which represents 15 per cent of the bank loan guarantee. They were also fully responsible for any cost overruns that occurred.
The Auditor General's report offsets the $30 million of company financing with $34.2 million of potential tax benefits. It could be easy to misinterpret the manner in which the potential tax benefits are reported without also realizing that tax benefits are potential and are realized only if there are profits against which they can be applied.
In this instance these benefits did not all materialize as Curragh suffered losses subsequent to the start-up of the Westray mine.
The Auditor General's exhibit 13-7 does not represent actual cash flow or actual costs but simply what might have occurred had Curragh been more profitable than it was and had been able to take advantage of the tax concessions. In actual fact all of the tax concessions were
not available to Curragh and the Westray mine is reported to have cost Curragh in excess of $28.5 million.
One must realize that the purpose of loan insurance is to encourage financial institutions to loan money to projects which, by their nature, would not normally be financed by these institutions or only at extremely high rates of interest. We were satisfied that Curragh shared a significant portion of the risk as demonstrated by the size of their reported loss on this project.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to say I am delighted to rise in this debate, but I am afraid that would not be true. I am inured to rise in this debate because of what the government perpetrated upon the people of Canada yesterday. I am most particularly upset, as are the vast majority of women in this country, with regard to one particular aspect of yesterday's so-called economic statement.
Others more eloquent than I have talked about the attack by this government on the unemployed but I want to talk particularly about the attack on women in this country. I refer of course to the utterly despicable decision by this government to refuse unemployment insurance benefits to people who quit their jobs volun-
December 3, 1992

tarily. This isolates thousands of women, possibly more than thousands in this country, who will quit their jobs because of sexual harassment.
I had a lot of things thrown at me in this Chamber today but I heard ministers of the Crown stand and say: "Nothing to worry about. Sexual harassment will be just cause". Well let me explain the concept of just cause within the concept of the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board and within the concept of the woman applying for benefits after she has quit her job because she has been sexually harassed.
First of all let us look at the process and the time. I am giving you times that are 8 to 12 years old because I chaired the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board from 1980 to 1984. My knowledge of time spans comes from that time. I can only say if those time spans have not lengthened considerably then it is the only place within the entire legal system where they have not.
What happens? I will tell you what happens. A woman leaves her job because sexual harassment is intolerable and unbearable. She does the standard thing and goes to the employment office with her documents to apply for unemployment insurance. She explains she quit her job because of sexual harassment. Without fail, in my experience and in the experience of my colleagues knowledgeable in this area, she will be disqualified. Under the old rules that meant she bore a penalty period of approximately eight weeks. For most women then, in spite of the penalty period that was enforced, there was the knowledge the remainder of the claim would be available. Many of them would bring forward an appeal to the Unemployment Insurance Appeal Board. Some of them, having lost there, would then take the appeal to the umpire, a judge of the Federal Court.
I will quote my colleague, the member for Gander-Grand Falls, who is one of the most knowledgeable people in this House when it comes to representing his constituents before Unemployment Insurance Appeal Boards. In Newfoundland you would be looking at about eight weeks from disqualification to appeal. You would be looking at at least another week to knowledge of the decision on your appeal board but you could be looking at as long as two years before the Federal Court judge came to Newfoundland to hear the appeals from the
Government Orders
decisions of the appeal board. By that time who would care? What would have become of the person who had been disqualified?
As I say, under the old rules a woman in that position could at least look forward to the remainder of her claim. Now she can look forward to nothing.
I heard over and over again sexual harassment is just cause. Well it certainly is, but little has been shown by this government that it believes it.
I rose three times in this House last week and once this week on different issues of sexual harassment. There are two women from the Public Service in Halifax who are currently at home collecting UI benefits. They are lucky they are still under the old rules. The Public Service of Canada in two separate investigations found sexual harassment against these two women yet they are at home without jobs, collecting UI benefits. Their harasses who are known to the Public Service Commission are in their jobs. According to a report someone in that very office is highly amused the member of Parliament for Halifax has brought forward this complaint and these women have gone public in the press. I promise that sometime before I die people will be laughing from the other sides of their faces.
There are other incidents of sexual harassment in the Public Service of Canada. I have an incident of a woman who was at managerial level in another Public Service branch who is also at home collecting unemployment insurance benefits because she dared to complain.
I have another incident of a woman who was on contract and was told by a minister of this very House the report she made would not be left on her file. She is also currently unemployed.
We have a report from the advisory body on the status of women to the Associate Minister of National Defence that was published last week. I raised it in the House yesterday and it says: "The Armed Forces of Canada: Complaints rise from every base in this country on sexual harassment".
Does this sound like a government that has a policy that would consider sexual harassment just cause for leaving your employment? If it does to you, Mr. Speaker, I can only say it does not to the women of Canada, and the women of Canada are upset.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
We are not going to sit back and allow a whole series of Anita Hills to be pilloried in this country the way they were in the United States. This makes us angry and it is not just women parliamentarians, women lawyers and those of us who have a voice and an arena in which to speak who are angry. It is women across the board in this country. It is store clerks, secretaries, clerks in government departments, people all over the place who work for low wages and have glass ceilings keeping them from advancement. They are angry and they have a right to be angry.
This government has changed the rules in UI so if these women are sexually harassed and quit their jobs they have to prove their cases. They are going to have to hire lawyers to do it. I would like to know where the government, and in particular the Minister of Employment and Immigration, thinks they are going to get the money to do this. By accidents of birth, education, and personality a number of us can combat this kind of behaviour and cut it off where it deserves to be cut off.
The woman who can barely afford bus fare, to quote one of my hon. colleagues in the other place this afternoon, does not have that luxury. She does not have that kind of money. In this economy where this government has cut so much to so many groups, there is not a legal aid office that can afford to take on cases like that.
I know my hon. colleague, the member for Cape Breton-East Richmond and our critic for justice, knows that as well. Legal aid lawyers are too busy with security of the person cases to have time to represent these.
Not all members of Parliament are committed as the member for Gander-Grand Falls to representing constituents in these situations.
What happens to these women? I will tell you what happens to them. They quit their jobs. They do not have the money for legal representation. They know the "cubs" as they are called, which are the reports of the umpire, show unequivocally that sexual harassment has not been found to be just cause. So what happens to these women? They go on welfare. They go on social assistance. They walk away because they cannot sacrifice what little money they have for lawyers' fees and they do not have enough to cover them anyway. There is no legal aid and there sure is no recourse from their government
in Ottawa. The government in Ottawa, through its senior public servants, its minions, the supposed personnel officers for this government, says sexual harassment complaints are childish. They say sexual harassment is something women have to learn to live with. We will not and we are not going to put up with it.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise this evening to support the important and progressive economic program tabled yesterday by my colleague, the Minister of Finance. I will talk more specifically about the measures in this program that deal with transport.
Over all, the measures that were announced will significantly affect every Canadian. Some have said that it is strong medicine and too extreme. Based on my own experience as a businessman and a politician at the municipal and federal levels I can only applaud the strategy developed by my colleague to reduce expenses and, at the same time, to apply the economic stimulus that is so necessary to our country in the present circumstances.

Transportation cannot be immune from such a balancing exercise. Belt tightening has to be shared by all Canadians.
As the Minister of Finance said in his statement, the government will commit $500 million in new federal spending during the next two years to a strategic investment program. I am pleased to note a considerable portion of these funds has been earmarked for transportation infrastructure.
The federal initiative comprises two parts. First, the federal government will invest up to $255 million in federally owned highway infrastructure which is key to economic development. Among other things funds will be allocated to the maintenance of the federal bridges in Montreal, namely the Champlain and Jacques Cartier bridges. These bridges have reached their full capacity and handle some 80 million vehicles a year. At this rate the rapidity with which these bridge facilities are deteriorating cannot be overstated. Given their strategic importance for the Montreal region as major national and
December 3, 1992

international arteries, it is our responsibility to ensure these links are maintained in safe and usable conditions.

A second important federal intervention concerns the Trans-Canada Highway in the national parks located in Newfoundland, Alberta and British Columbia. More than 200 kilometres of the Trans-Canada Highway belong to the federal government and major sections of that highway no longer meet safety standards.
Provincial highways have aged in spite of the efforts made by provinces. If we want to meet present needs and promote economic growth for tomorrow it is essential to do these repairs and to expand our whole highway system. Without interfering in provincial jurisdiction the federal government has now announced its intention to invest jointly with the provinces in some provincial road projects that are national priorities in terms of security and economic growth.
Consequently, the federal government will invest over $400 million in upgrading provincial highways across the country. We believe that the provinces will be pleased with this unprecedented federal effort and will participate with us in implementing this ambitious highway investment program. We will very soon discuss with the provinces the specific projects to be undertaken as well as the provinces' financial involvement. We hope that construction can begin as early as next spring thus speeding the economic recovery. It is estimated that these projects will generate approximately 11,000 person-years of employment over the next five years.

In addition to upgrading existing highways and bridges it is also time to begin the construction of new strategic infrastructures. Consequently the federal government will commit to the construction of a fixed crossing to P.E.I. provided the province agrees to recognize the facility meets Canada's constitutional obligations to the province. To demonstrate this commitment the government will allow advanced engineering and environmental work to proceed.
Assuming provincial agreements and successful negotiations with the private developer, project construction could begin next spring. The project is expected to generate up to 3,500 person- years of employment over a
Government Orders
five-year construction period. Roughly 70 per cent of the estimated $800 million to $900 million project cost will be spent in Atlantic Canada.
Surface transportation has many interdependent links. For an integrated approach it is vital we ensure improvements are undertaken which strengthen the transportation system as a whole.
At this time I am pleased to be able to inform this House of developments in two other areas of transport activity. On the port side, Canada Ports Corporation has a key role to play in ensuring that our ports make the necessary key commercial investments needed to meet the competitive challenge of global markets.
I understand that Canada Ports Corporation has given high priority consideration to strategic capital investments in a number of areas, including a major new container facility for the port of Vancouver at Roberts Bank and an expansion of existing container facilities, as well as rail network improvements, in the port of Montreal.
The government will be exploring similar non-budget financing opportunities in other areas as further strategic infrastructure projects with clear and direct commercial potential are identified.
On the rail side the government is prepared to make available new funding for the development of a more efficient rail system in high-traffic areas. Works will include new grade separations and other improvements with high safety and efficiency pay-offs.
Let me now turn to another vital element of our transportation infrastructure, namely our airports. The initiative provides for airport capital projects based on commercial arrangements, arrangements which will not require new government spending.
Airports in particular can make a strong contribution to the economic life of their communities as independent commercial entities. The transfer of a number of federal airports to local operating authorities with independent financing capabilities is already facilitating productive new investments such as the development of a major new runway facility for Vancouver.
Similarly, pending consideration of the report of the environmental panel, it is anticipated that any new runways at Pearson International will be constructed and funded on the basis of a commercial approach. The

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
importance of Pearson cannot be overstated. The airport now generates more than 56,000 direct and indirect jobs, which in turn generate $1.9 billion a year in personal income and $4 billion in direct revenue for local businesses and the tourist industry.
Modem facilities at Pearson are vital to the economic and social development of metropolitan Toronto, southern Ontario and all of Canada. In the case of terminal 3 it was the first time that government asked the private sector to provide a terminal building and operate it without government funding. The opening of terminal 3 in early 1991 and the improvements completed to terminal 2 in 1990 provided the additional terminal capacity to meet the short-term needs of Pearson Airport.
The government is committed to expanding Pearson's terminal capacity to provide better service to an increasing number of users. Development must however proceed in a responsible manner within established guidelines.

Members know very well that the environment is changing for all airline companies of the world and Canada is no exception. Our two main carriers have undertaken an organizational realignment in order to try to meet the challenge they are faced with.
Last March the government issued a request for proposals for the retrofitting and operation of terminals 1 and 2 at Pearson airport.
As the Minister of Finance said, we are ready to launch the project for terminals 1 and 2 in Toronto if we can get private funding. The project will be carried out in such a way as not to disturb these companies in their efforts to remain cost-effective. It should allow for the creation of 2,000 to 3,000 jobs each year during construction. I will be in a position to give you more information on this initiative in the near future.

During the next five years I envisage an expenditure of up to $20 million on airports north of 60. In our modern technological age the concept of infrastructure embraces more than roads, bridges and runways. High technology infrastructure has an important place in our modern transportation system.
For example International Civil Aviation is moving to microwave landing systems as the standard for instrument landing with a 1998 target for implementation. Therefore, there is a need to prepare Canadian airports for this development.
In the context of this initiative the money we are allocating to the MLS project will allow for an early start in applying the latest technology to air navigation.
MLS provides an opportunity for development of advanced technology within Canada which will both answer our own immediate operational needs and give us a product with considerable export potential.
This key economic sector will also gain from many of the other initiatives announced by my hon. colleague in his statement.
In the coming weeks we will be working diligently to finalize agreements with our partners in the various components of this initiative and we will commence work as soon as it is feasible to do so.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
I am not particularly happy to participate in this debate today on the Minister of Finance's economic statement that he delivered before the House yesterday. I say that because I think it was one of the saddest documents I have had the misfortune to listen to and read in this Chamber. However, do not just take my word for it.
The Minister of Finance today was quoting various articles from the Toronto Star to reinforce his arguments in response to questions during Question Period. I would like bring to the House's attention Carol Goar's article in today's Toronto Star. It is headlined: "A brazen attack on the weakest". That headline is referring to the minister's economic statement of yesterday. In the first paragraph she writes:
A government that would cut unemployment insurance benefits at a time like this is not just heartless. It is dangerously out of touch with the people it purports to serve.
By reaching into the pockets of the unemployed yesterday, finance minister Don Mazankowski transformed a mid-course economic correction into a brazen attack on the nation's most vulnerable citizens.
Many speakers on this side of the House have drawn attention to the absolute unfairness of the economic statement which was in fact a budget for the next fiscal year. It is not surprising that a Conservative government that still holds to the old ideology of the trickle-down theory of economics, that if we make it richer for the people at the top they will spend money and invest
December 3, 1992

money and it will somehow trickle down to the middle and lower income groups, a government that still adheres to that kind of economic philosophy is so out of whack, so out of date with the present reality that it no longer deserves to hold power in this country and to be in government.
After all the Americans discovered in the past year or two just how Reaganomics had destroyed their economy over the previous 10 years and they took action. They took action the democratic way and threw out a Republican conservative president of their country. That is exactly what the people of this country are going to do in the next seven or eight months when this government gets up enough nerve to call an election.
In the limited time that I have this evening I want to zero in on two aspects of that budget. The first aspect concerns the changes to the unemployment insurance system.
I do not know why the Minister of Finance would pick the weakest in our economy, the weakest in our society, to fight the deficit on. I really do not understand it. These are the people who are unemployed. These are the people who have been in and out of work for the past two or three years. Some of them have been out of work completely for the last two or three years. Yet this is the group the Conservative government of the day has targeted, on whose backs it has decided to fight the deficit and the debt.
The measures taken by the government are nothing short of Draconian. I do not think there is any question about that.
The initiative says that those who quit their jobs without just cause and those fired for insubordination will simply not get unemployment insurance benefits, period. I did not think that I would be in this Chamber long enough to witness any government taking that kind of extreme and unfair action, particularly at a time of severe economic depression in this country.
Who says, for example, what a just cause is? How do we know whether the applicant quit because he or she did not care or because he or she was working for an
Government Orders
abusive boss? These tribunals, this appeal process, is really not a court process.
They are not the rules of evidence. They are not the protections for those who are innocent. I suggest that when some of these cases get to the umpire, and the backlog builds up year after year after year, that these tribunals will be emotionally charged to the point where I doubt very much whether natural justice will have its day in court.
I suggest that the Minister of Finance go back to the blueprint, go back to his drawing board, and in the name of decency withdraw that Draconian measure which he introduced yesterday in his budget.
Whose decision will it be to say whether the applicant had a reason to quit? Is it the employer's word against the applicant's? If that is the case we all know whose side this government will be on.
What about workers who quit because they are breathing in toxic fumes and the company refuses to clean up its act? What about the woman who is forced to quit her job because her husband gets a transfer to another city? Is that going to be considered just cause? After all she has paid into unemployment insurance for many months, or many years in most cases. Should she be deprived of benefits simply because, through no fault of her own, she has to quit and remove herself to another city or another province?
Does anyone on the government side really appreciate just how long these appeals take? Can the House imagine an employee going to his employer and saying: "I am not working in that paint shop another minute. It is killing me. The toxic fumes are so intense I cannot breathe". Can the House imagine how long an environmental investigation assessment would take? It would take not weeks or months but possibly two or three years.
In the meantime the employee could be adjudicated as having not exercised just cause in quitting his job and therefore be denied unemployment insurance because the tribunal at that point, or the umpire, would not have the scientific evidence at its disposal in order to come to a decision in favour of the employee who has quit.
This is extremely unfair. It is going to open the whole process to even more abuse, this time particularly on the part of the employers. If we are talking about sexual harassment-and the hon. member for Halifax went into a great deal of detail in her remarks, and I agreed with everything she said-it is going to be extremely unfair to

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
women who are victims of sexual harassment, not necessarily physical harassment but verbal harassment. How do people prove that unless they walk around with some kind of a concealed microphone or tape recorder on their person? Do members see how this is going to bring so much tension, strife and conflict within the work place?
The government is reducing its costs of unemployment insurance but little does it realize that by withdrawing money or reducing money within the unemployment insurance envelope it is actually going to hurt small business in an economic downturn, in a severe recession.
In my riding of Brant there are many small businesses, small retail shops, which without welfare cheques from their customers and without unemployment insurance cheques from their customers would not make it during a recession. A lot of them do not want to admit it but it is the absolute truth. When people receive unemployment insurance they do not take that money and sock it into some luxury condominium in the Cayman Islands. They spend all that money and they spend it at home. They spend it on groceries, clothes, gasoline, car repairs, you name it. It goes directly back into the local economy.
Cutting back $550 million in unemployment insurance benefits means that there is so much less money to go back into the local economies across this country.
In cutting back on unemployment insurance, in tackling the poor in this country, the disadvantaged and the unemployed I noticed that the Minister of Finance once again very conveniently side-stepped the big issue of taxing family trusts. There is over $50 billion in family trusts, controlled by fewer than 100 families, in this country. It will now go untaxed for another 50 or 75 years until the last child living today dies. That could be 80 years. It is estimated that there will be accumulated tax losses of close to $ 100 billion over the next 50 to 75 years.
Even in one year alone, if those family trusts were taxed-and I am talking now about the Westons, the Bronfmans, the very wealthy people in this country-it is estimated that we could get $35 billion in taxes-billions of dollars, not millions-from that source. These people
would be forced to pay their fair share of taxes. That is equal to one year's annual budgetary deficit.
That is how serious this government is about making the tax system fair in this country. It is an absolute shame that this government allows the very rich and powerful in this country to get away without paying their fair share of taxes. At the same time it goes after those on unemployment insurance to cut back on their benefits. In my view, this government ha's become an absolute national disgrace.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to address members tonight concerning the economic statement recently brought down in the House of Commons.
The theme of investing in growth, investing in people, investing in our infrastructure are the themes I have heard in my own community of Scarborough Centre.
Scarborough Centre is a riding in metropolitan Toronto which has many small businesses. The heart and soul of every community and, indeed, the Canadian economy, is small business.
When businesses expand communities prosper and the Canadian economy grows. Businesses with 50 or fewer employees account for about 45 per cent of private sector employment in Canada. They have been responsible for most private sector job creation in recent years.
Between 1979 and 1990 small business has created more than two million new full-time jobs for Canadians. This is more than 80 per cent of the total jobs it created during that period. I am veiy proud of the vibrant small businesses we have in Scarborough Centre.
A business, however, is more than just a business to those who start it. It is a symbol of pride and fulfilment of a lifelong dream, the fruition of an idea, the result of tireless hard work and determination to make that idea come to life. The Government of Canada is working very hard to preserve and foster this sense of pride and to keep the dreams of every small business person alive in Canada.
December 3, 1992

Yesterday in the House of Commons my hon. colleague, the Minister of Finance, set out a plan to encourage the creation of more small businesses in Canada and the retention of existing ones.
The RRSP home buyers plan has been extended by another year and the Small Business Financing Program by another two years. He also introduced a one-year 10 per cent small business investment tax credit for purchases of machinery and equipment. That is going to be very good news indeed for Scarborough Centre and all of metro Toronto.
As well, he outlined plans to provide most new and existing small businesses in Canada with relief in the area of unemployment insurance premiums for 1993.
To encourage small businesses to expand and to hire new employees the government will, in effect, pay any increase in unemployment insurance employer premiums over the 1990 levels up to a maximum of $30,000. Therefore, any incorporated or unincorporated businesses whose employer's share of unemployment insurance premiums in 1992 was less than $60,000 will be eligible to benefit under this program.
These innovative measures will allow small and medium-sized businesses in Canada to continue to grow, to modernize, to create jobs in communities across this great nation of ours.
I know the benefits to a community of a prosperous local business sector. In my own community of Scarborough there are numerous examples of small businesses that are doing well. Some small businesses have now grown to medium and large-sized ones.
When it comes to unemployment insurance, we have talked to our constituents across Canada and we have heard of the costly abuses of unemployment insurance. We can all cite examples. That is why a very important aspect of this economic statement has been incorporated to deal with these abuses.
It was announced that some persons who voluntarily quit their jobs without just cause or who lose their jobs because of their own misconduct will not be eligible for unemployment insurance.
Let me hasten to say that just cause has already been defined as reasons of health, safety concerns, transfer of a spouse to another region of the country, and harassment. I feel confident those abuses which have taken
Government Orders
place will indeed be curtailed because of the inclusion of this just cause provision in this economic statement.
Now let me turn to the environmental aspects of the statement. Many companies in Scarborough and across Canada have demonstrated a commitment to the production of environmentally friendly products and environmentally sensitive production processes. This is very important since the environment is one of Canada's and the world's fastest growing industries.
Yesterday's economic statement has in no way reduced our government's commitment to protecting Canada's environment.
Although the green plan's budget has been reduced, funding for green plan initiatives will continue to grow significantly on a year to year basis at a time when expenditures on most programs will decline or be frozen. In fact, spending under our green plan program will continue to increase by some 30 per cent each year in the next three years.
As well, there is very good news for our national parks. In British Columbia and Alberta the national parks and roads will be improved as will the national park in Newfoundland. That will improve safety and make it far more accessible for visitors in our magnificent national parks.
The green plan's budget however should not be taken as a measure of its success or its failure, not the budget alone. The green plan's mandate is to improve decision making and decision-making processes and to change people's attitudes relating to the environment. Its accomplishments can only be judged by its ability to achieve its all-important goals, and this goes to the heart of the green plan and what it is all about.
There is good news concerning the expansion of environmental industries. The world market for environmental products in 1990 was approximately $200 billion U.S. By the year 2000 it is expected to grow to some $375 billion U.S. currency.
In Canada the market for environmental products is estimated to be some $7 billion. This $7 billion of environmental industries creates another $13 billion in indirect economic activity for a total of over $20 billion.
Some 150,000 Canadians work in this rapidly growing sector of our economy. It is growing steadily and is the real growth industry in Canada. I am so very proud to hear about the number of students enrolled in those environmental studies in order to go into these indus-

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
tries, to begin new industries, begin those new businesses that are being talked about in this economic statement.
Our government also believes that one of the keys to economic prosperity for Canada is the reduction of Canada's national debt. The hon. finance minister's economic statement yesterday reflects this position.
Individually and collectively, it is incumbent on us to curtail further deficit increases. Debt load leaves countries vulnerable. It is money which cannot be used to help our small businesses or develop our economy.
Our government has reversed the Government of Canada's operating deficit of some $16 billion in 1984 to an operating surplus. This economic statement further assists in this respect.
All Canadians have a responsibility to do their part in helping to reduce our country's burden of debt. That is why I fully support my colleagues announcement of a two-year freeze in the salaries of the Governor General, the Lieutenant-Governor, the Prime Minister, all ministers and indeed, each of us in the House of Commons, as well as on salaries of the public servants of the Crown.
The measures announced by my colleague yesterday in his economic statement demonstrate the Government of Canada's commitment to fostering the success of small businesses in communities throughout this magnificent country of ours.
As well, it sends a positive message to all Canadians. It is a message that this government is serious about fostering the entrepreneurial spirit of Canada's small business men and women.
This government is serious about preserving the heart and soul of the Canadian economy, the small business sector, in order that our children and indeed our grandchildren will have opportunities and will be the beneficiaries of our responsible actions and decisions.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it gives me a great deal of pleasure to speak on the economic statement delivered yesterday by the Minister of Finance.
I have quite a few concerns about the economic statement. I will relate them to the Minister of Finance who is in the House. I appreciate his presence. First of all, because he is here, I have to give credit where credit is due.
For a long time we have been trying to promote an industry on Cape Breton Island that made microwave landing systems. I have spoken to the Minister of Finance on this in the past. He has been very supportive to the extent that the government has awarded a contract to this company.
It is going to be of tremendous importance to my riding which has terrible unemployment. Not only that, but it is also going to enable us to get away from the older stereotyped industries of coal and steel. It will get us into a technological type of industry in which Cape Bretoners can develop a track record. They will be able to get the news of this track record across the country and thereby attract other important sophisticated research and development and technological industries to my riding.
There will be those who say: "Well, he really did not do anything. The government really did not do anything. This contract was announced awhile ago". But with the cost cutting, with the concern we have had on reduction, there has been this problem hanging over our heads that this contract was going to disappear. In fact the Minister of Transport, who is in the House, will know that this was scratched from the list as recently as August but put back on for which I am very grateful. Now we have it secured. That is tremendously important.
I also want to say to the Minister of Transport and the Minister of Finance and indeed to the government that our problems do not end in Cape Breton. There is the problem of what we are to do, how we are to employ those coming out of the steel plants and the mines having lost their jobs over the last number of years. We have an unemployment rate of about 30 per cent. It is really difficult. There are no easy answers and I recognize that.
I also want to say that twinning of highways is not an answer for Cape Breton. Going from Halifax to Sydney there is a good deal of traffic between Halifax and New Glasgow. Then after New Glasgow and Antigonish, the traffic reduces somewhat. It reduces even more getting to the Strait of Canso. Then when one gets to Cape Breton, the traffic is drastically reduced. When you get on to Cape Breton Island, not only is the traffic drastical-
December 3, 1992

ly reduced but there are two roads from the causeway to Sydney. There are twice the number of ways for you to get from the Strait of Canso to Sydney. We really do not need highways. But we do need help. We need help with infrastructure because unemployment and welfare has drained our municipalities something fierce.
We have had increased welfare costs in some of our communities of as much as 300 per cent. They cannot repair the infrastructure. They just cannot do it. The money is not there. Through the catch-22 situation that exists, we have to be able to upgrade our communities to make them attractive. Although we were starting to attract, hopefully, the nucleus of new technology, we want to have people who want to live in our communities. For that reason we do need a lot of help in that regard.
I am very pleased there is assistance for the parks in western Canada. Having travelled in western Canada, the national parks in that part of the country are absolutely gorgeous. They are a national treasure and should be upgraded and maintained. The federal government has said that federal roads and roadworks in western Canada's national parks will be upgraded and I think that is very important.
I would also say that on Cape Breton we have the Cape Breton Highlands National Park which needs some help because it is the flagship, so to speak, of the tourist industry on Cape Breton Island. Not only Cape Breton Island benefits but the whole province benefits because it brings tourists through the province to the park. With some seed money we can develop that park to benefit the whole province of Nova Scotia. As well, we can give much-needed jobs to people who are having a very difficult winter mainly because of the problems we had last year in our tourist industry and the problems we are enduring through the fishing industry on Cape Breton Island.
I would ask the government, and particularly the Minister of Finance, if he would please consider this.
I would say too that it is important when you take things away. People in Canada understand that at times you have to tighten your belt, you have to reduce the benefits sometimes and the incomes that have been forwarded and provided to the people of Canada. But it is very important at the same time to give the people an
Government Orders
idea of where it is going to end, to develop a program that tells the people you are preparing to contribute to the reduction of your aspirations and benefits, but this will lead to a specific conclusion. We do not have that in this economic statement. We do not know where it is going to end.
The Minister of Finance mentioned that the net foreign debt is far higher for Canada than any other of the G-7 countries. He also said that Canadians paid more than $22 billion in interest last year to foreign lenders. These figures are alarming. The fact is that we have to be able to deal with that.
The Minister of Finance in his budget last year targeted the repatriation of foreign debt. I think it is very important for the Minister of Finance to tell us where we are going to go. His deficit expectations for this year were not met because the revenues were not as high as the government expected.
However, this question of foreign debt is vital, particularly when we are dependent upon the sale of our treasury bonds to be able to pay the interest on this debt as it occurs. So the treasury bonds are not being sold to Canadians; more and more they are being sold to foreigners, particularly to Americans, which is requiring us to keep our interest rates high to make those bonds attractive.
We also have to keep our dollar high so that we are not paying an increasing amount to foreign countries in currency exchange. I realize that. The fact of the matter is that we have to deal with it. The fact of the matter is that we have not dealt with it. People need to know, they have to be able to see where we are going. People do not want to see their benefits that they have worked so hard to obtain, the better standard of living we have, our health care programs, our increased allowance for pensions, eroded without any idea as to where it is going to end. That will only cause further dissatisfaction, further uncertainty, and a tremendous amount of fear. We have to know what the government's plans are for bringing this slide to a halt.
Certainly there may be fat in the system, but there are a lot of poor middle-income Canadians who do not have any fat to give to the government, that there is real need in this country which we cannot ignore. We cannot

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
continually take away from these people. We cannot take away from the regions.
Perhaps we can modify what we are going to give on a short-term basis. People have to know. If they do not know, then they cannot accept this. They just cannot see that it is ever going to end. They are going to see the work and the development over the last few years and the accumulated improvements in the standard of living gradually disappear at their expense.
That is not going to work, I am afraid, in areas of high unemployment where the government is not being forthcoming with a plan. We are going to have a great deal of dissension, a great deal of hardship and a great deal of unhappiness and lack of confidence in the system. I am afraid that we have to deal with this. We have to deal with the people in need. We have got to address where this country is going.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I was just talking to the Minister of Finance and I do not think that the members of my Mount Royal riding are going to be particularly happy, as I told him, with this budget.
I can only hope that the end result will in the long run somehow repair the dramatic damage that has been done to our country through the poor public policy and particularly the financial policies undertaken by this government.
As I stand here to speak for the constituents of Mount Royal, believe me it is not to applaud this government, but to address the failures as they have impacted on my own riding and the people who live there.
It is quite obvious that the new economic statement continues the faulty economic policies. Many of my constituents in Hampstead, Cote St. Luc, Snowdon, Cote des Neiges and the town of Mount Royal keep telling me that this government is simply out of touch with the real people and they have not addressed their concerns. There is nothing positive in a really constructive way in this budget that makes them feel comfortable and feel hopeful.
It does not matter what their background, what their economic status, the level of their education, their mother tongue, their country of origin, where they live in
my riding, whether it is in a home, whether it is in an apartment and in the worst case some in the street, this government has ceased really to represent their needs and this budget simply confirms it.
I am talking about Mount Royal riding's population of
90,000	that includes a significant immigrant population from the world over: the Caribbean, East Africa, East Asia, Europe, the Middle East, eastern Europe, South America, from seniors who I am always proud to say make up over 20 per cent of my riding to single parent families, two parent families, the under employed to the unemployed, are all anxious for a more stable economic future, yet gained little hope from yesterday's declaration by the Conservative government.
Do not lose hope is my message to them. Do not lose your spirit. I know that you walk through the streets in my riding and you see all those empty store windows and all those endless for rent signs. We say that M. A Louer owns an awful lot of property in Mount Royal.
Thousands of jobs have been lost under the government's policies, particularly in textile, in clothing, in the food processing industry, in small business and in sales and services. When you add the youth job losses because of the cuts this government has brought in, particularly this past summer under the federal youth employment programs, the problem gets even worse.
Let us consider the Adjustment Training Program. I had a large number of young people who were quite excited about being admitted for re-education and training, if you would care to put it that way, but then the government reneged in the middle of all this and cut their opportunity at the third term, in mid-stream. Many of them have lost hope. I say to all of them, do not lose hope. I know that you have been very unhappy with the government. Obviously Tories do not know how to look at this world through proper glasses. They use those rose-coloured glasses that are not answering the needs.
I see in the community centres I visit, at the line-ups at the food banks, the images of the tremendous social needs out there. Children are going to school hungry, yes, in Mount Royal riding. People are living in dwellings that need upgrading. Our youth need training and skills. Again in yesterday's budget, this government has failed to be the compassionate and caring government it would like to pretend it is.
December 3, 1992

The story of poverty in my riding might shock some members of this House. Thousands of people live below the poverty line, from the working poor to those on social assistance, from the single mothers to the single elderly who rely on sponsored, in-home health care, meals on wheels and the food bank because their needs exceed their means. Yet they too receive little hope from the Prime Minister's trickle-down budget and the made-in-Canada recession. We have had the wrong policies at the wrong time. We have the GST and free trade instead of freer trade which would be good for all of us. It is not "any deal at any price" but a proper deal, a fair deal that we as Liberals have always believed in.
One could lose hope, but do not. Go out and help a neighbour. Go out and work as a volunteer. Do something. Do not get depressed because I know that it could be depressing when you know that Montreal is the capital urban city of the unemployed in Canada. I worry about the one in five unemployed. Perhaps now it might fall to one in four, although not yet I think, of our population who is without a job.
I worry for those who need better skills to find jobs. I share the concern of parents whose children have grown, become well-educated and yet still cannot find work. I worry about the 70 per cent of English speaking students who have said that they plan to leave upon graduation from college and university. I say, stay. You will find the way despite this government.
What do we get from the Conservatives? "Stay the course," they say. "Watch the deficit," they say. "We just cannot afford to help any more," they say. I say in response, we cannot afford not to help. Luckily the people in this riding are strong willed and still hold out hope with or without the care or help or caring of a national government.
Conditions in the riding and across the country prove that we need a change of course and yesterday's economic statement was really the last straw. This government has failed to meet the historic Canadian test of compassion, fairness, balance, putting people first, of giving Canadians the tools they need to win, the economic competition and simply giving hope.
I fear that we have become a country of little more than balance sheets and deficits as the only priorities. We simply cannot ignore the human debt and deficit in the name of financial debt and deficits, for doing so means we give up the social priorities that made us the great
Government Orders
nation we are, that has made us different and has made us the envy of the world.
It is not too late to hold on to caring and compassion and, yes, competitive Canada. These are not mutually exclusive goals. In fact, they are inherently Canadian goals and they make sense for the country we wish to build, particularly when we hear the echo of that early Haida saying: "We have not inherited this land from our grandparents. We have simply borrowed it from our grandchildren".
In the last moments I would like to address the communications and cultural issues which are my responsibility in this House. Once again, Canada's arts and cultural community have felt the lash of the Tories. In their first economic statement in 1984 culture was cut by $122.5 million and in what we all hope is their last economic statement, there will be a further cut of $80 million over the next two years, this coming just two weeks after the sector suffered a 2 per cent blow to the tune of $11.8 million.
Let us for a moment look at this government's support to culture since 1984 when it took office. These numbers are based upon the government's own spending estimates. From 1984 to 1992 there has been a 24 per cent cut in direct and indirect federal cultural spending in real terms. This is a drastic, unconscionable cut, if we truly believe in nation building.
It is also interesting to compare the trends in cultural spending and the federal defence budget. Federal defence spending increased 38.6 per cent during the same period. The notion of a proud and independent Canada seems to have faded in the interest of the war games and war toys.
Culture is the very essence of our national identity and the bedrock of our national sovereignty and national pride. It gives meaning to the lives of every Canadian and enriches the country socially, politically and economically. It gives us pride in our country.
A cultural defence for Canada is what we need. As we look at what this government has done, as we look at the Auditor General's statement on some of the unnecessary spending that has gone on, I sincerely hope the government will stop and give priority where it counts, to people, to people and work, to people and the social world in which they live, and to people and the expres-

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
sion of culture, the ultimate expression of a country in this great world in which are privileged to live.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George -Bulkley Valley):
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to enter into the debate and discussion tonight on the finance minister's mini budget yesterday.
There was certainly a great deal of hype and anticipation, as there always is around a statement that a finance minister is going to make. There was a great deal of that around this particular statement, given the current state of our economy and the general direction or lack of direction of the government. There was a great deal of anticipation about what the government was going to do. Some of that anticipation surrounded the thought that there would be a significant and large infrastructure program across the country. Even in the hour or two before the introduction of the mini statement there were some discussions and thought that the government would try to address and deal with the whole question of the goods and services tax and the impact it has had on the economy.
I would like to make a few points on the general situation we find ourselves in now and to concentrate ever so briefly on two areas of particular importance and interest to my constituents.
I want to congratulate my colleague, the member for Essex-Windsor, on the comments he made yesterday in his initial response to the Minister of Finance. He laid out pretty clearly some of the desperate straits this government has got us into.
When we take a look at some of the evidence and information we see the kind of challenge we have before us. We are talking about 11.3 per cent unemployment. A recent report came out saying that there are 3.8 million Canadians in poverty, the worst it has ever been. By the government's own statistics there are some 2.5 million people on welfare. There is 11 per cent unemployed.
There was discussion surrounding the inability of the government and the finance minister to predict accurately the budgetary situation in relation to what the deficit would be. According to previous estimates of the government, at one point the deficit for 1993-1994 would be
$22.5 billion. Of course we now have the report that it is around $32.6 billion for next year. At one point it even suggested that in two years it would be down to $5 billion.
I find interesting the comments of some commentators on television. They seem to have forgotten many of the comments they and others made on the previous estimates of where the budget deficit would be.
