They seem to have forgotten and have quickly and easily rewritten history as far as the predictions of the government go.
I would like to move to two areas that were not included in the financial statement. The first point I want to pursue briefly is the question of the green plan which was discussed today in Question Period. I appreciated the honesty of the minister who responded when she said that the third cut to the green plan would be reviewed by cabinet. It would review some of the current programs under that plan to see the nature of the programs and how they would be operating in the near future.
There are three components of the green plan that I am particularly concerned about. First is the Fraser River Basin Management Plan in British Columbia where the Fraser River starts. It starts at one end of my riding nice and clean. When it turns south in Prince George it starts to get a little dirty.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: The plan will be saved.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
The minister says that it will be saved. I hope she is as honest in the debate now as she was in Question Period when she says that the Fraser River plan will be saved.
Turning to the the other programs, maybe we will get the minister to respond as well. I am concerned about the Model Forest Plan and Tree Plan Canada. Let us hope the minister can give the same assurance. She is not doing that now. I am pleased about the Fraser River but we will hear-

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: It is a very important program.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
They are very important programs. I know we will hear from the government later. Let us hope they do not get the same treatment as some of the other programs have.
December 3, 1992

Most people have seen in the documents the minister brought forward some specific mention of a number of infrastructure programs in Atlantic Canada. Of course they are needed. There are some projects in national parks in British Columbia and Alberta-I think about Jasper near my riding and the Alaska Highway-that are needed.
The government has now had two years to take a look at a very important infrastructure program for northern British Columbia, the Yellowhead Highway Program, to upgrade and improve that particular highway. It was there before. It was cancelled by the former Social Credit government. The current government has not given us a great signal that it intends to proceed with that program.
Yesterday I wrote to the provincial minister, the member for Kamloops, the Hon. Art Charbonneau, and our federal transport minister to remind them of that program. It would be an excellent opportunity for us to improve the program. If I am not mistaken, the Yellowhead Highway goes through the riding of the Minister of Finance. I see him smiling. I would hope that means good luck for a Yellowhead program in the near future.
I have my Fraser River Program and I will get my Yellowhead Highway Program from the Minister of Finance tonight. However, I encourage the government to look at the program because it is important for northern British Columbia. I would strongly encourage the government and the minister to take a look at that particular highway because of its need. It is part of the national highways network. Of the $300 million that has been set aside for other initiatives with the provinces, I encourage this government to take a close look at that particular highway, to include it and to build in a program that would improve the Yellowhead Highway in some areas, bring it up to some standard. We are not talking about a lot of work.
I would like to conclude with those two comments on the importance of these programs. There is a need to protect the investment we have there and to suggest to the government that when it says it had some choices to make in this economic statement it was right. It made a number of wrong choices. It could have taken the opportunity to close some tax loopholes. It could have given Canadians an opportunity to have a consumer led
Government Orders
recovery by scrapping the GST and bringing in a fair tax system.
Those are the kinds of messages I hope the government will listen to so that we can try to put Canada's economy back on the road again.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Thank you, Madam Speaker, for the opportunity to speak tonight on this debate regarding the financial statement tabled in the House yesterday by the Minister of Finance which we should really refer to as a budget.
I am very concerned about various aspects of this budget, the fact that it zeros in on the people who can least afford it, the people who need help most. Certainly at this time of the year as we enter into the festive season, rather than giving a message of hope and inspiration it is ensuring us of increased and enduring hardship as we go into the new year. So much for a happy new year.
I could not help but notice in one of the documents yesterday an error that I think should be corrected because a lot of people may see it and take it to be fact. On page 66 of the document Investing In Growth, tabled December 2, 1992, it speaks about trade barriers within Canada and says "marketing boards, pricing and distribution of policies of provincially regulated marketing boards (pork products for example) can reduce interprovincial trade".
I am sure it is an oversight on the part of the minister. As a former Minister of Agriculture I am sure he is well aware that there are no interprovincial barriers to pork production. If there was to be a barrier to interprovincial movement it would have to be a federal barrier. The federal government, under the British North American Act, has jurisdiction over interprovincial trade and export trade. Only provincial governments can trade within the provinces. At the present time we do not have a national pork marketing agency. They are individual provincial marketing boards. Consequently that is an error. I draw it to the attention of the Minister of Finance. I am sure he will want to correct that statement.
I also want to point out that I am deeply alarmed by the cuts that took place in Agriculture Canada's budget. As I look at the chart that we have from the National Council of Welfare, property rates by occupation, 1990, it shows that in the heads of families the second highest is in farming, fishing and forestry. Here we have very little

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
if any help for those industries except the 10 per cent investment tax credit made available to them. Of what use is that to the fisheries industry at the present time with the cutbacks it has had to face? How many farmers, with the incomes they have had, can use that tax credit?
I am very disturbed because farm income has utterly failed to keep pace with the Canadian average family income. About three years ago the government started referring to farm family income that included the wages of a spouse who was teaching school or nursing or if the husband was off driving a truck to supplement the farm income.
While that total family farm income for 1990 was $37,958, $21,251 of that came from sources that are not connected to the farm, such as the off-farm income I referred to. To go further than that, it left them a net of a little over $15,000 coming from the actual farm operation. Of that $8,091 came from government subsidies, either federal or provincial, but they were combined. That left a net figure of $7,615 coming from the farming operation itself. That is a national disgrace. It cannot continue. If these trends continue Canadian agriculture as we know it today will be completely destroyed.
There are some other things I want to touch on here. I am not an economist but common sense tells me as we look at what has been happening over the last 10 years. Our merchandise trade over the last 10 years has dropped from $17.6 billion in 1982 to $7.3 billion in 1992. The merchandise trade surplus has dropped by over $10 billion in those 10 years.
I also want to point out the current account deficit in Canada has gone from a surplus position in that same period of over $2 billion a year in 1982 to a deficit of $26.7 billion in 1991. That is money flowing out of Canada in either interest payments, dividends or as we heard today in Question Period, through loopholes in the tax system.
Canada cannot afford such haemorrhaging. We have done nothing to stop it and it is getting worse each year. As that continues to get worse then of course we are going to face increased hardships and further attacks on the unemployed and those people in society who can least afford it.
I am deeply concerned because one of our prominent economists, Arthur Donar argues that for each $20 billion in current account deficit, 500,000 jobs are lost and the government is allowing that to happen.
One very large food distribution and retailing firm operating in western Canada sent $538.7 million in dividends out of this country in 1990 to its parent company in the U.S. It borrowed over $400 million to do that. Guess who is going to pay back the amount in excess of $400 million? It is going to be the Canadian consumers and that money has gone out of Canada. Those dividends are part of that current account deficit. This sort of thing has to be arrested.
I am further disturbed about the closures of food processing plants. I will give you the Ontario figures first. From 1989 to 1992 a lot of plants closed. In the province of Ontario alone there were 59 closures. We keep a close check on what has been happening across Canada and some of these figures are available from Agriculture Canada, Statistics Canada, the Department of Labour as well as press reports. We find there have been over 100 closures.
As those plants close, Canadian producers lose a marketing alternative. When they lose those alternatives, we have to import those products. In that regard it adds to our current account deficit.
I am disturbed the government did not include some facts and figures on the current account deficit in the financial statement given yesterday. That is vitally important to this nation if we are going to continue to prosper and keep this social safety network that has served this country so well for so many years.
This country is built on the understanding of the needs of those less fortunate. It is built on the principle of care and compassion for the less fortunate. There has to be a dramatic turn around in policy or else there will be a lot of needy people here in Canada who are even worse off than they are now.
I am deeply concerned also about what is happening in other countries in terms of the concentration in the food production processing industry.
December 3, 1992

I have some facts here which come out of the sociology department of the University of Missouri. They point out that in the United States four firms control 69 per cent of the beef processing. Four firms control the same percentage of beef cattle feed lots.
I could go on and on because I have the firms listed here. The same firms are involved in production and processing. As those firms move to Canada in a big way, they will continue to erode and destroy the food producing and processing sectors in Canada.
I am deeply concerned. I do not often speak in this House on such issues as we have at the present time. I am really disturbed about this budget that was brought down. It is going to impact so viciously on so many people who can least afford it.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise with pleasure to participate in this debate today. I want to start off by saying to the minister of revenue I cannot give him three cheers for the particular statement he gave in the House yesterday, but I will give him two and one-half for sure. I will explain slightly why I would not give him the other half although he was certainly going in the right direction.
There are a lot of very good things in this budget. I want to compliment the minister on the fact that during this whole process as he was preparing for this particular statement, he listened, asked for and received advice from numerous people including your humble servant who is now speaking.
I am happy to say some of the things I recommended to the minister as being very appropriate to include in this statement are in fact there. They were not just hair-brained ideas I came up with to give to the minister.
In fact during the summer recess when we were back in our ridings I certainly took advantage of the opportunity to meet with numerous business people. I met with a group in conjunction with a meeting organized by the mayor of Whitby, the Durham Regional Manufacturer's Association, the Whitby Chamber of Commerce and the Whitby Junior Jaycees.
We came together with several vice-presidents of banks, I might add, to talk about the financing problems that exist for small businesses. In that meeting the issue
Government Orders
was raised that the Small Businesses Loans Act existed, but it was there for people who wanted to invest in such things as new equipment. They appreciated the minister raised the amount from $100,000 to $200,000, but they were concerned it could not be used to assist them in their cash flow requirements on a daily basis.
I am happy to report in the minister's statement there is a clear indication there may be some assistance in those areas which were requested by the business community, the people who create jobs in the town of Whitby, the town of Ajax and the town of Pickering. I think that is a very positive step and I congratulate the minister for it.
Again, it was not my idea. It was an idea brought to me by the business community I met with during the summer. I thank the minister for that.
But he went a little further because there are businesses that are very successful and are experiencing good economic activity. They want to buy some new equipment. Not only has he improved the financing opportunity for that equipment, he has improved the tax credits for them to be able to afford to buy that equipment. That creates jobs. That equipment is manufactured in whole or in part in many areas of Canada and that creates economic activity everywhere.
There are some other things I was asked to deal with by the people I met. Unemployment insurance was of concern, not only to the business community but to my constituents who were on unemployment insurance and wanted to find jobs. Unlike some stories, I do believe and most of my constituents indicate, they want jobs. They do not want to sit at home and collect unemployment insurance. They do not want to sit at home and collect welfare. They want to find jobs.
The minister has put some very positive things in here. The first is for those businesses that want to hire the people who are on unemployment insurance. They do not face an increase in premiums because they are hiring some people. My riding has many small businesses. The minister, with full credit to him, has said to these small businesses: "We will not charge you more in the way of unemployment insurance premiums if you hire new people and get them working for you". That is very positive.

Government Orders
On the other side many of my small business people have said when they do hire somebody they work their 20 or 22 weeks and then for whatever reason they can come up with they quit. They say they invest all this time, money and effort in training these people and lo and behold they qualify for unemployment insurance, they get their 20 weeks and quit. 1 can tell you the small business community has commented to me about that.
As a member of Parliament who represents one of the largest ridings in Canada, I can tell you many of my constituents tell me they are tired of these people who quit their jobs and go on unemployment insurance because they think they are entitled to it.
I want to congratulate the minister for that very bold step of telling people if they have jobs not to quit just to go on unemployment insurance because they are not going to get it. I congratulate the minister fully on that particular step.
I also congratulate the minister on another very appropriate step that relates to the unemployment insurance scheme. My constituents have faced very difficult times in the last few years and will not be getting salary increases. In fact many of them, if not most of them, are working for less money now than two or three years ago. But lo and behold if you go on unemployment insurance you are going to get an automatic raise in April of some 3 per cent or whatever.
I congratulate the minister for telling those on unemployment insurance they are not getting a raise next year. He did not say their unemployment benefits would be cut. He said they would not be raised. The raise that would have taken place next year of some 3 per cent is being cancelled. I congratulate the minister for that.
I also congratulate the minister for the salary freeze. You do not often like to admit these things but I was one of those who in fact encouraged it to happen. I encouraged it to happen in the Public Service and throughout the various government corporations that are affected. I encouraged it to happen for senators and I know that will just cause them to have another reason to have their thoughts about me. I also encouraged it to happen for members of Parliament.
I would have liked a raise, but I have 185,000 constituents and many of them are not getting raises. I think it is about time we in this collective Chamber decide we have to live within the means. Someday in the future when this Parliament and our budget systems in Canada are much more in line with the economic realities, maybe we can afford to give members of Parliament a raise. A two year freeze on MPs' salaries and all those others affected certainly does not bother me in the least. I can tell you I was one of those who recommended this and I have no hesitation in supporting that particular activity.
I think the minister was very wise in his statement relating to the infrastructure problem. We have unemployed people across Canada, there is no doubt about that. One of the easiest and quickest things we can do to get some people back to work is to put some money into building roads, bridges, highways and all those kinds of things.
First, they are very locally oriented so if you are going to build a bridge in Ajax, the construction workers of Ajax are probably going to be working on it. Across Canada, construction workers probably have one of the highest rates of unemployment. Lo and behold the Minister of Finance in his economic statement has said the government is going to put some money into infrastructure development.
It will be good for Atlantic Canada. It will be good for western Canada with highways through the national parks. It will be good for southern Ontario because money is going to be put into level crossings at railroads where a safety factor often has to be addressed. Those are very high concentrations of employment creation and I commend the minister for making those steps.
I also commend the minister for his commitment to getting on with the job of building the fixed link to Prince Edward Island. As someone from Ontario, you might question why I would even care about that. Those kinds of projects are important to the over-all structure of Canada. There is the whole highway aspect of eastern Canada and the maritimes. Part of the problem in this country is you must have the transportation systems in place to have economic activity. You have to make it possible for people and business to locate in regions of Canada and yet get to other parts of Canada. It is a very good economic decision.
December 3, 1992

I travelled extensively throughout the United States in my previous career. I was always amazed at how easy it was to get into some very rural parts of the United States. There would be large industries and maybe one industry towns. Manufacturing industries were located there for many reasons. One of them was the transportation systems were in place to allow industry to get its products to market. The best thing we can do for the maritimes and other regions of Canada is put in place a transportation system to allow industry to locate there without having to get a government grant. Government grants to locate industry are not the best thing.
I talked about some of the other things. I am really running short of time. I like the cuts in grants to organizations of 10 per cent across the board. However, this is where I miss out on my half a per cent. I had some in mind that I recommended should be cut totally and I am sorry they were not; the National Action Committee on the Status of Women, the Canadian Labour Congress and some business groups that get grants. There is a whole bunch I would like to cut off totally. Recognizing them may be difficult to do.
In very short order, I just want to put the minister on notice that I will be back for his February or March budget telling him about the groups I am ready to cut. I will also be back to tell him how I think we ought to adjust the MPs' pension plan and finally and certainly not least of all, I will be telling him how I think we have to address the deficit even further than we have already done.
I give the minister a good mark for effort on this. I cannot quite give him three cheers. However, it is probably one of the best statements I have heard the minister give and I give him full marks for that.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am happy to have this opportunity to speak about the economic situation in the north and generally in Canada.
Canadians in every region of this country have suffered in this recession, northern Canadians included. In fact, northerners must cope with additional economic difficulties due to their geographic location from the main economic corridors of the country. As a result, the
Government Orders
cost of living in the north is 60 per cent higher than in the south. Major transportation routes and infrastructures remain basically incomplete.
A serious housing shortage threatens many northern communities. There is, I believe, a backlog of 3,500 units. The number of housing units, as has been announced, has been cut in half. This is something that is intolerable and unacceptable with the kinds of conditions northerners live in.
A lack of financial support threatens important aboriginal programs and organizations such as Indigenous Survival International, the fur industry defence program. There was no announcement for a commitment to those particular efforts that are much needed by the traditional harvesters of Canada.
With regard to public infrastructure, the NWT highway development, yesterday's economic statement outlined the government's commitment to undertake regional infrastructure projects to strengthen our national transportation system and communications network. Improving transportation in the north is crucial. Transportation is essentially the lifeline of the north due to the vast distances and the isolation which exists between communities. Transportation costs in the NWT are the highest in Canada. Economic development in the north cannot proceed without proper roads.
Never mind roads, if we lose Canadian Airlines as one of our carriers in the Northwest Territories, we will have a monopoly that will drive prices to a rate that would be intolerable and I think unconstitutional and unfair to people in the region who essentially will not have any other choice. They do not have a highway system.
The GNWT has identified the need of $3 billion for development. The government leader, Nellie Cour-noyea, has raised this issue with federal leaders at various meetings. I believe this was an issue that was profiled at the economic meetings among the premiers of the country. New roads are the constitutional and legal responsibility of the federal government. It has to be noted that only existing roads were transferred to the Northwest Territories, not any new initiatives.
I guess gone is the dream of Roads to Resources that Mr. Diefenbaker implemented. That certainly is not a Tory goal at this stage of the game.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
The Kitikmeot region in the NWT is very mineral rich but cannot develop without a transportation network. The Mackenzie Valley highway extension from Fort Wrigley to Inuvik is 804 kilometres and will cost $500 million. This is something that northerners have supported. I put forward a petition to the Elouse just recently about this.
GNWT cannot afford to build any new roads without the federal government contribution. While the government will spend approximately $5.25 million in the
1993-94 fiscal year, the needs are great and the north simply cannot be developed without transportation infrastructure. There is a great need in the north for new roads and ports, but $3 billion is needed and so is the initiative of the federal government where the responsibility lies squarely.
Yesterday's economic statement outlines that federal roads and roadworks in western Canada's national parks will be upgraded. We as westerners from the north, of course, assume that this includes the Wood Buffalo National Park, one of the outstanding parks in the world. Wood Buffalo National Park is one of Canada's most precious prizes in terms of parks.
The superintendent of Wood Buffalo National Park has announced that the park can no longer operate the winter road between Fort Chipewyan, Alberta, and Fort Smith, Northwest Territories. We need to extricate a definite commitment from the Minister of the Environment and the Minister of Finance that this indeed includes the initiative that was announced yesterday. The amount that they are asking for is a meagre $76,000 to keep these communities connected by a winter road. The 130 kilometre winter road provides winter-only access between Fort Smith, a population of 2,500, and Fort Chipewyan, a population of 1,300.
This other community outside of my riding borders the community of the hon. member for Athabasca. He also has an interest in seeing that this particular goal is achieved.
The road is open for four months a year approximately. This is the only means of access and transportation link between the isolated communities during winter months. The average cost to operate the road for four months is $60,000. I said $76,000; it is $60,000.
Clearly, as far as developing regional infrastructure projects, the federal government must consider a permanent road through Wood Buffalo National Park and a policy funding initiative whereby the cost of maintaining and continuing the Fort Smith winter road would be guaranteed, possibly through cost-sharing initiatives split between the province, territories and federal government.
Another issue that came up yesterday was that there would be an improvement in the airports in the north. The federal government has different levels of airports for which it has maintained support. The federal government must provide the desperately needed funding that would enable the GNWT to meet the existing needs and requirements for the improvements and upgrading of a number of community airports in the Northwest Territories in light of the fact that northern residents rely upon air transportation more than any other means of transportation. This critical and basic need is also an issue of safety.
The responsibility that the federal government had for the grassroots community is no longer there. It has transferred that responsibility to the GNWT. Those communities have real need. If no further resources are going to be allocated to the government of the Northwest Territories, we are not going to be able to deal with these specific needs.
I can think specifically off the top of my head of two instances where safety is an issue. In the community of Fort Franklin we had a very major accident in the last 15 years. We did not have the requirements met and there was an accident which resulted in the loss of life. The community is very concerned in that the airport runway is situated so that aeroplanes fly right over a schoolyard so the community wants the airport relocated.
In the community of Trout Lake, Northwest Territories, which is also a priority listed under the GNWT's airport plan, the community experiences severe crosswinds, extremely dangerous because it is not a sometimes thing. It is a constant problem for people going in and out of that community.
Regarding the home buyers plan and the Northwest Territories housing needs, the Minister of Finance said the RRSP program for first time home buyers would be extended for one more year. This is good news. Unfortunately, there are virtually no private housing markets
December 3, 1992

outside of Yellowknife. This means a lack of affordable housing alternatives in most communities.
The federal government's decision to reduce the NWT housing budget will mean 200 fewer low-cost shared social housing units which will be built in the Northwest Territories in 1993. This comes at a time when the need for housing in the Northwest Territories has risen by 14 per cent over the last two years, in spite of the GNWT providing 800 units during this two year period. The NWT housing unit needs are unique. Severe climate isolated communities make construction and maintenance of housing unit costs five times higher than in the south. A higher percentage of residents in the north rely on social housing assistance as compared to the south.
The federal Department of Indian and Northern Affairs and Development does not contribute funding specifically for native housing in the NWT as it does in other jurisdictions. The birth rate in the Northwest Territories is more than twice the national average.
The federal reductions will have a definite impact: increased numbers of families in need of housing assistance, overcrowding and inadequate conditions will increase social and health-related problems, and loss of construction and other jobs in the private sector. The government needs to reinstate social housing funding to the NWT to the 1991 level. This is being recommended to the aboriginal affairs committee in the housing study they are doing. Hopefully we will be able to get some redress there.
Program cuts are of particular interest to natives and interest groups. I really resent the way in which interest groups or advocacy groups are being labelled by the government.
I might end by quoting one of the people who has written to me on this particular issue. What has happened over the last couple of years is that advocacy groups are being referred to in a very negative way. They pick up where the government has left off and I think that they do very good work.
I would like to quote one of the people from my riding who has indicated to me concern about the kind of situation that will be created by the reduction. Lynn
Government Orders
Brooks with the NWT status of women has indicated the situation for women and children living in some of the northern communities is virtually explosive. In order to help and to have resources available, there needs to be funding. Women, children and seniors always fall at the bottom of this list.
In closing, I have to say that these cuts are very detrimental to the other community programs that we have, specifically the friendship centres. The Tree of Peace Friendship Centre in the Northwest Territories which offers very important programs like kindergarten, adult education, native outreach, drug and alcohol abuse programs and a camp for children in the summer is very important to our community. It cannot endure this 10 per cent cut.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, Bill C-98, Borrowing Authority Act 1992-93, No. 2. The statement of the minister yesterday in speaking on this bill of course was an admission of failure. The minister kept talking about what the deficit is going to be this year, what it is going to be next year and the year after. For four years I have heard ministers of finance tell us quite confidently what the deficit is going to be five years from now and then estimate what it will be this year and perhaps next year.
Madam Speaker, I am sure you have had occasion in your career, or in your home life at least, to have used a funnel. There is a small hole at one end and a big hole at the other. As you pour material into the large hole, you can direct the flow through the small hole. Everything works out fine as long as you do it that way.
But, Madam Speaker, it would not occur to you to turn the funnel upside down and do it the other way around, trying to pour something into the wrong end of the funnel. That is what the Minister of Finance has been doing in trying to get the economy going. He is trying to pour the medicine into the wrong end of the funnel. In the process of doing that, of course a lot of it is being wasted. It misses the small hole and as it comes out the large hole, it is spread around and does not do any good.
The process has failed for two years now. This is not the first time they have tried it. Each time we get a new budget or a statement such as we had yesterday, the minister is trying to deal with the problem by going backward, pouring the medicine through the small hole

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
and letting it come out the large hole and losing the effect.
Other members have talked about 1.5 million people unemployed in this country. They have talked about 2.5 million on social welfare, a total of four million people. That is a serious problem. It is very serious for the people involved. The talk so far has been about them and the harm this is causing them and what they are doing without.
There is another way of looking at those people. They are all potential customers. They all want to purchase something but they do not have the wherewithal to purchase it. What does the government do? The government says: "We will help small businesses produce more stuff. We are going to give them breaks on their depreciation allowance so that they can claim more depreciation for small businesses". This is the case after it was introduced in the budget this spring.
That will not help small businesses. It will not help them if they cannot produce anything and they cannot produce if they cannot sell. They cannot sell if there are not customers out there wanting to buy and able to buy, with the wherewithal to buy. That is the problem.
The government is going to increase the loan limit. What is the point in saying to the prospective borrower and to the lender that if this business person can produce financial statements that show that he or she can produce at a profit, and that unless they can do that the bank is not going to lend any money at whatever rate or whatever limit? If that business person could come to the prospective lender and say: "Here are my projections. I know that this business is out there waiting to buy if I produce this item. Will you lend to me knowing that I can make a profit on selling these items", then that prospective borrower has a much better chance of getting that loan.
What the government should be doing, instead of taking away from the unemployed and taking away from the people who do not have money, is giving the money directly to them, pouring the medicine through the small end of the funnel rather than through the large end, directing it to the people who need it most.
The Minister of Finance has been listening to a lot of advice since we started this debate at about 3.15 yesterday afternoon until midnight last night and probably until midnight again tonight. I have some sympathy for him. He is listening to a bunch of his own members tell him what a great job he has done, and he is listening to opposition members tell him what a terrible job he has done and, as I did, to say that it is an admission of failure when he comes in with the statement he made yesterday.
I am not sure if he would not like to consider for one moment what I have been talking about, which is that he should work it the other way around: put the money where the prospective customers are and make the purchasing power available to the four million people who are on social welfare and who are unemployed. Then small business will have the opportunity that it needs to expand.
That will create employment. That will get the economy going. As for giving the money directly to the small business people, if they are already making a profit, so be it, they will get a little more. If they are not making a profit it is not going to help them. They are not going to be able to borrow. They are not going to be able to do anything. It might slow down the time it takes them to go bankrupt as businesses are doing at a great rate in this country.
There is a way. It is not new. There is nothing new about it at all. This government has not tried it. There should be more money spent on education. The government has cut back on the money going to the provinces to help them with their educational programs. The government did not produce the training programs that were promised as part of the free trade deal. There are things like that that could and should be done that would get things moving in Canada.
More than anything else the thing that the government can do right now that would be most impressive would be to put money in the hands of the people that we know would spend it in Canada on goods that are being produced in Canada, not on goods that are being imported, especially with the dollar going down. That is good. That means that people are going to be buying more Canadian produce and more Canadian articles because it is more expensive to buy the imports. It helps us sell in outside markets.
December 3, 1992

Interest is something that does have to be paid. To the extent that it is interest on borrowed money we have to export to be able to pay that interest.
To the extent that it is interest paid on money borrowed within Canada then that is simply redistributing income within Canada, shifting the income within Canada. That is not as serious a problem.
That advice was given by a finance minister in the province of British Columbia in the early 1940s, incidentally another Tory, the hon. Herbert Anscomb. He said: "A government should never borrow but in the event that it has to borrow in bad times to maintain its public service then it should never borrow externally. It should do its borrowing internally".
That, too, is not new. We did that during the war, and we prospered. We borrowed internally because there was nowhere else to borrow. Everybody was busy doing their own thing. Everybody was busy expanding their own industries in their own countries. We borrowed it all internally. We piled up a tremendous debt during the war doing that, and we paid it off afterwards because we kept the money circulating within Canada. It is only when we started borrowing from abroad that we started to run into trouble.
However, the immediate answer for now is simply to put this money where it will do the most good. Instead of giving it to people and saying: "Go out and hire somebody, it does not matter what you do, just hire somebody", and then not being able to police it anyway, instead of giving them increased depreciation allowances that will let them write off their taxes faster put the money in the hands of the unemployed, put the money in the hands of the people who are on social welfare, and they will create a genuine business boom that will start the economy of Canada moving again.
We have gone down the wrong road. We have cut back on education and cut back on training. We are giving money to companies. I have no real quarrel with taxing corporations or not taxing them. As a matter of fact, I would be inclined to look at the Carter report again if I really wanted to get things going. Carter went so far as to recommend no corporation tax but said to make sure that we get it from the individuals who are profiting from the business activities of those corporations. Of course, that would mean a total change in the tax structure and I
Government Orders
do not recommend doing that all in one fell swoop. That is something that would have to be done gradually.
To return to what I was talking about, the funnel analogy, put the medicine in the right end of the funnel, let it spread around and let it be picked up by people who would benefit from it and who would then benefit the whole economy by spending that money within the economy.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to enter the debate on this economic statement presented by the former Minister of Transport with whom I had a lot of memorable days and years when he was the critic for transport and I was a parliamentary secretary. He says those days are over. Yes, but I thought he had learned something over the years and judging from his economic statement he has not learned very much.
My constituents of Parkdale-High Park are pleased to hear that the home buyers' plan, which we had recommended for the last two years now, has been extended by one year. However the problem in my riding is that most of them cannot afford to buy a home right now and therefore the real estate economy is down. Even if some of my constituents of Parkdale-High Park could afford a home they may not buy one for fear of losing their job in this new economic order cooked up by this Conservative government.
If people lose their jobs under this new regime they may no longer qualify for unemployment insurance. This is the kind of thing that makes the blood boil in most Canadians. It creates a national anger that is growing and spreading across this land. I have never seen such frustration, such anger as we have in our country right now.
For those who have paid UI premiums for years the safety net has now been removed. If they are fired or if they leave their job voluntarily they no longer qualify for UI benefits. Tell me, how many Canadians does this government intend to force onto the welfare rolls? How many women have been forced to leave their jobs because of sexual harassment? Without at least the UI option this government simply expects women to grin and bear it. The Minister of Employment and Immigration rose in the House today and provided no reassurance to women. The minister's only response was: "Trust me". Canadians are through trusting this government,

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
especially this Minister of Employment and Immigration and the last two finance ministers.
My daughter, who is in her second year of university, did for one of her projects a study of projections made by finance ministers over the last eight years. She was horrified. She came to me and said: "Dad, those ministers lied". I said: "No, no, Elaine, we do not use that word. That is not parliamentary". However, this young Canadian starting university was shocked that she cannot trust the finance ministers who are setting the economy for this country.
This government told Canadians that the first priority was jobs, jobs, jobs. Instead, what do we have? Higher taxes, taxes, taxes. The reality of the situation is that the national unemployment rate is 11.3 per cent. In metro Toronto the unemployment rate is a full percentage point higher than the national average, 12.3 per cent. Toronto and Montreal were cities of opportunities. I remember people from Saskatchewan and Manitoba coming to Toronto, people from Newfoundland and Prince Edward Island coming to Montreal or Toronto to find jobs because that is where the jobs were. Now the people from Toronto, people from my riding, are looking to go to other provinces, but there are no jobs there either. For young people aged 18 to 24 that rate may be as high as 23 per cent.
My constituency office is becoming an employment office. It is very sad to see students with masters degrees and Ph.D.s begging: "Mr. Flis, can you help us find a job?" They are that desperate. People who were selfemployed, architects and project managers in engineering who have worked for 15 or 20 years, are now coming embarrassed to their member of Parliament saying: "Mr. Flis, maybe through your contacts you can help me find a job". They are too embarrassed to go on the welfare rolls. They are too embarrassed to go on the UI rolls, but they are forced to do this. How can the minister look Canadians straight in the eye and say: "Trust me"? No one trusts this government any more.
Let us look at the small business employment and investment package. It says that the ceiling for loans to small firms under the Small Businesses Loans Act will be
increased to $250,000. That sounds great but the problem is that the banks are not willing to invest in small firms during this recession. Twice nothing is still nothing.
Small business people come to my office and explain to me that they have a payroll to meet, they have to pay income tax to Revenue Canada, and because of a low cash flow they cannot pay it that month. Revenue Canada penalizes them 20 per cent. Representatives from one firm came to me owing $80,000 to Revenue Canada, and Revenue Canada is insisting that this be paid immediately. The firm is saying: "If we pay this $80,000 we go bankrupt. We employ 10 people. If Revenue Canada would forego this penalty the firm agrees to pay the interest but if Revenue Canada could forgive the penalty for at least the duration of the recession then I could maybe survive".
Representatives from another business came to me owing Revenue Canada $40,000. They said: "Mr. Flis, it means going under. If we are forced to pay this, it means going under". I did refer them to Revenue Canada because I understand that there is a plan to help small businesses that are being threatened with bankruptcy to somehow negotiate with Revenue Canada to save these businesses. Mr. Minister, this is a good plan but why are you not advertising it? Why do not more small businesses that are going bankrupt know about this? To announce that the small business loan has increased to $250,000 does not mean a darn thing because they go to the bank and they cannot get $40,000.
They cannot get a $50,000 loan. They are kicked in the rear by Revenue Canada and they are kicked from the front by the banks.
Instead of the banks being good corporate citizens, what they are doing is deteriorating the state of the economy of this country. Together with Revenue Canada and the banks, the small entrepreneurs, the businesses, are not getting much help today.
No one has confidence in this government any more. The money lenders do not have confidence. Entrepreneurs do not have confidence. Consumers do not have confidence-nobody; as the Russians would say, nada.
December 3, 1992

Government Orders
Look at the deficit fighting program of this government. It represents a litany of unrealistic and failed promises in the billions. Where cost savings have been realized, the government takes a bow. These savings are usually at the expense of the provinces which in turn must pass along the burden to the municipalities. My leader pointed out in his debate that he met with the mayor of Montreal. The mayor is very concerned how the city cannot bear carrying the welfare payments for the unemployed.
I happened to be on a Liberal task force crossing Ontario. We talked to the chairman of metropolitan Toronto, Alan Tonks. He has the same concern. The people are exhausting their UI benefits. They are forced to go on the welfare rolls and the big and smaller cities cannot afford the tab.
The minister stands up here and says look what a great job we are doing because we are cutting back. It makes the federal government look good but who ends up picking up the tab? Provinces are not picking up the tab. The poor municipalities end up picking up the tab. They end up becoming the fall guy.
This government professes that governments should be run on the same principles as business in the private sector. If that is so, the Minister of Finance would have been fired a long time ago. He did a better job in transport. I recommend that he go back there.
What if the minister then tries to apply for UI benefits? He would soon find out that he is not eligible for benefits through his own misconduct.
Let us look at the record of financial management of this government, this so-called deficit fighting government. In 1984 the national debt stood at $170 billion. By the end of this fiscal year it is $420 billion. When we turned over the reins at $170 billion, we at least borrowed money in Canada from pension plans and so on. This government, no. It is the big shot. It went on the foreign markets. No wonder we have a $420 billion public debt. No wonder we are in the mess that we are in.
I know my time is up, I will close. I am pleased the Minister of Finance is sitting here. I hope that he will listen to the people of Parkdale-High Park. I am just their servant. I am their spokesman but I say to the minister times are tough across Canada.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to participate in the debate following the recent economic statement made by the Minister of Finance. He gave us a good description of our economic future and of how we will reach our goals.
We will continue to follow sound monetary and fiscal policies. We will continue to increase the efficiency of the public sector. We will continue to open our markets while improving our productivity and our competitiveness in order to meet the competition challenge. We will invest more in our human resources and in our infrastructure in partnership with Canadians and other jurisdictions in order to promote growth.
Many Canadians, including my colleagues opposite, have trouble dealing with the globalization phenomenon which started in the 1990s. Some would have liked things to remain the way they were and Canadians to have a false sense of security thanks to an imaginary protection against the outside world.
Mr. Speaker, we must still face contemporary economic realities. We can no longer live turned in on ourselves and looking towards the past. We must have a forwardlooking vision. The last thing we want is for the Canadian economy to fall into a permanent slump. The new initiatives and maintenance of the policies announced by the minister will help us enter the 21st century on the right foot.
I do not pretend for a moment that the changes and restructuring that we have gone through and continue to undergo have been easy for anyone, including the federal government.
Nevertheless, since 1984 we have pursued an economic program to give all Canadians a more secure future with better economic opportunities and we now see the result of it. For example, Canada has the lowest inflation rate among the seven largest industrial countries, the G-7, namely 1.4 per cent this year. Productivity growth is now 2.6 per cent and our trade efforts abroad are starting to give results. Canada's merchandise balance of trade, a key to reducing the current account deficit, is up nearly $2 billion over last year.
Consumer confidence is being restored. Employment has started to grow, domestic demand has strengthened and real exports are rising. The improvements are slight but undeniable. But that is not enough. Our economy is slow to come out of the recent recession. One of the

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
factors holding us back is the low growth in all the G-7 countries, our trading partners. They have the same problems we do.
In his statement on Canada's economic future the Minister of Finance reiterated and strengthened the government's commitment to continue working to expand our markets. The importance of permanently expanding our trade potential internationally was a highlight of the statement. I would like to spend a few minutes on this subject.
International trade is vital for the Canadian economy. Canada depends more on foreign trade than any of the G-7 countries except Germany. You see, Mr. Speaker, the Canadian market is relatively small. If we want Canadians to keep the standard of living to which they are accustomed we need international trade.
Canada exports more than a quarter of its domestic production and one job in four depends on our country's exports. Exports create jobs and help companies reduce their production costs, while imports offer consumers a wide choice of low-priced goods and services.
One way to stimulate foreign trade is to improve access to markets through clear and equitable trade rules. Trade barriers hurt Canada much more than they hurt nations with a large domestic market and our country is also more vulnerable to trade instability. These problems can only be solved by negotiating trade agreements. The trade agreements offer new opportunities to businesses that want to be competitive worldwide by improving their products and lowering their costs. The agreements also provide dispute settlement mechanisms which make trade relations surer and more stable.
Since foreign trade is so important to maintaining and improving our welfare, Canada has been a leader in the effort to liberalize world trade since the end of the Second World War.
As part of a two-pronged trade liberalization strategy, Canada has worked for freer international trade through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, GATT, and free trade agreements with its regional partners.
As a result of successive GATT negotiations, customs duties on our imports have been reduced and our access to foreign markets has improved. For example, Canadian import duties have fallen from over 10 per cent in 1955 to less than 4 per cent in 1990.
On Wednesday, the minister reiterated that the government will work to bring the Uruguay round negotiations to a conclusion. The success of these negotiations would have a major impact on Canada and the rest of the world and would avoid an escalation in costly trade conflicts.
Canada has also concluded regional trade agreements in accordance with GATT rules. The first important agreement was the auto pact with the United States in 1965.
The 1989 Canada-U.S. free trade agreement falls directly in line with this strategy. In spite of the recent recession FTA has had positive results. Canada has markedly increased the volume and the balance of its trade with the United States since the introduction of FTA. Under the agreement, tariff and non-tariff barriers have been lowered and a dispute settlement mechanism put in place, giving us a more stable access to our biggest export market.
Canadian exports to the United States are up $16 billion since the free trade agreement. Also, FTA has attracted more investments to Canada. Foreign investments in the manufacturing sector increased from $1.3 billion in 1989 to $3.1 billion in 1991.
Investments are just as important as foreign trade to ensure economic prosperity. They increase productivity and allow for the creation of more highly paid jobs requiring higher skills. FTA has made Canada more attractive to foreign investors.
The North American free trade agreement is another step in the ongoing strategy followed by Canada to liberalize exchanges. The minister spoke of our commitment to ratify NAFTA.
The North American free trade zone will be the largest in the world with a population of 361 million and a gross domestic product of $7 billion.
December 3, 1992

Thanks to NAFTA, Canada has made major gains which will improve our economic future and open new opportunities to Canadian businesses.
NAFTA will give us better access to an ever increasing Mexican market. It will protect and improve important FTA gains. Finally, it will protect Canadian interests on the American market and will make Canada more attractive to foreign investors. If Canada had stayed out of NAFTA negotiations, the United States would have been the main winners since they would have been the only country to have privileged access to both the Mexican and the Canadian markets.
By staying the course on trade liberalization through NAFTA, Canada will improve its competitiveness, create new jobs and stimulate economic growth.
Trade liberalization will increase Canada's competitiveness and its ability to ensure a high standard of living for its citizens. Competitiveness and a high standard of living will mean more jobs, better security and increased prosperity for every Canadian, which is one of the main goals of the government.
Therefore, I urge all the members of this House to support these initiatives.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it was interesting last week. I had a constituent visit and we were talking about the monetary and fiscal policies of the government and at that time my constituent, Dale MacLean from Penticton, British Columbia, presented me with a tie and he asked me to wear that tie in the House tonight to point out the Mickey Mouse policies of this government.
He talked about the three frontbenchers, Huey, Dewey and Louie sitting there forming the policies of this government and how he felt that the government was in fantasy land because it simply did not lace realities.
When I looked at what was in the particular economic and fiscal statement of the minister there were two things that occurred to me that fit the theme ol this beautiful tie that he presented me with. One was that with Christmas coming it appeared that Scrooge
Government Orders
McDuck had something to say about this. With taking away the 3 per cent from the unemployed, putting the rest of the economic situation on to the provinces, the government was not acting very well prior to Christmas, and that the Minister of Finance was acting like Scrooge.
I thought that was a rather Goofy policy.
Looking at what the media has said since, I was listening to a number of speeches today by members of the government who were quoting The Financial Times and others. I got a number of clippings from various newspapers. One dates back to November 24 in the Edmonton Journal in the Minister of Finance's own back yard of Vegreville. It was interesting because the headline was "Mulroney's Tories run out of gas". In one of the paragraphs it states: "A mini-budget from finance minister Don Mazankowski is unlikely to make a big difference. The bottom line is this: Brian Mulroney has had eight years to create the jobs and prosperity he promised in 1984 and he has failed". How prophetic.
We can look at a number of others. In The Globe and Mail, Jeffrey Simpson states: "Finance Minister Don Mazankowski's economic statement yesterday displayed all the hallmarks of a government running on an intellectual fuel tank marked empty". He goes on to say further: "By its non-choice, it revealed itself to be tired by the exertions of the past seven years, timid in the face of increasingly painful choices, and too far along in its mandate to make the bold policy choices the country's economic and fiscal problems require".
In The Ottawa Citizen it states that the economic statement is too little, too late, too Tory. It says that instead of broad bold policies "Canadians get Reaganism in aspic".
Hugh Winsor in the December 3 The Globe and Mail states:
Tories could have done something about the rapidly accumulating debt in 1987 and 1988 when the economy was on the boil. Instead, they gave everybody a pre-election income tax rebate while pushing up spending in politically sensitive areas.
In their zeal to slay the inflation dragon after winning the 1988 election, they also killed off hope and economic confidence, which is why yesterday's statement is such a confused effort.
When in doubt, tinker, and yesterday's statement did a lot of that.

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
The Ottawa Sun headline says: "Snow clouds?" The article said: "If there is snow on the ground this morning, was linance minister Don Mazankowski responsible?" Further on it states: "The reason some snow jobs work after all is that details are often covered up by whatever has fallen from the sky-the hows and the wherefroms being obscured by the wish to believe that there will finally be some magical solution to ease their burden".
It appears that the finance minister aimed and he shot, but he missed the mark. He did not have anything new to tell us. He went through the same old Reagan economics, the same old Thatcherite economics and he fell well short.
It is unfortunate in the aftermath of the policies set out by this government that there are 1.6 million unemployed and that the poverty rate has increased substantially.
Looking at the Christmas season and what we have to look forward to in Okanagan-Similkameen-Merritt and the Boundary country, I spoke to a number of food banks over the last few days.
In the small community of Merritt, 60 people, 40 per cent of whom are children and 10 per cent employed use the food banks in Merritt. The Boundary country unfortunately does not have enough food for all of the people lining up at the food banks. In Penticton they get 180 people per month and over 40 per cent of those are children. In Oliver, British Columbia, a community of some 4,500 to 5,000 people, 100 people a month line up, 40 per cent of whom are children.
Nationally, there are 1.2 million Canadian kids living in poverty. In 1990 it was estimated there were 3.8 million Canadians living in poverty, an increase of 12 per cent over 1989. Over the year we know that poverty statement has increased. Half of these are considered working poor.
The Canadian Association of Food Banks says there were two million people including 700,000 children who visited a food bank at least once in 1991.
It we look at what has happened with the income tax situation we know and the figures show that the average Canadian family will pay $1,894 more now than what they did in 1984 when this government came into power.
We have pedalled backward instead of moving forward. We have already had a number of people come up and make their speeches and suggest a number of alternatives.
It is important in looking at what is happening in Canada to emphasize the position that when food banks were created in 1981 they were created as a temporary solution to the problem of hunger in our country and in our society. Now there are over 400 of those food banks in Canada and they have so many people lining up that they cannot feed them all.
We look at the situation with seniors. We know once again that so many of our seniors live below the poverty line. Of those seniors, a majority of them are single women.
I looked at the financial statement from the perspectives of British Columbia, western Canada, and Okanagan-Similkameen-Merritt and the Boundary country.
I wondered what was in there that was going to help the people in those areas.
I looked at it from the perspective of seniors. Well, luckily guaranteed income supplement and old age pension were not touched. But the government cut across the board 10 per cent on grants. If the New Horizons grants are cut 10 per cent I will say that in my riding and I am certain in many of the ridings across Canada, those grants have become a necessary part of increasing the education of seniors, increasing seniors helping seniors, wellness programs, increasing the availability of hospice programs, it goes on and on with respect to seniors and I hate to see those cut.
If we look at it from the perspective of the young, I am concerned about some of the cuts in unemployment insurance. We have the situation where we have cut back the mobility of some of these young people who move from job to job but need some time within which to move. They quit and they move on. These are not people who abuse the system. They are people who are trying to do better things. So they quit a $5.50 an hour job, look around and maybe move on to a $7 an hour job. They have been substantially injured in the ability to do that by the cutbacks.
There are so many things in this statement that we could talk about. Agriculture has been cut back. I end by simply saying that the monetary policies of this government have not been cured by this. The fiscal policies have not been cured. The unemployment rate runs
December 3, 1992

rampant. People are hurting out there. We have not created those jobs.
Madam Speaker, this is a Mickey Mouse government with a Mickey Mouse policy.

speakeroldname: Mr. Marcel R. Tremblay (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to participate in this important debate on the Canadian economy and the future course of our economic policy.
We are looking at investing in economic policies designed to increase and permanently establish prosperity for all Canadians. To achieve this our government suggests that we should improve our productivity if we are to compete on the global market which is becoming increasingly competitive at the turn of the century and beyond.
One of our main priorities is to encourage increased productivity in Canada. This is absolutely necessary if we are to meet the challenge of an increasingly competitive global economy.
This increased productivity will provide a broader scope of options for all Canadians. It will improve our standard of living by making real wages higher and allowing us to buy more goods and services, while having more time at our disposal for leisure and hobbies.
In other words, by working smarter and more efficiently, we will raise our standard of living and our quality of life across the country.
Unfortunately, Canada's productivity performance has deteriorated since the late 1970s. Many people believe our productivity has gone down because ol rising inflation. uncertainty about public policy and government intervention in the economy. Whatever the reason, the fact is that the slowing down of total factor productivity since the 1970s is reflected in weaker growth of labour productivity and real wages.
This drop in productivity growth must be reversed. To achieve this, we must invest more in technologies, physical capital and human resources. However, this will only occur if the economic environment is favourable to productivity-enhancing investment. This requires ma-
Government Orders
croeconomic stability as reflected in low inflation, fiscal prudence and appropriate fiscal policies that expand the opportunities for people to work, invest and innovate.
Madam Speaker, this is exactly the kind of economic climate our government has tried to put in place since it came to power. However, changes of the kind we had to bring about cannot be achieved overnight. The world recession has also postponed many of the positive spinoffs that would now be felt if the world economy were in better shape. However, the International Monetary Fund and the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development are of the opinion that next year Canada will experience the strongest rate of economic growth of any industrialized country. I think that the best way the government can help improve productivity in this country is to stay the course.
For instance we must continue to cut public spending. We have legislated annual spending ceilings through the Spending Control Act. We must also continue to privatize Crown corporations, restructure federal activities and keep public service wage settlements in line. The economic and financial statement presented by the Minister of Finance reinforces the government's commitment to spending restrictions. Thanks to the measures announced by the minister, spending will be cut by nearly $8 billion over the next two fiscal years.
Spending cutbacks allow us to pursue our efforts to reduce borrowing requirements, and, together with a sound monetary policy, have made it possible to keep inflation and interest rates at levels that support instead of undermining productive investment. In fact, I am proud to say that Canada had the lowest rate of inflation, an average of 1.5 per cent over the first ten months of 1992, of all G-7 countries.
Low inflation protects people's purchasing power and reduces capital costs for business. It also leads to lower interest rates. In spite of recent increases, the lower interest rates since 1990 have helped stimulate productive investments and made Canadian goods and services more affordable on both the domestic and the foreign market.
The government must also continue to invest in structural policies that will help productive investments recover. For example, we must realize that we need a skilled labour force to increase our international com-

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
petitiveness and our productivity. That is why we have invested in human resources by redirecting unemployment insurance from passive income support to active skills acquisition. That is why spending on worker training and adjustment has increased from $1.2 billion to $3.5 billion in the past two years. That is also why the Minister of Finance announced more aid in his economic and fiscal statement.
We have also invested in economic growth by reforming Canada's tax system. In particular we eliminated the manufacturers' sales tax which cost Canadians jobs and replaced it with the goods and services tax. The GST makes an important contribution to our international competitiveness by reducing the tax included in Canadian exports. Since it came into effect Canadian exporters have saved over $3.5 billion.
To achieve economic prosperity we must continue to invest in the small business sector which is the primary engine of employment growth in this country. Today, thanks to special tax provisions, small businesses enjoy assistance totalling $3 billion annually.
The Minister of Finance has proposed a small business employment and investment package to help small businesses and create new jobs. The measures announced by the minister include capping the employer share ol unemployment insurance premiums for one year, a one-year investment tax credit for small businesses and an extension of the Small Business Financing Program.
We must continue to invest actively in research and development. R and D is essential in developing new products and processes which are the key to success and growth in a global economy.
Since we came to power we have introduced the most generous tax incentives for R and D of any major industrialized country. For instance the February budget provided for additional assistance totalling $230 million over five years to support Canadian companies undertaking research and development.
Furthermore, in his economic statement the Minister of Finance announced changes to allow the tax rules to better reflect how R and D is actually performed in the
business community. We must continue to invest in broadening trade opportunities. As the global economy becomes increasingly competitive, countries and companies that try to ignore this fact will see their share of world trade deteriorate and their economies decline.
That is why we are doing our best to bring about a positive conclusion to the Uruguay round, the series of multilateral trade talks held under the GATT. We are trying to improve our trade relations with east Asian countries, including Korea, Thailand and Singapore.
In 1988 we negotiated and successfully implemented the free trade agreement with the United States, our most important trading partner.
Madam Speaker, as you know the FTA has paid off. Since it came into effect our exports to the United States have increased by more than $16 billion. This represents about 200,000 jobs. The FTA also gave us the power to review any measures taken by the United States including countervail and anti-dumping, while providing for an open process in which arbitrators fairly selected by both parties are able to quash decisions that are unfair.
The North American free trade agreement is a logical extension of the FTA. There is a very real potential for growth in sales of Canadian products and services to Mexico. It is also a fact that the United States plan to enter into some kind of free trade agreement with Mexico, with or without the participation of Canada.
If we had not been at the negotiating table any increase in trade with and international investment in Mexico would have gone to the United States.
In concluding, perhaps I may recapitulate. Further improving our standard of living will require strengthening the rate of productivity growth in this country. What the government can and must do is invest in macroeconomic stability and appropriate structural policies that expand the opportunities for people to work, invest and innovate.
That is what the government has done and will keep on doing.

subtopic: BORROWING AUTHORITY ACT, 1992-93 (NO. 2) MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have sat in the House all day and listened to presentations from both sides of the House

December 3, 1992

and different parties. I have been amazed by the different approaches that we have had.
As I sat here, as I am sure the Minister of Finance has done for some time, I have really tried to reflect on why we got ourselves into the position that we are in today. What I hear from the other side of the House-and I really do not believe that it believes this-is that it blames it on a policy that happened eight years ago, going on to nine years now, that it was left with a massive debt by the Liberal Party.
I really don't think it does believe that. It is certainly more than that. I think to put in perspective what we are looking at today and the mini budget that came out yesterday, we really need to look at why in the name of the Lord we are where we are today.
There are a number of things that happened. In the last eight and a half years I reckon that about five of them have been reasonably good years, kind of boomish. There has been an opportunity to create jobs and to reduce government spending, the things that the government is trying to do right now. When it takes eight years to get into the rather difficult situation the government has found itself in, it is very difficult to be able with a stroke of a pen and with one budget and perhaps one more main one to go before the next election to really want a policy that is counter to something that has taken eight years to achieve and have it disappear in a short time.
I will grant that the Minister of Finance had very little manoeuvring room. In that sense I would commiserate with him to try and produce a policy that was acceptable to his colleagues and the country, including the opposition.
However, in those eight and half years, and I will use that term even though it is a little less, government spending increased an average of about 4 per cent a year and that was higher than inflation. That was not a good move to begin with. I believe it could have done something about it.
The second thing, the interest payments on the debt, which now represent 26 per cent of all government expenditure, were growing at 9 per cent a year. When you have 9 per cent a year, the interest on the deficit and the national debt and government program spending increasing by 4 per cent a year, it is very difficult to be
Government Orders
able to do anything to change it. This has gone on essentially on average for the last 8 years.
There are other things that have caused us to have little manoeuvring room. The finance minister's projections have been off. I have made projections in my lifetime and it is very difficult with the world situation for the projections beyond plus or minus 10 per cent or 15 per cent. However, the projections have been very far off and I am sure the minister is embarrassed that they are so far off.
He gets advice from his colleagues and I am sure there is a desire to make it look good for each budget, but we are now at the ninth budget, I believe, and we are hearing the same stories and we are seeing the same projects that essentially leave us with the same deficit we had 8 years ago. A lot of Canadians have trouble understanding that.
On top of the other things that I mentioned, the growth in government spending and the 9 per cent increase on financing the debt, in that period of time there have been 32 tax increases which make it very difficult for the government now to use taxing measures to help it get out of this funny situation that it is in, this disastrous situation that it is in.
The deficit is about $34.5 billion. The government will be taking $122.2 billion and will be spending $156.7 billion. I may be out by $.1 billion. However, when I look at where the revenue comes from, the $122.2 billion, I see a large percentage of that being paid by the middle class. Fifty per cent alone of that comes from income tax. We all know in this House that income tax falls mostly on the middle class.
Twelve per cent on top of that 50 per cent comes from the GST. We know that the GST falls more heavily on the middle class because it spends proportionately more on consumer products. Thirteen per cent comes from the UI contributions of which more than half are paid by the middle class. Seven per cent comes from what are called in the finance department others, made up of cigarettes, alcohol and gas tax, again falling on the middle class.
I do not have to use much imagination nor be accused of exaggeration to say that when I add all this up I am looking at about 75 per cent to 85 per cent falling very

December 3, 1992
Government Orders
much on the middle class. Corporation tax accounts for 8 per cent on the figures produced a couple of days ago.
It was not too long ago that instead of being 8 per cent and 50 per cent, without the GST which makes it 8 per cent and 62 per cent, it was more along the lines of maybe 20 per cent and 30 per cent. I am going back a few years before this government took power, but certainly in 1984 the ratio was much different. The middle class paid less income tax as individuals and corporations paid a lot more.
The situation is that the government has found itself in a position where it cannot manoeuvre, so what does it do? I tend not to expect good projections, but I did have expectations as to what was going to happen. I was in my riding last night when I heard what the minister's measures were and I really honestly believed that I had missed something. It was not until this morning when I saw some of the national newspapers that I realized unfortunately I had not missed anything.
On the main point that concerns me in my riding-and I have heard practically every second speaker today speak on it-I have seen something happen that I never really thought would happen, even with this government. With the choice and with the difficult areas of high unemployment, a staggering deficit and a staggering national debt, there were choices.
